column10:
Metro Exodus is a really good game, but it is also completely different from the previous two Metro games. 

Exodus's gameplay is far more forgiving and action focused to the point where one should play on the Ranger difficulty just to have just a little-bit of the tense survival experience that made the two previous games great. With the new looting/crafting system and an abundance of loot/human enemies it is much easier to keep a stock of filters, ammunition and healing.  Filters and healing can be made at anytime so they are not an issue as long as one looks for materials. Shortages in anything only happen near the tail end of the game if one conserves their supplies and explores for loot. This change was necessary for the shift to a more open-world, but it fundamentally changes the game. 

The storytelling is also noticeably different. Exodus is the opposite of the previous two games that downplayed the political discourse and philosophy of the books to focus on the supernatural. There is barely any supernatural stuff in Exodus. The political and religious commentary is insanely blunt and over the top, but considering the history of Russia and Ukraine it is kindof understandable. Getting good endings is pretty straight forward with a balance of missions that demand you sneak around and some that let you gun down lots of bandits. Big issue with Exodus's story though is that the opening chapters are abit awkward, and that there is alot of idle unnatural expository dialogue throughout the entire story. There is also a few disconnects between the gameplay and story - such as the game telling you this is your chance to explore while your crew waiting for you is dying of thirst. 

Its a good game, but it feels more like some kind of Fallout/Metro hybrid than just another Metro game.

I've really, really tried liking this game. I always hear on social media how great it is, how it "changed" some people's opinions on how video games can be as a storytelling medium. But honestly, the game just feels poorly made.

The story is fine so far. Obviously, some people will be like "well, you haven't even beaten the game, so how would you know if it's bad or not!?" but the way that the NPCs move is enough to take me out of the immersion. Although it was released in 2019, it feels much older with how the characters move and interact with one another. Don't get me wrong, I love story games, especially first person shooter ones. But not only does the story feel underwhelming, the gun-play feels less rewarding than I anticipated. Utterly disappointing, considering it's the entire game. I know I can get much more satisfying gameplay from anything else.

Although, the world is absolutely stunning, and from what I've read on Wikipedia, the story is incredible, it just isn't enough to keep me captivated when the gameplay isn't fun, and the characters remind me of the Sims.
Don't bother with the DLC packs. Two Colonels is very short and Sam's Story is just full of basic control bugs that make it almost unplayable.
All 3 Metro games are great little games, very fun and good story. Each take about 20hrs to fully explore and complete.

It's a good game with some caveats. I had a good time with it but I don't think it's the "perfect" game people usually say it is. All told, it's a solid 8/10.

Here's what I liked:

* The gunplay is satisfying
* Gun sound design is really good, gunshots feel as loud and powerful as they should
* The story, while sometimes being a bit eh, is overall very good 
* Environmental storytelling is a big plus in this game
* Atmosphere is perfect
* The horror elements are well done, relying more on suspense than cheap shock value

Here's what I didn't like:

* The English voice acting is not great. The sound mixing for the voice lines is off, so voices appear too "warm" and close to you to feel right
* God, the crashing is insane. I had a rough patch where crashes were occurring every five minutes or so. It seems the game will crash for any reason, varying by user, so it's really hard to nail down a fix (I just trucked through constant crashes), it got to the point where I wondered if I could finish the game at all
* Stealth is sometimes weird, and one enemy spotting you for .2 seconds (before being killed silently) will sometimes tip off the entire encampment to your presence - it's easier to just start shootin'
* The story warms up right as it's about to end, which can leave you feeling blue-balled but in a good way

For the voice acting, the game lets you choose the native language for audio and maintains the translated subtitles. I ended up playing the game in Russian (where the voice acting is much better) and just relied on subtitles.

Overall, it's a solid game. For how cheap it is nowadays, it's worth giving it a shot. Just give the story some time to warm up and you'll probably love it. New Game+ support is also awesome with modifiers etc.

Massive disappointment. I have encountered two game breaking bugs. One was the lighthouse freeze, where the game freezes on the second open world map when exiting a cave. Which I had to fix by turning everything to low and walk out of the cave while looking at the ground and pray to all the divine that the game wont freeze. Too bad this bug is not in the first two hours meaby then they would bother to fix it. And no it is not hardware issue since the rest of the game runs on 144+ FPS on high. The second bug was in the DLC where the screen would go black and stay that way. That one was fixed by luck.

There is also the scuffed lighting which goes through some kind of grey filter which is most visible when taking the gas mask off as the filter is switch off and then on during the gas mask animation. And sometimes some grass just decides to float. But that is miner issue.

Otherwise, the textures and models are great. The game does look good. Too bad that it is supposed to be a game and not a painting.

So how is the gameplay? The shooting is passable, the crafting is pointless since there is nothing to really craft. Weapon upgrades you have to pick up from dropped weapons, suit upgrades you have to find. I have played on the hardcore difficulty and not once did I run out of ammo, filters or medkits. 

Say goodbye mutans and hello to generic zombies. Actually say goodbye to all interesting supernatural stuff from previous games.

The "cutscenes" (or more precisely unskippable dialog) are needlessly drawn out which would not be that big of a problem if the story was interesting. You go on a trip and meet religious cults, slavers, people living as one with the forest, cannibals, really it is post-apocalypse 101.

Some of the story could flow better if Artyom spoke. He does not. Why? He is not mute and speaks during the loading screens so why does he not answer direct questions? The DLC characters talk so why not the main character?

The Two Colonels DLC is one loooooong cutscene with little bit of gameplay in the middle centred around a guy you know is already dead. The flamethrower could be better.

The Sam DLC is substantial improvement over the first DLC. So it ends up being OK. It actually might be slightly better than the main game. No flametrower but there are cute bats. It is also the one part of the game you should definitely play with Russian dub. Or at least any other one then English. Since it might be weird when Sam the American switches from english to english.

Overall OK shooter, terrible generic story. Should have been called Metro: Call of Duty.

Sure it looks incredible but its cut scene after un-skip-able cut scene, a couple minutes of play then another cut scene or gameplay is relentlessly wrestled away to an annoying degree,  I spent more time hands off and waiting than playing. The first time was somewhat bearable, the second time I uninstalled after 90 min and of that 90 min, maybe 30 min was hands on. I made dinner, did dishes and some laundry while "playing" Metro. Painful.

Think the devs spent too much time making pretty maps and a ridiculous amount of scripted events instead of making sure the game play actually works and is consistent. 

The stealth and combat leaves much to be desired. Metro still suffers from it's previous iterations of stealth of, as long as you're in the dark you're an invisible assassin. With the same caveat of being screwed as soon as you get spotted with enemies having a 6th sense of where you are despite breaking contact and relocating. 

Combat is wonky at best with enemies just running around full sprint, suddenly turning 180 at an inhuman speed and doing a cod style no scope killing you instantly. Artyom is akin to a wet napkin when it comes to taking damage at normal difficulty yet enemies can take way more punishment outside of head shots. It takes roughly 3 shots from any weapon to just kill you outright, if you land in fire you die in 0.5 seconds so I hope you like looking at the loading screen. 

So let's get to the crashes and bugs. The game has frozen multiple times with it ever only successfully managing to launch a bug report once which is ironic. It seems that the longer you play in a session the higher your chances become of the game crashing. Also be ready to expect the game to say "corrupted auto save please rewrite" when you relaunch the game aka whatever progress you made before the crash is now just gone. Bugs are just enemies shooting through solid objects and spotting you through solid objects. My most recent experience is a mutant just phasing through a closed door because it had no other path so it said "fuck it noclip enabled" so it could get a free hit before dying. During the final cut scene the game crashed during the loading screen which was amazing it couldn't load a scripted cut scene. Movement is also weird with trying to sprint up slopes sending you flying and slowly coming back down like you're on the moon, stairs are notorious for this and sometimes stairs will just stop you dead until you back up and try again. 

Kind of speaks volumes by itself that only 27% of people on steam have actually finished the game as of this post. Good thing these jokers took Epics money to put it on their store exclusively for 6 months they need it.
METRO 10/10 AS ALWAYS!

The best of the Metro series and my favorite game in the apocalypse genre.  Combat feels smooth, crafting and equipment maintenance is ever present without being overly demanding. The writing and voice acting is excellent -- it has some of the most human interactions you'll find in a video game.  Philosophically the depth of story is found in the individual characters, cults, and warlords you encounter rather than Artyom's internal dialogue, which at face value is rather cliche.  The karma system feels more natural than previous metro games and you can pick up a lot of subtle hints and warnings from the other characters to guide you toward the "right" choices simply by paying attention to their dialogue. Playing a moral route also requires more diverse tactics such as use of stealth and understanding some of the faction politics in each level. However if mad listening skills and story are not your thing, the game is perfectly playable as a standard shooter blasting your way through everything.  The environments are top tier -- harsh hostile open world levels juxtaposed with the cozy sanctuary of your train as it rumbles through abandoned wasteland.  This is a comfort game I come back to every couple years and it has yet to feel aged out.  If you are new to Metro I suggest starting here and then playing the others if you enjoy this one.

Well, just wow. This game really surprised me. I went into Exodus not expecting much, thought it was just another bland Post-apocalyptic game with nothing new too offer and no real impacting material. Booooy was i wrong. Ill happily admit that. Throughout my playthru, i found that this game was just full of heart, creativity, rich lore, great story telling, characters that feel real and alive, amazing gameplay mechanics, and sooo much more. Exodus really sets a new bar for what an apocalyptic game should strive for. Its not a short game, but it also does not exceed its welcome either. One of my favorite things that i really loved that was done EXTREMELY well is the dialog. I truly enjoy when games make you feel like your apart of that world, a world lived in and not just lifeless, and Exodus just does it right. I lost track of how many times i just sat back soaked in and enjoyed the banter/arguments/convos of the world around me. I know not everyone likes that  but being a story nut and lore fanatic, i just truly love how they went about it here. You can tell they really put love and care into getting the player immersed in the story that they wanted to tell. And daam did they do an amazing job in doing that. Solid 9/10.

The day steam gives us the option to post a review with neither a recommendation nor a non-recommendation, but a happy in between is when this game will receive accurate reviews, among others. This game was pretty fun for a while, though i experienced noticeable audio issues like certain sounds just not playing where they should play, and npcs completely talking over eachother to the point where you literally don't know what is being said. Once I got to the later parts of the game, where you start to explore different parts of the map, I found myself uneasy with the fact that I couldn't go back and get more stuff. The map moves with the story but it was kind of upsetting. Also it doesn't help that I just got completely bored by the later stages. The characters are extremely hollow. Super conflicted about this game. In the end I had a positive experience, but I also went through a sizeable slump of genuine frustration with it. I played on Ranger Hardcore difficulty for my first playthrough, and the game does not feel like it has been playtested enough for these difficulty settings to ensure a fully satisfying experience. I want to stress that the issue isn't so much the difficulty itself (it is very manageable and fun most of the time), but those moments when the difficulty clashes with other aspects of the game which are clearly designed with other difficulty modes in mind, like its encounter and level design.

As for the encounters, the first two major levels of the game ([spoiler] the Volga and the Caspian [/spoiler]) are mostly S.T.A.L.K.E.R.-like open world experiences, in which you engage with enemies or react to involuntary enemy encounters as you see fit, with factors like ammo and resource scarcity meaningfully informing your gameplay expression. I found these levels, for the most part to be extremely satisfying experiences. There is however, a scripted encounter towards the end of [spoiler] the Caspian [/spoiler], which is so close-quarters, deadly and narrow, that any amount of creative play becomes impossible. As any mistake is essentially punished with an instant death, you are unable to react to the situation in any interesting manner or roll with your mistake, and the entire encounter feels uncharacteristically "arcade-y" as a result, essentially asking you to find a way to perfectly execute the fight. The encounter is very clearly designed for a more forgiving difficulty level, but on Ranger Hardcore It creates a very different type of challenge than the game has put forth before that, and does not really play to the game's strengths at all, which made it very frustrating.

The second issue in [spoiler] the Caspian [/spoiler] is that game does not provide you with a reliable place to save (i.e. a bed at basecamp) out of the gate. On Ranger Hardcore, you cannot manually save the game, so you are reliant on autosaves, with the only way to force one being to sleep in a bed. Because of the way the game strings you along through the story segments at a pretty brisk place, this does not become a problem immediately, as the game automatically saves at key moments of these segments. However, once you go off to explore, those key autosaves are often all you have to fall back on, meaning that, if you die during exploration (i.e. while trying to find a bed to save in), you can get caught in a loop where you have to replay a specific encounter again, because the game saved right before it, then have to gather all the resources and ammo pickups from fallen enemies again, then have to return to basecamp, because the only workbench you know about is there, and then set out into the map again, to find a bed to save, potentially to just die once more and lose all this "progress," which amounted to meaningless busywork. This can get frustrating really really quickly and could have been avoided if some more thought had been put into the placement of autosaves / beds.

Lastly, the [spoiler] Taiga [/spoiler] level has issues, which I expect are completely independent of difficulty settings. Compared to previous levels, it is intensely linear. This is not a problem per se (the game has other, really really good linear levels), but because it is presented in a similar manner as the previous two open-world levels, it is very disappointing to make it through the entire level, expecting it to open up at any minute, just to realize that the entire thing has ended (and was very short). This would not be as much of an issue if the level had been fun, however large stretches of it are spent stealthing past a faction of enemies, which are clearly not entirely antagonistic, and which the game explicitly asks you not to kill. As the only nonlethal option in your arsenal are stealth takedowns, this severely limits the ways you can engage with enemies here. This is doubly frustrating as the game takes away your entire arsenal anyways and replaces it with [spoiler] a cool crossbow [/spoiler], which I would have loved to actually use, at all, but as a result, never had a reason to, rendering the posed challenge of "How will you survive without the weapons you're used to?" completely mute. I suppose if you don't care about the game's karma system or ending, or don't have any issue roleplaying as a huge piece of sh*t, you could just rambo your way through, and it'd probably be a better experience, but I felt pressured into a specific, extremely boring playstyle. The stealth in this game is simply not fun and complex enough to support an extended stealth segment like this.

Despite all that, I think this game is good. It has very low lows, to me, but those are outweighed by the game's best moments and its excellent storytelling. But I'd recommend learning from my mistakes and to not play this game on Ranger Hardcore, unless you feel particularly resistant to the kinds of frustrations I experienced.

SPOILERS: This review spoils essentially every part of the game.

Metro Exodus is a game that I really wish I could've loved: A tactical stealth-shooter where you trek across the Soviet wasteland into parts unknown while battling raiders, mutants, hunger, and resource scarcity? Sounds like a good time to me! While the gunplay is satisfying, the locations detailed and interesting, and the vibes immaculate, I found myself stuck within a mediocre narrative I wish I could escape from and a tedious gameplay loop that left a lot to be desired. The game plays a lot more like an early 2010s Far Cry title than a traditional Metro game, except Exodus does away with merchants, currency, radio towers, and charismatic lunatic dictators. I can also tell there is a lot of inspiration taken from the Stalker series of games: radiation pockets hiding loot, strange floating anomalies, etc. 

The cast of characters here are serviceable at best, boring and uninspired at worst, and mediocre overall. Everyone is a one-note trope with zero room to grow. The dialogue is generic, boring, and poorly written, and the stilted and mediocre voice acting doesn’t help at all. Exodus has a strange problem where the characters all talk so much yet say very little. There is a LOT of exposition here - too much actually. I will sit and listen to characters speak for what feels like forever and when I think they're done and I begin to walk away they will continue yapping away. If I'm feeling bored to death by the people I'm supposed to care about then something has gone very wrong. Artyom, being a silent character, has no spoken interactions with his wife. What is the point of the player and her being romantically involved? Is Artyom supposed to be an avatar or a character? The game can’t seem to decide.

Enemies are pathetically easy and the AI is borderline braindead. Bandits be baited out of cover and can’t aim to save their lives. Mutants are zero threat and go down in a couple of hits. Demons and mutants in earlier games were terrifying, with large packs running around and terrorizing the player at their most vulnerable. However, in Exodus I could walk around most enemies and I never experienced any fear of dying to enemies. Similarly, I never felt like I was running out of medical equipment and ammunition, regardless of what difficulty I played on, because I could always craft more. I never found resources to be scarce and I hit more than enough headshots and took down enough enemies through stealth as to never drain all my ammo. I found that the feeling of being an impoverished scavenger turning over every nook and cranny for a single bullet did not return from previous Metro titles.

When I first completed Metro Exodus last year I received the "bad" ending. I lost all three of squad members and died after getting the medication. Part of this was me not paying enough attention to the dialogue and instructions from other characters and part of it was me not understanding that a morality system existed in the game at all. I won't blame the game for me not realizing this, and during my revisit to the Metro universe, I kept in mind to listen to dialogue ques and make sure to do good things and avoid harming people whenever I had the chance.

In my quest for the "Good" ending I've had to fight not only mutants, bandits, and cannibals, but also the games tedious and obtuse "morality" system. Based on your actions during missions, exploration, and interactions with NPCs, you can gain or lose what I'll refer to as "morality points". You can tell what kind of morality points you're getting based on the color of a flash on your screen after doing specific actions. For example, executing surrendering enemies and shooting slaves gives a black negative flash and freeing slaves and cultists gives a white positive flash. Simple enough.

The Volga area is very straightforward: If I want Duke to survive at the end, I cannot kill the merchants and cultists, but I have free reign to slaughter bandits and mutants. Bandit camps are also very clearly labeled with skulls and random gore and corpses. I checked my targets, completed some rudimentary stealth sections, and managed to get out of the bridge without a firefight.

The cannibal bunker known as the Ark is a shooting gallery where the dynamic and satisfying gunplay is given a chance to truly shine. There's not much to say about this area, it's a 20 or so minute underground dungeon where the Colonel makes himself look like an idiot for listening to the "government" on the radio. The player can see the danger coming from a mile away and I was not at all surprised by the twist of everyone in the Ark being a deranged cannibal.

The Caspian area is where I started having some trouble. The Caspian is a large desert environment with many open sight-lines and is home to three main types of human enemies: slaves, tribals, and slavers/thugs. I and many others (I did a lot of googling and forum searching for this section) had a very difficult time trying to differentiate between these three types of enemy. I've seen it argued that I should listen to dialogue to figure out who the slavers are in groups, but not every encounter has subtitled dialogue and it can be difficult to know who is speaking when everyone has masks on. Because I can't tell if killing groups of enemies would have me shoot a tribal or slave in the process, and thus net me an unknown quantity of "bad morality points" (which could ruin the good run I'm aiming for), I'm often forced to try to run away or restart from a save. I started quick-saving before every encounter not out of a fear of dying, but out of a fear of shooting the "wrong" enemies. Also, and I'm not entirely sure if this is a glitch or not, very occasionally I am in a  combat situation with a group of mixed enemies and I am not given the prompt to knock some of them out, forcing me to run away or try again. It's not fun, it's unintuitive, and it made this section feel like a slog.

There was a point where I asked myself, "isn't it silly and perhaps just a little bit insane that I have to google which groups of slavers I can and can’t kill?" Moreover, I've seen posts from people saying that Damir still left the train even after they had freed all the slaves, given Giul her family portrait, and spared Saul. It's never made clear just how much you have to do to make him stay, which is probably a contributing factor to why only 17% of all players have had him stay at the end of the Caspian, compared to 1/3 players managing to keep Duke.

The more linear Taiga area is much welcomed change of pace. This area is far more straightforward and features Artyom fighting and/or sneaking past a splintered group called the Children of the Forest. Two factions exist, the Pioneers and the Pirates. the Pirates are more outwardly hostile to the Spartans while the Pioneers, led by a mysterious woman of the woods, are less. You can avoid hurting this group much easier than you can hurting slaves in the desert, given the wooded environment full of cover that lends itself to sneaking around. Bandits are open season in this area as well. This level, as well as the final section in the city, are my favorite parts of the game, feeling much more like the older Metro games.

Final Score: 5/10. It's mid. Many such cases! I know I spent most of this review tearing apart the game but I didn’t completely hate it. I will VERY SOFTLY recommend it to anyone who feels they can put up with the annoying and tedious parts of the game. I seriously wish Steam would introduce a "neutral" option for these reviews, but since that doesn't exist, oh well.

Metro Exodus gets a lot of praise and rightly so but I have to admit that I had a miserable time despite really liking the previous games. I played through the prequels several times and always enjoyed my time with them. The series has a phenomenal setting and really immersive gameplay that keeps you hooked in this desolate and mysterious world.

However, Exodus went into a direction that really put me off but it really depends on what type of player you are. Exodus is very much know for having open maps and encouraging scavenging which are honestly nice additions that enhance the overall strong atmosphere.

My biggest gripe with Exodus is that the game is so invested in its mediocre characters, dialogues and story that it becomes an absolute nuisance. Previous games always put you through cutscenes and some dialogues which elaborated on characters or a certain event. However, Exodus features characters that won't shut up for a minute. Every encounter with random characters is filled with extensive dialogues and you will often find yourself in situations where several NPCs are spouting out exposition over each other. In addition, the game loves to take the control away from you during cutscenes which are delivered in such a static way. The player will often be forced to watch cutscenes which take away all sort of agency and this gets infuriating because almost every mission or encounter has extensive animations which take control away from you. There is a serious issue where you feel absolutely disconnected with everything.

Now, this wouldn't be much of an issue if the characters and dialogues would be compelling but they simply are not engaging. Dialogues are contrived, stilted and clumsily delivered with a lack of nuance or even any sort of finesse. The devs obviously cared a lot for players to care about characters and the world but it requires a lot of patience to get through the extensive expositions dump at every occasion. The main character Artyom is treated like an absolute braindead child and at some point you realize that the writing won't get any better. The intro sequence is quite lengthy but even when the game opens up, it will still wrestle the controls from you and force you to listen to exposition. Every character is just a walking vehicle for exposition and absolutely mundane dialogue with no substance.

Naturally, this is entirely subjective and many enjoy the increased interaction but I honestly feel like the writing is to weak to really carry the game. It's absolutely boring and sometimes even insulting with the way that the game treats you. I usually don't mind these parts as much as long as the gameplay holds up but I'm sorry to say that Exodus left a really bad initial impression.

The open world is not as engaging due to the slow pace and encounters which suffer from absolutely braindead AI. Firefights and stealths are a joke due to the AI which just feels almost broken. The scavenging is enjoyable but the environment suffers from enemies with weak AI and the newly added zombies are such a joke that it breaks immersion.

The game looks stunning with amazing audio, it has some cool gun customization and there is lots to like. But there was a point where the constant forcefed dialogue was suffocating. The cutscenes took away all agency from the player and the actual conversations are stale. 

If you don't like old school cinematic cutscenes and overly long dialogues, just avoid this game.

It's hard to explain just how much I love the Metro games, but equally hard to nail down exactly why.

For Exodus, it comes down to the design. Every map is handcrafted, tree by rock by easter egg hidden in a shack you don't have a quest reason to visit. There are better shooters, better sandboxes, I think Redux has better atmosphere and that supernatural icing on this deliciously bleak cake, BUT, nothing out there makes me feel the way I do playing Exodus on Ranger Hardcore. It's greater than the sum of its parts, made with love and polish so this game punches way above the small dev studio's weight. 

I *love* how the level structure works, with claustrophobic linear levels alternating with the most fantastic open world levels I've ever played, made with more attention to detail than most AAA games marketed on their sandboxes. The shooting is weighty and if you're playing "correctly", you'll always be thinking about whether spending ammo in this particular fight is worth it so pulling the trigger has a kind of mental impact FarCry or whatever just can't match. I like the survival elements that are lightweight enough they don't hamper the experience, but cause you to always be scrounging, to go a little further out of your way looking for loot, to take your time looking around the stunning environments. I love the weapon design where guns look post-apocalyptic but not like they were cobbled together by Fallout raiders high on their supply. I love how the story revolves around a trainload of comrades looking for a better home. I love how you make choices through actions instead of dialogue options. I love the stealth, although it's much less of an emphasis than Redux.

Actually yeah let me throw on a couple other things I prefer in Redux: the supernatural stuff. I don't like horror games, but I love spooky, atmospheric games. Metro 2033 and LL struck that balance for me where I never felt like I could actually enjoy scary stuff for once. Another thing I miss is the lack of humanimals. They are everywhere in Exodus and are lame. They're just Fallout ghouls with less interesting visual design; boring to fight, annoying to encounter, uninspiring to look at. I would much rather have run across roving Watcher packs, maybe different "evolutions" depending on the regions. Librarians, Demons... ANYTHING else.

But when my only complaints are comparisons to its prequels that boil down to "I don't like this one enemy" and "this non-horror-focused game isn't as scary"... well that kinda speaks volumes.

I was sadly pretty disappointed with this addition to the Metro Catalogue. They really missed the mark on what made Metro special. I wish that the last 10% of the game was the entire game, that is the only part of this game that met the feel of Metro. Everything else feels like Far Cry. I like that they have moved this toward as a more open world experience, but I want to explore post apocalyptic nuclear winter Russia/Ukraine. Why they felt the need to bring us to a desert and a taiga is beyond me. There are a few core things that really made me not enjoy the game over all...

- The crafting at first feels cool... but then your realize... oh I can just craft a med-kit, or ammo, or filters almost anytime I need them. Completely killing that tension that the original Metro's builds by having to manage your very limited supplies. Hell, even having bullets as a currency which was such a cool idea, was scrapped.
- This also kills stealth. Stealth in the original Metro games were not entirely optional. You were out gunned and out manned. You took stealth more seriously because you couldn't afford to waste supplies in a gunfight. Gun fights in this game felt like a joke. The AI is far too dumb, the supplies you have are plentiful and as long as you have cover, you pretty much have unlimited heals. I never felt at risk, there are even times I would just charge the enemy head first knifing people.
- Crafting also killed the tension of gas mask as well. This was such a core part... the gasping for air... the feeling of not being able to linger because you only have so much oxygen. Pretty much completely gone and almost entirely un-utilized for the majority of the game
- Are there even any gas mask effects anymore? I don't remember getting my mask smudged with blood or water or snow in this game... only patching a hole and leeches.
- They pretty much killed the psychological horror aspects the game except at the very end - super disappointed in this. I loved the idea of the horror being so significant that it is imprinted on the location. I wish they had expanded on this.
- I found it way more difficult to be invested in the story. I don't even know why. Almost every dialogue with the exception of the end of the game felt more like roadblocks and filler than something meant to be there. I always felt like I wish I could skip it and get back to the game or wanting NPC's to get out of my way. I never felt this way ever with the original Metros.
- The in-game chatter dialogue felt was too sanitized... like this is a supposed to be an adult game, but the insults sound like something out of a pixar game.
- Some of the weapon design felt good, but some of it felt a little too steampunk and unrealistic. Even the AK just seemed to have a weird design.
- Also, forgot to mention that there are still some game breaking bugs. My first play through I like 80% the desert area and had a bug that prevented me from progressing the only fix was to restart the whole level from the beginning... which is like 60% of the entire game. My second play through was less buggy, the only major bug I had was being dropped out of the sky and getting stuck falling under the ground forever - I was expecting there to be a teleport plane, like most games if you somehow glitch under the map, but no dice here. Had to reload - not a huge deal but kinda breaks immersion.


- What I enjoyed was the combat and weapon customization. Although the AI was bad and didn't feel challenging or intelligent, the gun play felt fun.
- The desert map did feel a bit disjointed compared to the taiga map, but from a design aspect they did a good job even if it wasn't what I was looking for.
- They clearly put a lot of time and thought into the maps' progression and flow. I very rarely ever felt like I was picking up an new inferior attachment. Almost all attachments were actual upgrades.

To be clear this game isn't bad by any means. It is good for what it is, but what it is, is not a Metro game... It just isn't. The tone, the feel, and the core elements are just not there. I want to see a open world Metro game that has handcraft areas that are seamed together through a metroidvania style progression. I want the same brutality that existed in the first games. The starvation for supplies. The feeling of being at the bottom of the food chain. The uninhabitable unforgiving surface. Way more psychological horror elements. I want do dredge through the underbelly of the Metro. I don't want Far Cry in Metro. Sadly, I doubt I will ever see this game.

Recommended only if it's on a discount and you're a fan of the Metro series.

Graphics and sound design are superb. And gunplay can be a lot of fun with high variety of customizations for iconic Metro guns. There is some replay value as well, with new game+ unlocking more challenging ways of playing. But other than that, I feel like Metro exodus offers remarkably little:
To start off with, there are five main maps/chapters in the base game, and just two of them are open - Volga river and Caspian sea. You can free roam, but there's very little to explore, apart from bandit camps, which you can either shoot up or stealth your way through, which is highly repetitive. The other three chapters are completely linear, much like the last two games.
Moving on to gameplay mechanics, Exodus, at times, is genuinely worse than Last light and 2033:
Movement is extremely slippery, melee attack is highly unreliable and glitchy, some realistic features like guns jamming and Artyom getting exhausted from running only end up making the game more tedious.. Resource management is basically non-existent due to crafting ability. Mutants aren't even remotely scary anymore, as you can literally just avoid them. There is also a boss fight against a giant bear, which was recycled from Last light.
Last but not least, story of exodus departs from the usual Metro storytelling and leads the characters to explore the world outside of ruined Moscow. There are a few interesting plot twists, but dialogue and character development is mostly underwhelming, since there is no ambiguity as to who's good and who bad.
Overall, I think this game doesn't offer much for its price and advertising as an "open world" title. Like I said, only get it if you adore the Metro franchise. And make sure you do so at a discount price.

I'm not gonna lie, the game has its problems, I dont mean problems like bugs/crashes as I didn't encounter many crashes or bugs during my playthrough, I mean problems like certain things in the game that feel kinda "off". Things that other people have talked about in their reviews like the fact that a silent protagonist doesn't work as well as it did in previous games or how it has at time repetitives dialogues for the enemies, most of that stuff its true and I can argue against it but GOD I just cant give this game a rating that is not 5 stars.

As well as the rest of the games I LOVE the atmosphere in these games, they always make me feel like I AM Artyom, the way I always get inmerse into these games is something i hadn't felt since I played TLOU for the first time. Many times I found myself listening to my fellow rangers companions conversations and sitting with them while drinking like if i was one of them, I love how they talk about what just happened in the previous level, or about stuff happening during the levels themselves, how sometimes they talk about their own desires and goals, I can confidently say that I listened to every conversation I could, with my fellow rangers, with npcs around the map, with Miller and with Anna.

I just cant explain how this game made me feel like I was into his world, I played the story mode over 6 times, got every achievement and still I find myself thinking I could do another playthrough again.

Spending more than an hour on levels like "Winter/Autumn/Summer/Spring" Triggerin every conversation I could, listening to every dialogue with Anna and listening to the radio for clues about the world around us is something I had never done with such feeling in any other game.

This game is just beautifull and a must play to me. The whole saga is a must play to me is really one of those games I wanna remember for the rest of my life, I just cant give it any other rating but 5 stars.

And a quick shoutout to Anna that was my favorite character in the game, I really love how she is a strong woman when needed but never stops being a loving wife to artyom and a great friend with the rest of the crew. Anna you're the best ^^

This is one of those titles that stuck with me long after I finished it and that I kept thinking about for several days.

The game is set 2 years after the events of the previous chapter.

Our protagonists, Artyom, Anna, Miller and some former Spartans, tired of life underground and after discovering that there are other survivors living on the surface, embark on a journey on board a train in search of a place where they can settle a colony and start a new life outside the metro.

This "exodus" will mean that throughout the storyline we will visit a variety of different places, each characterized by its own peculiarities. The bombings occurred about 25 years earlier and therefore a large part of the territories are still highly irradiated, inhospitable, infested with mutants or in any case difficult to inhabit.

The game will let us discover many small settlements, each of which, following the wars and the absence of a central government, has had different events and has evolved and adapted to the circumstances as best it could.
This allows for a very varied narrative that is free from the setting of the tunnels, which bored me a bit after Last Light. And towards the end, when we’ll have to return to another subway and visit its tunnels, we will discover that even there events took a very different turn compared to what happened under Moscow.

Initially I didn't appreciate the first "open" level (The Volga), coming from the linear gameplay of the previous chapters I found it a bit distracting. However, once I got past the first adaptation phase, the game hooked me. In fact, it is not so much the gameplay that popped, but rather the various stories that we will gradually discover. Each chapter is somewhat comparable to one of the Fallout vaults, and so the thing I found most exciting was trying to understand what happened and how it got to the current situation.

The environmental narration also helps a lot in this, very carefully crafted, full of visual clues as well as the classic fragments of diaries scattered around. All this captured me and immersed me in the stories, I felt right there, sometimes inside and sometimes alongside Artyom, while I explored [spoiler] a settlement inhabited by cannibals, a desert inspired by Mad Max and governed by the "Baron" (Immortan Joe?), or even a forest populated by pirates and beast-men who live in the trees… [/spoiler]

All the characters have endured extremely hard stories, and are the often tragic fruit of their experiences. Despite everything at the end of each episode, however dramatic, there sometimes remains a glimmer of hope, perhaps reflecting the vision of Dmitry Glukhovsky (not having read the novels I can't say for sure, but I can certainly say that I felt like to read them while playing this title).
To all this I would add that aliens are not present in the main plot, unlike the previous chapters, and this makes it in my opinion much more linear and simple to follow, and ultimately I appreciated it much more than that of 2033 and Last Light.

Speaking of pure gameplay, however in this chapter we will have more freedom of movement thanks to the introduction of semi-open world hubs, where in addition to being able to decide whether to have a stealth or more aggressive approach, sometimes we will be able to choose the order in which to face the objectives.
This might be a bit reminiscent of the immersive sim genre, although in reality everything will be much simpler and more linear. The result, in my opinion, is quite balanced and enjoyable, and contributes to immersion in the general atmosphere.

Moving on to the graphics section, I must say that I also found this to be exceptional. I played the version with Ray Tracing and I found everything really well done, non-repetitive and with great attention to detail. As already mentioned, the environmental storytelling is really effective, also thanks to the beautiful graphics. The artistic direction is excellent, all the settings had a strong visual impact on me, without ever boring me, really managing to immerse myself in the atmosphere.

The same thing I can say about the sound, whose well-crafted effects amplify even more the emotions gradually transmitted by the environment, the tension of walking alone inside radioactive tunnels full of corpses or in a sandstorm. The soundtrack is also excellent, discreet and effective.

In conclusion, a game that I approached because I felt the need for a bit of a post-apocalyptic “fix” and which definitely exceeded all expectations, leaving me more than satisfied, and above all intrigued to finally read the novels on which it is based. Highly recommended!

Metro Exodus is a thrilling and immersive game that combines the survival horror and stealth elements of the previous Metro games with a more open and dynamic world. The game follows Artyom, a survivor of the nuclear war that devastated the Earth, as he leads a group of Spartans on a journey aboard the Aurora train. Along the way, they encounter various factions, mutants, and environmental hazards, as well as glimpses of hope and humanity.

The game features four different regions, each with its own season, climate, and challenges. The regions are not fully open-world, but rather large sandbox areas that allow for exploration and side quests. The game also has several linear levels that are more reminiscent of the classic Metro style. The game gives you a lot of freedom in how you approach each situation, whether you prefer stealth, combat, or a mix of both. You can also customize your weapons and gear using a crafting system that requires you to scavenge for resources.

The game's graphics are stunning, with realistic lighting, shadows, and weather effects. The game also has a great sound design, with immersive ambient noises and a fitting soundtrack. The voice acting is decent, although some of the dialogue is cheesy or clichéd. The game's story is engaging and emotional, with multiple endings depending on your choices and actions. The game also has a lot of replay value, with different modes, difficulties, and secrets to discover. The game is about 15-20 hours long, depending on how you play and explore.

Metro Exodus is a must-play for fans of the Metro series, as well as anyone who enjoys a well-crafted and atmospheric FPS game. The game is a masterpiece of gameplay, visuals, and storytelling, and deserves a high score of 9.5/10.

The devs put a lot of work into making this game. But playing it feels so constantly underwhelming as in so much was rushed and abandoned (especially some glaring bugs that have been there since LAUNCH).
      Bullet resources are finite and most of time simply irrational. Human enemies contain like 1-5 bullets when looted. Yet wildlife is procedurally respawned. Killed a large winged demon thinking it would finally stop bothering you? Voila there is another one and always just one for you.
      The wildlife almost never display any interaction with each other yet are all willing to kamikaze you. You miss one shot from far away and somehow ALL OF THEM in the vicinity knows exactly where you are and go kamikaze. There is no dismemberment, no wounding/slowing down before death. The sheer quantity of wildlife to be killed - and respawned! - is unbelievable given that the story protagonist is NOT a pest squad. Did I mention HUNDREDS of male human somehow living inside a bunker expecting 10 or so outsiders to come as food?
       Different regions had either cliche Cult, Mad Max, or tree hugger setting but no real life to sustain it. There would be a slave economy in story but not a single resource caravan or patrol on the road. Just you and the wildlife in the wild. 
       The first few chapters have you collecting unique gears and upgrades which are fantastic. But just when you collected every upgrade, the story forbids you to use them, like it's just out to troll you. 
       They put a lot of work into the weapon modifications and lovable story companions. But to keep those companions alive you have to avoid using weapons in almost every specific level that is nicely crafted. You have to stealth, which the devs happened to NOT put too much work in.
       The story itself seems rushed. A power figure known to murder and rape would suddenly be reconciled and spared at the last and only brief time you meet him. Someone who has been fighting harshly against an external threat would suddenly be totally open to a new group of foreigners. Important characters pop out and give you long earful to stuff you with all the background settings at once.
       The tree hugger folks, according to story, are somewhat confused teenagers? Yet their model height and built is identical to the real grown-ups you have been seeing. Their voice casting, even in Russian, sounds unbelievably identical to the bandits and slavers you have been hearing.
       Besides the constant underwhelming feeling? Great game.

Wow. I grew up with e.g. PlayStation 1 etc and only relatively recently discovered these modern computer games. I'm using a Mac Mini M2 Pro and the game is running on maximum graphics settings with a really good frame rate. The visuals are absolutely stunning - at some points in some levels it looks photorealistic. The mechanics of the gameplay (e.g. the various items you have to use such as the gas mask and the charger etc) feel really immersive and challenging. Altogether I've been absolutely blown away by how compelling the experience is of playing this game. The final level in particular is utterly mind-bending; the artistry of how the different themes (e.g. science-fiction, horror, surrealism, and an increasing sense of grief) all come together is stunningly well done. I've been playing on some sort of 'normal' difficulty and the learning curve has been just right i.e. it's been pretty hard on the first play-through and I'm really looking forward to playing through again on higher difficulty levels. There were some sequences where I had to use night-vision goggles to clear out some abandoned building in total darkness and it felt electrifying i.e. really intense and detailed gameplay and I was on the edge of my seat. The story feels artful and very thoughtfully written; it makes the cutscenes (which are quite long and you can't skip them) ok to sit through (!). My only negative comment would be that, on my operating system at least, the game is quite buggy i.e. it quits to desktop every 2-3 plays at some point; this issue is seemingly related to certain keypresses and/or the triggering of notifications within Steam (for e.g. achievement badges). But it's worth it overall. I've been really blown away by the overall quality and experience of the game.

Complete... Without a proper save system.

I got this game for my father. He really enjoyed the previous two games and was warming up to this one. 

He got into the whole semi-open world concept. He was off-put at first given the huge change from the first two games, but he got used to it. 

Well, at some point during the Volga chapter, he decided to do a main mission because it was just close to him, so he figured he'd just do it.

He had no idea it was a one-way street. There would be no way to return to Volga. Though there was no warning, no reason to really believe that, and it would put him into a huge linear section of multiple hours before just plopping him into the best semi-open section. And he had plenty of looting and sidequests left to do in Volga, he wasn't near done with that section. And he's not like, a veteran gamer. He doesn't have that experience that you need to check the wiki before doing a main mission to see if it is a point of no return.

However, this was no big deal. The beauty of the Metro games is that you can reload chapters. If you miss something, you lose 10, or 20 minutes maybe at most. It was a really nice system. It also remembered your progression. Sure those games had flaws too, but overall it was solid. 

So I thought "Okay, he'll just have to load the Volga chapter, it'll be easy. Just like the last game you can just reload a chapter and play through it.

In this game, you CAN reload chapters... So what's the problem? The problem is, that you reload the Volga chapter... From the beginning. It doesn't keep track of your looting, your progression... You start AT THE BEGINNING OF THE VOLGA CHAPTER. The chapter that is a semi-open world that can take over well over two hours to loot the important locations and explore...

Okay, so what did they do to like, account for this? Surely something right? Like... Maybe they remembered where you were in that chapter and you can continue at the point before you entered the next main mission? Maybe you could choose to restart the entire chapter or continue where you left off?

Nope. Nothing. 

You see, the game doesn't have a manual save system. Okay... So what does it have? It has a quick save system. You can save up to 4 quick saves before they start overriding each other. Take my word for it, this was not enough. He had well savelocked himself out of returning to Volga.

The auto saves take up quicksave slots, and the game auto saves frequently. So it probably would've savelocked him out even if he tried to save very sparingly.

My dad did nothing wrong. He quick saved regularly, and in most games that is ideal. That isn't a detriment, that's a good thing! In no way should he have been punished for this behavior.

How do you mess up a game this bad? Like seriously, savelocking your players is one of the top concerns you should have had when making this game. Did no one think of this? Did no one care? You made larger, longer chapters than the last game... And didn't adjust the checkpoint or save system to accommodate it. And worst, this is a common complaint, and you've never fixed it!

"Oh you can play through it all again!" Woohoo, my father can spend his already limited time replaying a game just to get that extra loot, those upgrades, and experience the game he should've been able to experience at his own pace and his own discretion

That should only factor in if you like a game and WANT to replay it. In no way does this excuse their lack of a save system, poor communication, and in general incomprehensibly incompetent progression design. 

He will replay a game he wants. (He's replayed TLOU on NG+, and I had to use a glitch to increase the difficulty for him because he wanted to try it harder difficulty, yet for some reason, you can't change it legitimately because players wanting to try a harder difficulty with NG+ is bad I guess? (Maybe they wanted to gatekeep those achievements.) Yeah, that was a stupid design choice, but at least it came at the end of the game and didn't ruin the entire experience.)

But that should be HIS decision. Not a requirement to enjoy a game that is inherently flawed by its very own design because he didn't know the ins and outs of a game he has never played, and he can do nothing to remedy his common, understandable, and minor mistake.

Update: Bugs plus long cut scenes make it very unpleasant to play.  Do not buy it unless you are ready to suffer.  Otherwise, the review below applies.  Too bad.  

I'm enjoying the game and highly recommend it.  I did not like a couple of things that I mention below.  I like the game but only mention the negative?  Sure, but just to give you a heads up so that it does not detract from enjoying the game.  (Just because I mention the negative does not mean I'm not negative.  I'm in California - double negatives and crazy are easy to come by.)

The quick save is wonky in that it's not reliable.  I like to experiment sometimes and finding all saves to be experimental is no fun.  My quick save rarely is the the "quick save" I want.  I have to guess and load several of the saves to find the one I want.  Noting the time of your quick save will help.  I finally created my own save-archive using PowerShell just in case all my saves are badly timed.  You can manually copy the "C:\Users\*username*\Saved Games\metro exodus" folder someplace safe once in a while - timestamp the folder if you like.  (It has to be done as a set because metadata in the files has to be consistent.)  If you have a backup (e.g., free Veeam), that works too.  Be sure to turn of the steam cloud sync of the game if doing your own restore of the "metro exodus" folder.  Can't have two processes mucking with files without mucking up the files.   

A few cut scenes are a bit long.  I don't know a way to skip them - no "E" (using keyboard) on them.  They are okay, but twiddling thumbs is not as fun as playing the game.  The cut scenes are decent and not offensive like some of those franchise killing ones in Wolfenstein II The New Colossus.  (I hated the Colossus cut scenes enough to give up on the Wolfenstein franchise.  I'm not some puppet that has to listen to their drivel.  Screw them.  Ah, I guess I'm still pissed at them. I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

[h1][b]Metro Exodus - A Masterpiece of Atmospheric Storytelling and Survival[/b][/h1]

[h2][b]Rating: 100/100[/b][/h2]

[h3][b]Gameplay (95/100):[/b][/h3]
Metro Exodus maintains the series' core survival mechanics while introducing a more expansive and open-world environment. The game combines stealth, combat, and exploration seamlessly, offering a diverse range of gameplay experiences. The addition of a dynamic day-night cycle and weather conditions contributes to the realism and unpredictability of the game world.

The crafting system, resource management, and the need to maintain gas masks and other survival gear enhance the sense of immersion. The variety of weapons and modifications, coupled with the need to adapt to different scenarios, provides players with a satisfying level of strategic depth. However, occasional AI quirks and minor bugs may slightly impact the overall experience.

[h3][b]Graphics and Sound (100/100):[/b][/h3]
Metro Exodus is a visual marvel, showcasing the capabilities of modern gaming technology. The game's detailed and atmospheric environments, from the desolate surface to the claustrophobic metro tunnels, are a testament to the developers' commitment to visual excellence. The lighting effects, character models, and attention to detail create a world that is both beautiful and haunting.

The sound design is equally exceptional, with a haunting and evocative soundtrack that heightens the emotional impact of the narrative. The atmospheric audio, including the sounds of the desolate wasteland and the eerie whispers of mutated creatures, adds to the sense of dread and suspense. The voice acting is top-notch, conveying the desperation and humanity of the characters.

[h3][b]Story and Narrative (100/100):[/b][/h3]
Metro Exodus weaves a captivating and emotionally charged narrative that follows protagonist Artyom's journey across a post-apocalyptic Russia in search of a new home. The storytelling is mature, nuanced, and enriched by the deep lore of Dmitry Glukhovsky's Metro novels. The characters are well-developed, and their relationships evolve organically, fostering a genuine connection with the player.

The game's narrative is not afraid to explore complex themes of hope, despair, and the consequences of human actions in a world on the brink of collapse. The branching storylines and moral choices provide a level of player agency that influences the overall narrative, offering a sense of personal investment in the outcome.

[h3][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h3]
Metro Exodus is a triumph of narrative-driven gaming, combining breathtaking visuals, immersive sound design, and deep storytelling to create an unparalleled experience. Metro exodus accurately reflects the excellence in every aspect, from its atmospheric world design to its mature and emotionally resonant narrative. Metro Exodus stands as a testament to the artistic potential of video games, delivering an unforgettable journey through a desolate, yet captivating, post-apocalyptic landscape.

[h1] Review [/h1]

[h3]Metro Exodus Is Excellent [/h3]



[h2] Atmosphere [/h2]

the atmosphere is one of, if not the best part of the game. its the way it makes you completely immersed in its unfathomably well done levels, which paired with the audio and graphics amkes for an experience you cant really get anywhere else. it makes you completely lost in what is, for me personally, the most immerse video game world to date.

[h2] How It Makes You Immersed [/h2]

how is it the game makes you so immersed? its the way it makes you think about preparation and stability, in ways of making sure your equipment is ready, like charging your flashlight, changing you gas-mask filter, or pumping your guns. it makes you live in the world, it doesnt skip realism, it strives to make it a feature, and a good one at that. along with this, its the small things such as there being a seperate reload animation for stopping halfway through the animation, or water being splashed on your mask's glass, and then wiping it clean. its things such as those that make it just that much more impressive. 

[h2] Safe Houses [/h2]

i feel like safe houses in this game are so well done theyre worth mentioning on their own. its another example of how well these developers create feelings. after exploring around the levels and coming across a safezone, you can really see how someone couldve lived there. some of the safe zones arent really safe either, since its very possible that a mutant could come flying by, attempting to attack you, and it kinda makes it feel like you always have to be on the move cause youre never really safe, theres always a noise of a mutant just outside the door, or bandits thinking no ones there, and sitting themselves around a campfire just outside. and also, the places and ways they make the safe zones are impressive. it can be in a rusted crashed boat, or the top of a tree. i could go on, theyre well done, very much so. its worth stopping by them, just to adore them.


[h3]TLDR:[/h3]

Metro Exodus is one of the best games ive ever played, doing well in each of its parts, barely ever falling short on anything.
from its groundbreaking immersion level, to its impressively detailed landscapes, it does it all well for a studio not that well known. they really knew how to work with all this stuff, and kept it from being a very regular post-apocalyptic open world type-game. so if youre looking to decide whether to buy or not, also considereing its incredibly high price to value when its on sale, id say go for it.  like, 6 dollars for the game, 3 for dlc? incredible! its almost guranteed you'll get your moneys worth, one way or the other.

Let me start off by saying that this game is *genuinely* good. Graphics aside (which are amazing btw) It has one of the best stories I've ever seen, good gameplay and interesting mechanics

--However--

As someone who has played the whole series multiple times (on Ranger difficulty no less), there are a few gripes I have with this game comparing it to the previous one.

The movement feels very...floaty and unresponsive, it's similar in a way to GTA V. This makes stealth encounters a pain.

Speaking of stealth, it's..okay it's pretty bad. Unlike in the previous games, if an enemy spots you then  that's it, you gotta reload or shoot your way through, and if you're going for the good ending then chances are you'll reload either way, because in *two* major levels the game pretty much prohibits you from shooting people (Volga and Tundra).

The guns get dirty *wayyyy* too fast. You're telling me that 2 mags and my Kalash is already jamming? This is a very bad way to encourage stealth/collecting resources, because you're heavily gimped in forced combat encounters.

Finally - the enemies. They're way too tanky. Ranger mode is supposed to be 1 shot 1 kill. 1 shotgun hit, 2 rifle hits or 1-2 revolver hits and they're biting the dust....or in 2033 and Last Light that is. In this game for -whatever- reason, even if you get up close with a SHOTGUN, it might not be a one shot kill. a s h o t g u n. Rifles are pretty much useless unless  you're specifically going for headshots, but enemies can both dish it out and take it. Now, enemies that kill you in just a few shots wouldn't be an issue if not for the aformentioned bullet-sponge  problem, so what ends up happening is that your enemies are walking tanks while Artyom is a wet tissue.  And GOD don't get me started on the Humanimals. Cliffnotes - they're basically  the ghouls from Fallout 4...but without the interesting lore,  variety (Ferals, Glowing Ones, Sentient) or attack speed. They're just..kinda shambling zombies, It wouldn't be a problem if these fuckers didn't appear in every single location like a scripted Call of Duty gunfight, and couldn't throw bricks. Seriously if they're dumb enough to be shambling on all fours why are they able to chuck stuff at you? They're uninspired and annoying to deal with.

I don't hate this game, I just think it's very flawed. If both S.T.A.L.K.E.R. and Metro, both games made by pretty much the same people can figure out their difficulties, then I don't see why this game can't

misc. ranting for the fun of it  lol.

The lighter flame no longer shows you  where your objective is (bummer).

Replacing the gas-mask filter is way too quick, in 2033 it  felt like something you had to do while alone or in cover because it took a few seconds, here it's like 0.3 seconds.

Artyom's bones must have partially melted from the radiation because he somehow manages to get damaged by falling off a small platform

He also seems to have developed asthma as he cannot sprint for more than 5 seconds and at a much lower speed.

Having a separate slot for your Tikhar *and* being able to craft ammo for it in the field is just too busted. It was already useful in 2033 (Being one of two only truly silent weapons).

Weapon variety is lacking, Sure you can *basically* make weapons from attachments (long barrel and drum mag for RPK, Box Mag for Saiga, etc.), But I also would have loved to see some more coventional weapons, it's not too farfetched to think that you found some post-russian equipment on your journey.

I miss the pseudo-P90 top loading mag of the Kalash-2012. The Bulldog is just an ugly-looking generic bull-pup (I don't hate bull-pups, i just think this one is ugly with all of the welding shit all over)

Fun game
(Edit 01/02/2024)
Let me give a brief summary of the game cause I feel like I didn’t do it justice
METRO EXODUS
it’s like S.T.A.L.K.E.R but not

Story
you play Artyom who is a mute but also isn’t really mute, he talks in the loading cutscenes and has tons of special dialog for what you did as Artyom.
In the start of the game you are trying to look for other people since once on Artyom’s radio he heard a different faction talking to other people, Anna (Artyom’s wife) comes along one time to show Artyom there isn’t anyone left since everyone got nuked HARD (due to the war). When the weather gets bad in Moscow, you and Anna start running back home but see a train moving by and it shocks the both of you, a car comes up to you and tells you get in so they can catch up to the train, turns out they aren’t friendly and knock you out. Your stuck in their base and you break free only to break the radioprotecter, your commanding officer shows up out of no where to tell you he has been working with them to keep Moscow safe amongst everyone (basically playing dead) and now that YOU broke the radioprotecter Moscow is back into the war, 
You steal a train to find some higher power commanding officers to get info about the war and turn the radioprotecter back on.
(This is just two hours of the story out of 20ish hours)

Moral
In this game you are given a moral meter for whoever you kill, even if they are shooting you. The game likes to give options for stealth and highly encourages it but some stealth sections is more painful than shooting everyone in the head. This does affect many aspects of the game from dialog to characters, but not everyone causes moral to go down so you can still shoot some bad guys.

Combat
I feel like the combat is sorta lacking but thats because I sorta like close ranged combat and the game gives almost no options for that other than V(the knife/gun), but you are given MANY options for long ranged combat, from making you pistol into a shotgun or turning your AK to a sniper rifle.

Bugs
The game is sorta cheap for a reason and that because the game can be very buggy at times, I honestly enjoyed the bugs since it affected your movement rather than just insta-kills you and just makes you feel like your playing CS;GO serf map, the bugs that do affect your gameplay majorly are quite rare from my play-through and were quite annoying but it was easy to fix.

Maps
You are given three maps that are open world, the swamp, the desert and the forest. All of these maps are fairly fun to be around except for the desert which gets old fast, the last map is more linear and gives you a straight forward path but still fun.

Stealth
At some points it’s a waiting game and others matters how much patience you have, I don’t really like the stealth in this game (and in the forest level near the end it sucks) but I guess if you want go for it.

Rating
8.3, the game is pretty fun but can be annoying at some times

Let me start by saying I love the Metro series. 2033 and Last Light were amazing, and both ran flawlessly too. So I was really excited to play Exodus when it finally came to Steam. I was thoroughly enjoying it until all the crashing began. It started crashing in the Volga level, but would only happen rarely. However, in the following levels, the game began crashing to desktop more and more frequently, and at random times. I tried some of the solutions I found on the internet such as updating video drivers, updating Windows, lowering gfx settings, closing any monitoring software, disabling any overclocking, disabling hairworks, etc. The only solution I refused to try is switching from DX12 to 11. The game looks beautiful on DX12, so why should I reduce the graphic fidelity just because the developers couldn't get it together for the PC port? It's a real shame too, because I was really enjoying this game; it looks beautiful, and the story and immersion are great. But constantly worrying if your progress will get erased tends to completely ruin any immersion this game had going.  I can't get involved when I know a crash is right around the corner. I know it's not my system because no other games do this. Everything else runs perfectly. I am really disappointed in this game as it stands, and I am sad that I probably won't continue playing it, despite really enjoying it so far. It is just unplayable at this point. Dealing with crashing every 20-30 minutes just isn't fun; especially when sometimes it completely hard locks my computer and I need to reboot. 

So as it stands, I can't leave a positive recommendation in its current state. If 4A gets their act together and fixes this flawed port, I will change my review. I don't mean to sound like a whiny entitled gamer brat, but when you pay money for a game, it should at least be playable. 

EDIT: Ok Now I've hit a progress halting bug in the Caspian level. At the lighthouse after you kill all the guards a character is supposed to send a lift down...welp, not in my save, I guess. She just stands up there in the lighthouse doing nothing. Reloading saves does nothing. Apparently this is a well known bug that is a year old with no solution other than replaying the entire level and hoping it works. Well I can say I will not be doing that. If the devs can't be arsed to fix a glitch that's been reported for over a year now, then I can't be arsed to finish the game. That's the nail in the coffin for me.

Man, I love this game, but the bugs and crashes makes me hate it. There are two bugs that I have encountered. The first one is New Game Plus (NG+) bug with My Weapon mutation. When Yermak gives you a gun, you won't have any guns at all. What should happen is that you get all three guns from your previous playthrough. The solution is to turn off Steam Cloud or play on Offline Mode. The second bug is on the Caspian and connected to Giul's Lighthouse. If you go loud and the bandits, Giul will bug out and look into the distance. She is supposed to lower the boat so you can get up. It happened on my Ranger Hardcore and my save has already overwritten to the lighthouse and I had to restart chapter. In ranger Hardcore, you can't manually save. It sucked so much. I have completed Iron Mode and it is worse than Ranger Hardcore by having no saves at all (no manual and auto, only saves between levels), it sucks so much. Sometimes the game crashes in random time, maybe due to my hardware no reallly strong. Still.. I don't know why anyone thought this is fun.
Aside from all of those, it is a great game. Great story, great characters, and great settings. I got attached to them through the story, and felt really bad when going through the negative moral playthrough and seeing the consequences. I don't really like open world stuff in general because I don't know where to start, but it is not bad in this game. Not really empty and not stuffed either, and there is guidance in where to go (I don't know how I will feel with Elden Ring).
Edit: I have played the DLCs. The Two Colonels is great. I would say more because it would be spoilers. Sam's Story is good with more open world stuff. I love Sam & Captain's interaction in the Captain's hideout, very funny.

This game was really only worth it at a sale price. There are a lot of things that were fun about this game, but a lot that was pretty a s s. 

First off, I love the game play. I love how it's open world to a point but still has a mission-based campaign. I personally found this very enjoyable. The world in this game is also really cool, it was crafted very well and a lot of backstory is put into it. I haven't fully played the first two metro games but I know of them (probably should have played them in order to better understand the characters). With that in mind, even not knowing the full backstory, I was able to piece together Artyom's relationship with the others, and found that they were quite good. The monsters and npc's are all pretty cool. Except when you look at them in the notes section in-game. They have some weird a s s names ngl. = 

Now onto the bad. The game constantly would freeze-crash, and I was unable to alt+f4 and/or task manager, end task. This would result in me having to restart my pc. Although this was fixed by lowering the graphics, turning on v-sync and tinkering, it was still hella annoying restarting my pc up to 4 times in a span of 10 minutes. 

Now what I personally disliked about this game is the dialogue. It was just so weird, sometimes the dialogue felt like it was straight out of "The Room". Overlapping and just being the most generic a s s dialogue I've heard. It was also hard considering Sam's voice (Steve Blum) was just his regular voice. The whole time I was questioning whether or not he was supposed to be American or if it was a half-a s s job at a Russian accent, which couldn't be possible as I know Steve Blum is an amazing voice actor. Also considering that the dialogue was mostly optional just felt out of place. I lost a lot of the story since I just went off to do more important things. Other than that there were a few minor annoyances but that's just me. 

Overall the game was a fun play, but I probably won't be playing it again for a very long time.
