This is one of the games I bought my gaming PC just to play back in 2015. I'm sad to say that It's AVERAGE, at best. The 'open worlds' are just empty and boring to explore, nothing more than glorified shooting galleries. You can't interact with any of the new factions by doing anything other than shooting/sneaking past them. The new factions ideas might seem cool to those that never played any post-apocalyptic game, but they're pretty much copies of Fallout's concepts. There are no quests in the open world, just 'missions' in some places, and most of those amount to nothing more than 'clear that bandit camp' or 'Anna is missing, go there and find her'. To be honest, the best parts of the game are the Chapters of Moscow and the Volga, the maps and missions are actually fun there. This is the perfect example of a franchise that had It's own identity but opted to go the mainstream path of blandness, just like Fallout or the Mass Effect series...

The Metro franchise is characterized by creating games with emotional stories, surprising settings and Metro Exodus is no exception.
In this particular one, it evolved significantly, starting from the graphics (which are amazing), to the gameplay, implementing the option to improve weapons, suits and masks at will, giving an innovative experience in regards to the saga.
The main story has ten missions and two endings of the player's choice. I recommend playing the dlcs, especially "The Two Colonels" since it is really worth it.
Although Metro Exodus takes place on the surface, I would have liked the game to be more intuitive, that is, among other things, having the ability to climb anywhere to be able to fully explore within reason and not be limited by this. For lovers of post-apocalyptic games you will find an interesting as well as entertaining game.

I took my time with this game. Exploring, interacting, doing side missions, all worth it in the end because of the engineered dialogues and scripted behaviors of the people(NPCs) around you. Whether they forgive you or want to attack you and give up, or because you did something that benefitted them like not kill people from a group they identify with, among other things. The way you interact with the world carries weight in determination of events unfolding as Artyom proceeds in his journey and you play in this world.

I fell in love with all the characters in the story but if you speedrun through this game and not pay attention to the dialogue heavy scenes then you may not feel the same way since it'll be tough to be influenced into having feelings for the characters, to make a connection, if you zone out on what they say or don't choose to listen. So take your time and stay and listen. There's so much dialogue and information shared between the characters in this universe. If you hear anyone speak just stay around them so you hear what they have to say, it was always very interesting how the NPCs interact with one another. I've never played a 3d fps game as rich in scripted conversation between NPCs as what I experienced in this game and part of that is because of the bond I formed with every single crew member in the exodus toward clear skies, and also characters in their respective locations. A huge chance of the player being emotionally invested in the characters is if the characters are written with care and thought and I think 4A Games did an incredible job at this!

4A Games retained the Metro feel and made it open world and it's marvelous. If you explore enough of the several open world locations you have a good chance of upping your readiness in the form of gear all to your advantage against the wildlife and dangers of enemy monsters in the form of human beings. The wild life is dangerous, icky or innocent, or all three combined because this is not only your world it's every survivor's world and also every new genetically altered lifeform's birth world too.

The world detail of Metro Exodus and atmosphere it creates is next level. If the graphics look this good on the non-Enhanced Edition I can't wait to see what the fourth Metro game will look like.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

A fantastic conclusion to the Metro trilogy. Without spoiling, Metro Exodus expands the world of the Metro unlike any of the other two titles in the series. The unique crafting system and the wide range of weapons that you can make, and the means that you can use to engage the enemy (both human and non-human) are arguably the best in the entire trilogy. Most of the same enemies in the franchise do return, and Exodus gives you an extremely well-balanced way to handle them as long as you build your loadouts correctly for the situation.

If you want more Metro, Exodus is definitely it. This is the single biggest Metro experience you will ever have if you've been craving more of it. Exploring entire maps and doing all the side missions and the campaign story objectives took me several days, and it was engaging and fun every step of the way. The only real gripe I had with the game is that the crafting system could be a little bit better explained, as it can be a little confusing for new players to figure out.

Metro Exodus plays a lot differently than Last Light or 2033, and the environments are GIGANTIC, so be prepared to run around a lot and go a lot of different places. There's stuff everywhere, and the game feels a lot more like Fallout in its open-worldness and it does so brilliantly.

Even without prior Metro series experience, this game is amazing! It's more on the "stealth" side of things than a guns-a-blazing fps. It's also a very good combo of open-world exploration mixed with linear story, kinda like the fallout series or other fps-rpg games, just without as many side quests. Overall it is a great game, and especially if it is on sale (I got my copy for around $6) it is absolutely worth it!!

[h1] Metro Exodus - A Journey Beyond the Shadows [/h1]

Graphics: ★★★★★ 
Metro Exodus showcases a significant leap in graphical fidelity compared to its predecessors. The game's environments are breathtaking, ranging from the hauntingly beautiful post-apocalyptic landscapes to the detailed interiors of makeshift settlements. Dynamic weather, day-night cycles, and realistic lighting contribute to an immersive visual experience that elevates the Metro series to new heights.

Gameplay: ★★★★☆ 
Metro Exodus maintains the series' signature blend of first-person shooting, survival horror, and atmospheric exploration. The addition of semi-open world environments introduces a new level of freedom, allowing players to tackle objectives in a more non-linear fashion. The variety of weapons and the emphasis on resource management contribute to a tense and strategic gameplay experience.  

Story: ★★★★★ 
The narrative in Metro Exodus continues the compelling story of Artyom and his companions as they journey across the post-apocalyptic Russian landscape. The well-developed characters, moral choices, and the exploration of the Metro's rich lore create a narrative that is both engaging and emotionally resonant. The evolving relationships among the characters add depth to the storytelling.  

Soundtrack: ★★★★★ 
The atmospheric and evocative soundtrack of Metro Exodus complements the desolate beauty of its world. The music, combined with ambient sounds and the haunting cries of mutated creatures, enhances the immersive experience. The attention to detail in the audio design contributes to the overall sense of isolation and tension.  

Level Design: ★★★★☆ The semi-open world design introduces a refreshing change to the Metro series. Each environment feels distinct, featuring a mix of urban ruins, frozen landscapes, and desolate wilderness. The level design encourages exploration, and the dynamic nature of the world, including day-night cycles and weather changes, adds depth to the gameplay.  

Replayability: ★★★☆☆ 
While Metro Exodus offers multiple endings based on player choices, the linear narrative and scripted events may limit replayability for some. However, the variety in approaches to missions and the moral decisions throughout the game may motivate players to experience different outcomes.  

Overall: ★★★★☆
Metro Exodus successfully evolves the Metro series, delivering a visually stunning and emotionally charged experience. With its engaging narrative, atmospheric world design, and strategic gameplay mechanics, it stands as a worthy addition to the post-apocalyptic saga. While some series purists may miss the confined spaces of the metro tunnels, the expansion into a more open world proves to be a welcome and refreshing change for the franchise.

Ok, first of all. I love metro series and after gotten immersed from first two bangers (2033 and Last Light), we got this horrendously designed sequel you call Exodus.

Alright, before you get mad, let me explain. The graphic, mechanics and gameplay are hugely improved in this one. But two greatest turn off for me are; NARRATIVE and LEVEL DESIGN.

- NARRATIVE - : Boy, where do i start, the narrative is such a convoluted clusterf**k, the dialogues are presented like a goddamn thesis. Too many infodumping unlike the first two where we learn the world through observations and actions of its characters. In Exodus, however, the plot is soo divided with barely any smooth connections in between. Te first train mission was great, but things started to spiral down as we go from Moscow. All of characters that are not even significant to Artyom are introduced. I'm ok with Katya, her kid and first engineer dude, but after Volga, IDGAF to almost everyone, like this one schizo admiral guy in Taiga. Giul was ok i thought she's cool but she's still useless to bigger narrative. And man, how much I hate Anna as the story goes. The only narrative design that I think is decent is short transit in Yamantau where we dont need much words to explain the horror that happened in that base.

- LEVEL DESIGN -: I'm thinking on uninstalling this after SECOND bear fight. It's just soo uncreative, so boring and souless. 90% of the game are about hiding, sneaking and infiltrating. You're not given freedom of playstyles unless you want the bad endings. The open world mechanic is such a drawback and poorly executed, which essentially removed the desolate atmosphere and claustrophobic survival vibe that I love so much about Metro. I thoroughly disappointed by Exodus playstyle direction after the previously two masterpieces.

Now, if you're not fan of metro, you prolly like it, 7/10-8/10 most probably if you cant ignore clunky a** movement. But if you're planning to play it because you like the first two story and atmosphere, you should carefully consider my words.

This is game is gawd damn gorgeous at times. I've taken a ton of screenshots, and props must be given to the team for presentation. Exploring these worlds at your own pace is really satisfying. The mixture of linear and sandbox worked well. It was a nice change after the last two games in the cramped Metro. 

Scanning the area with your Binos and then heading out to explore kept me interested the most. The environmental story telling is where it shines combined with a few good set pieces. The day night cycle + weather affects were flipping awesome too. At one point a huge electrical storm rolled over as I was climbing a crane in the Volga level which was atmospheric as hell. 

Still as a whole I'm not sure where I stand on this one in the series, because it felt so different. It got raving reviews which in some cases it deserved but not all. 

The controls are quite ''floaty'' and need some work. Artyom flies down stares and over bumps like he's attached to a pair of roller skates. (Which was annoying)

The story takes place over the course of a year but it feels kind of disjointed. The voice acting can be average at times and personally I think it's story was a bit overrated. If I remember correctly the original Metro 2033 took place over 7 - 8 days it total and the cohesion as such was better with a very clear goal throughout. 

Most encounters play out the same way, shoot people or don't shoot people. So they haven't really pushed the envelope there. Mutants feel samey and less threatening that previous titles. The human chameleon chaps you fight are ridiculous. With all these new areas I was hoping for new monsters and better iterations. 

The animation also seemed to be a bit more janky. (Looking at you flying gargoyle things). Once I've upgraded my rig in a few years time I'll come back to it.

I've played all Metro games, and I can say without any doubt: Metro Exodus is the sole masterpiece of the franchise.

- Starting by the visuals, it is absolutely stunning, with lots of diverse environments (something I've missed in the original series, but that's not a con, considering it made sense with the previous plots).
- It has the BEST character development of all the games. All the characters from Metro Exodus feels like family, you grow attached to them. Their stories, personalities, backgrounds, everything was better constructed in Metro Exodus.
- I've played the original game and both the DLCs, and all the endings are beautiful, it's almost ridiculous. I'm a grown man and for the first time in ages I've shed a tear in the end of "The Two Colonels" DLC.
- Lots of side dialogues between NPCs. Really. Lots. If you try to listen it all, the game will get tiresome, too much information. Listen to some, pass anothers, play it in your own time, and in a future playthrough, listen to the others (there's a lot that you will surely miss in the first playthrough)

There's two cons, however, that bothered me during the game:

- Sometimes the game just crashes between levels. It's not a serious problem considering it autosaves frequently, but it can become annoying to reopen the game every time after you finish a level. And for some reason, if you have NVidia instant record enabled, it will ALWAYS crash between levels, so you gotta play with it disabled, or only enable it after the level already started.
- Some FPS drops in places that makes no sense to have it. In the big cities I've managed to get used to these drops, it made sense considering the amount of details in-screen, but there was also some stutterings in closed places with not really much happening. A little bit unoptimized in that aspect, but it's nothing so serious that it will make your game unplayable, as long as you have a decent setup (medium tier+)

Game is stunningly appealing. Story is nice especially if you are caught up with the other games. Basically a looting story game with craftable items. Many guns and types, including throwables. Lots to explore and doesn't have you follow a strict story only path as you can explore on your own as much as you wish.

(If this is your first Metro game i'd highly recommend to play the previous ones before going into Exodus, but if you don't want to play the prequels i'd encourage to at least play Last Light to have an idea of the characters in your crew and have an idea of the previous events)

While Metro Exodus improves on the world and making it an open world exploration sandbox, i believe that the developers steered too far away from what they have titled their games.  You spend very little time for the majority of the game outside of the metro and more time outside which is what gave the old games such a good atmosphere.

The inventory system has been further improved from it's predecessors and weapons still feel good and true to the older games which i like. Soundtracks are also stellar just like all other metro games, with Metro Last Light having the best soundtracks by far out of the franchise.

The moral system in this game is FAR better than the older games, most notably Last Light. 
Last Light made the player play in a very specific way where one bad decision could well mean that you'd ruin your good ending, however in Metro Exodus the game is MUCH more forgiving which allows the player to make their own decisions (good or bad) while still having a good opportunity to get the good ending.

Minimum specs for the game are quite accurate but i'd recommend a 1650 for a more stable experience.

My Epic Odyssey: A Personal Journey Through Gaming Excellence

When I embarked on my gaming journey with "Epic Odyssey," I had high expectations. After all, this title had garnered praise from players and critics alike across the internet. As I delved into this epic adventure, it didn't take long for me to realize that these expectations were not only met but exceeded in ways that I couldn't have imagined.

From the moment I stepped into the sprawling world of "Epic Odyssey," I was immediately struck by its breathtaking beauty. The landscapes were awe-inspiring, each meticulously designed to transport players to a realm of fantasy and wonder. Whether I was exploring dense, mystical forests or scaling towering mountain peaks, every corner of the game world felt like a work of art.

Character creation is where my personal journey truly began. The ability to customize my protagonist's appearance, abilities, and background allowed me to craft a character that felt uniquely mine. This level of personalization created an emotional connection between me and my character, making me deeply invested in their growth and choices throughout the game.

The combat system in "Epic Odyssey" is an absolute joy to experience. It seamlessly blends real-time action with strategic elements, offering a dynamic and engaging gameplay experience. I appreciated the flexibility it provided, allowing me to choose between adrenaline-fueled battles or a more calculated approach. This adaptability ensured that the game appealed to a wide range of gamers, regardless of their preferred playstyle.

However, it's the game's narrative that truly stole my heart. "Epic Odyssey" weaves a complex, non-linear storyline that allows players to shape their own destinies through a series of choices and consequences. The branching narrative ensures that no two playthroughs are the same, compelling me to replay the game multiple times to explore different outcomes and moral dilemmas.

The characters I encountered throughout my journey were equally captivating. Each NPC felt meticulously crafted, their stories and personalities adding depth and authenticity to the game world. Whether they were enigmatic allies or formidable adversaries, I found myself eagerly anticipating each interaction to uncover their secrets and motivations.

Visually, "Epic Odyssey" is nothing short of a masterpiece. The attention to detail in every aspect of the game is astonishing, and it's evident that the developers poured their hearts and souls into creating a visually stunning experience. From the shimmering waters of crystal-clear lakes to the intricate architecture of ancient ruins, every pixel felt like a labor of love.

The game's soundtrack deserves its own accolades. The music effortlessly sets the tone for each scene, enhancing the emotional immersion. Whether it's the stirring orchestral melodies during epic battles or the hauntingly beautiful tunes that accompany moments of reflection, the music heightened my overall experience.

I was particularly impressed by "Epic Odyssey's" commitment to inclusivity and representation. The game features a diverse range of characters, backgrounds, and relationships, reflecting the richness of the real world. This progressive stance resonated with me, and I believe it sets a positive example for the gaming industry as a whole.

As I became more engrossed in the game, I couldn't help but seek out the online community surrounding "Epic Odyssey." It was heartwarming to see players from diverse backgrounds come together to share their experiences, theories, and fan art. The sense of camaraderie and shared enthusiasm within the player base only added to my appreciation for the game.

Of course, no game is without its flaws, and "Epic Odyssey" is no exception. Some players have noted that the game's initial learning curve can be steep. However, I firmly believe that this challenge is part of what makes the game so rewarding. It encourages players to invest time and effort into mastering its mechanics, ultimately making the experience more satisfying.

Occasional bugs or glitches have been a source of frustration for some players. While these technical issues are not uncommon in the gaming world, it's worth mentioning that the developers of "Epic Odyssey" have been diligent in addressing these problems through regular updates and patches, which speaks to their commitment to the player community.

In conclusion, my personal journey with "Epic Odyssey" has been nothing short of extraordinary. This game has exceeded my expectations in every way, from its breathtaking visuals and deep narrative to its inclusive approach and engaging combat system. While it may have a few minor imperfections, they pale in comparison to the grandeur of the adventure that awaits players. "Epic Odyssey" is not just a game; it's a personal and unforgettable journey through the realms of gaming excellence.

Metro Exodus: A Mind - Boggling Ride Through the Apocalypse

Just finished Metro Exodus, and I gotta spill the beans. This game is one wild trip through the post-apocalyptic wilderness.

Graphics? Holy smokes, they're jaw-dropping. The attention to detail in the wasteland and creepy tunnels? Top-notch. You'll find yourself stopping just to soak it all in.

Storyline? Buckle up! It's a rollercoaster of emotions. You'll laugh, you'll cry, and you'll definitely freak out when things go bump in the dark. The narrative grabs you and doesn't let go.

Gameplay? Stealth or guns blazing, the choice is yours. The freedom to explore adds a layer of excitement. You'll scavenge for resources and feel the adrenaline as mutants lurk around every corner.

And the characters? They feel like real people, not just pixels on a screen. You'll get attached, so be prepared to ride the emotional rollercoaster.

Minor bugs? Yeah, every game has them, but they're like that one weird friend—weird but lovable.

In a nutshell, Metro Exodus is a post-apocalyptic masterpiece. If you dig immersive stories, stunning visuals, and intense gameplay, give it a go. It's a wild ride from start to finish

Metro Exodus is a top contender for the best semi-open world single player shooter currently on the steam store. Top quality graphics, an interesting story that changes for good or bad depending on your actions, snappy gun play, simple but rewarding looting and crafting and a truly unique and varied but brutal world combine to deliver a rare gem.

I found Metro 2033 to be a fun game but couldn't get into it and never finished it, Exodus improves upon the first two games in every way. Whether you're tip toeing around religious fanatics that worship a giant mutated catfish on the Volga River or brutally murdering Mad Max inspired slavers on the dried up shores of the Caspian Sea Exodus always manages to keep you enthralled.

Both DLC's are also a great addition with their own standalone stories. Clearing out filth infested metro tunnels genuinely makes your skin crawl while fighting through a port in Ukraine to reach a submarine manages to make you truly feel like a post apocalyptic warrior.

Metro Exodus is a fantastic story driven shooter. There is plenty of loot to find and doing so is enjoyable. There are many opportunities to complete side quests and explore areas off the mission's path. Exodus does a great job of developing characters and you will truly care about what happens to each of them. I will say that this is the buggiest game I have played in quite some time. Interact with a door and walk forward too soon? Stuck in the wall. Drive too fast and bump a guard rail? Stuck on the rail. Jump on a boulder without the interaction to climb up it? Glitch against the wall. All of these bugs result in you reloading your last save. If you were diligent, maybe your're reset 30 seconds. If not and you're unlucky with the last autosave, it could be 5 or 10 minutes back. The customization in your equipment feels great. Being able to craft out of your backpack is fantastic. Enemies are diverse, threatening, and horrifying. Some of these encounters will truly have you squirming or leaning forward as your sprint to safety. I loved the twists in the story and the freedom to choose how to deal with the heads of each faction. Stealth is another area that I have a problem with. If one enemy spots you for a split second, the entire camp will know you're exact location and be aware of you. Even if you kill the enemy immediately, before they can yell and expose you, the entire camp is aware. This is really frustrating because often times enemies are bunched up in the stealth areas. My final gripe is about the juggernauts. They're few and far between, but the fights can become extremely drawn out if you do not dispatch them with Molotovs and shots to their exposed wrists. The first one you encounter is without explanation so I wasted a lot of time and ammo discovering his weakness. Unique, but an unrealistic bullet sponge that seems out of place compared to the rest of the enemies. Overall, the game is awesome and well worth the price tag. If you get it on sell, even better!

The conclusion to the Metro trilogy, Metro Exodus, was a huge leap over the previous games not just in gameplay but in story and other facets of the game as well. I could tell that this was the vision for the series ever since the first game dropped 10 years ago. It far exceeded expectations and delivered one of the best narratives in gaming history. 

Story: The story picked up just a year after the 2nd game's good ending. Where Artyom, our protagonist, having conquered the Dark Ones and the Metro politics in the previous games, is in search of other survivors of the war. What went down just within just the prologue of the game was probably one of the best plot twists in recent history. It expanded not just the lore and current story but also the way how the game played. After its amazing prologue, the story, over the course of many chapters, then perfectly encapsulated desperation and hopelessness in its narrative which I didn't expect due to how it differs in setting from the previous games. Although the ending was quite predictable, it fit the overall themes of the story. It also included two amazing DLCs which focused on two different aspects of the game. Two Colonels which focused on the narrative brings the gameplay back to its roots and delivered probably one of the best DLCs I've ever played and Sam's Story which focused more on the gameplay to be your typical shooter. 

Gameplay: Bringing the gameplay to a semi-open world was probably one of the best ideas of the developers. It helped in delivering the narrative and other gameplay adjustments. The day and night adjustments did not just provide visual changes but also gameplay changes wherein you are stealthier at night but there are more monsters. Shelters provided a way to clean equipment, change the time, and replenish health. Although the available weapons decreased, customization saw a huge overhaul with lots of new moving pieces,the disassembly, and cleaning system. Every part has also its downside so you can't make just one super-weapon until the endgame. Dissembling pieces means you have to sacrifice one item for another. You also cannot spam your weapons too much or go to dirty areas as it will affect efficiency. These were welcomed changes because it made players not be too overpowered over the course of the game especially on higher difficulties. Being in an open-world also meant side-quests which added an extra layer to the game. 

Sound & Visuals: The sound design is classic eerie metro but this time its more emphasized from the clank of moving parts to wiping a smudge of blood off your mask and Artyom's heavy breathing. They also fixed the inconsistent volume from the previous games wherein some chapters felt a bit too loud on the ears. Most importantly, the voice acting is now actually proper compared to the previous games where some characters voices did not have any semblance of passion and emotion at all. It also has amazingly good graphics for its current price. It might not have been the best in 2019 and is obviously not the best in 2023, but the PC Enhanced Edition did give it a slight visual update. For low-mid end PCs, it is still very much playable even with ultra high graphics. And guess what? no more hyper glaring lights from enemies. 

Enjoyment: I have no more words on how much I love and enjoyed this game. It far exceeded my expectations and made the previous two games look like works from amateurs. Definitely in my top 10 games of all time.

I bought the game yesterday on Steams fall sale and paid $10 CAD. I have very mixed feelings about this game. I played the first game, but not the second one. I like the premise and the look and am really wanting to love it, but man is it aggravating at times. Whether or not you will like it will really depend on what you expect and are looking for. The many positive reviews are likely genuine and show that some players will absolutely love it. I am fairly early in, in the Volga chapter which is your first zone once you leave Moscow. 

Firstly, it's not really billed as primarily a stealth game, but it easily could be. Ammo is severely limited, and even early on it's very easy to be quickly overrun but canine type mutants that will tear you apart easily, or deplete all your ammo to defeat them. It's less of a concern fighting humans as you will loot their ammo, but the hostile wildlife, not so much. I'm on  the second mission of the Volga chapter, "Get to the Port". The objective is about half a kilometre from your start location and on my first try I ran into a pack of watchers which used up all my ammo to defeat. I reloaded and tried again and basically had to stealth creep half a km to avoid the rabid mutant canines (watchers). I just finished Cyberpunk 2077 and loved the stealth elements, but I found creeping half a kilometre to be tedious, your mileage may vary.

It can be very unforgiving which brings me to the second point. The save game system is quite limited. While the game is far from "roguelike", I would say it has semi-roguelike elements. You are limited to 4 save slots, and auto saves overwrite older saves. What that means is that when I realized I should have explored more on the first Volga mission and wanted to go back to the first mission, I found my early saves were gone. A quick google search revealed that my only option was to restart the chapter. Not too bad given that I was only on the second mission, but would have been really maddening if I was much further in the chapter. This leads to the next point. 

The game is missing many quality of life features that pretty standard in most games of this genre. I was surprised to discover there is no persistent mini-map on the UI. There is a map folder you carry and can open any time to view the entire map, so its not like the game is denying you the utility a mini-map would provide. However the game forces you to press a key to access it, and blocks your view when its open. It looks very nice and realistic, but the novelty of it wore off for me pretty quickly. Bizarrely, it and other functions require a long press of the key. Want to look at the map, long press M, want to open a door or loot something, long press E, want to open your pack, long press I. No idea what the obsession is with long pressing all these hot keys, but is serves no purpose I can see aside from wasting time. 

Another QOL design choice I find weird is that there is no way to skip through NPC dialogues. Given the limited saves option and the need restart an entire chapter to replay a previous mission as mentioned above, it's annoying that I have to sit through lengthy NPC dialogues I have already heard to play a mission over again (and man do these NPCs like to ramble on at great length). They have even made it so that if you alt-tab out of the game it pauses and goes to the main menu screen. You are forced to listen again to what you already heard. I literally restarted the chapter and went an took a dump, which seemed somehow appropriate.

Sometimes omitted QOL features can be fixed with useful mods, but the mod selection for this game is near non-existent. Nexusmods has less that three full pages of mods for this game and nearly all of them are graphical enhancement, re-shader type mods, one is a difficulty changer if you started on the hardest, and two to make Anna prettier and show her boobs (modders are so predictable in that regard). I would definitely have appreciated a mod for a basic persistent mini-map, more save slots and perhaps a greater ammo carry limit. At present I am limited to 90 rounds, so while I could have looted more from the previous mission against humans, I wasn't able to carry more than 90 rounds, easy to blow through fighting 5 watchers. 

The way weapons are portrayed is quick nice. They have a very cool mix of pre-nuclear war AK style rifles and the kind of hand build Fallout style custom stuff you'd expect. They are graphically very pretty, and from what I can see so far are incredible customizable, ie silencer and shoulder stock on the first 3 round revolver, reflex red dot on the AK. I expect I will be able to upgrade the AK's inexplicable 20 round magazine at some point. What I do not like is that they limited you to having only two standard weapons, and one "special" weapon. I am very much missing my holy trinity of pistol, shotgun and rifle that I have used in every shooter I have ever played since the 90's, and is literally used in professional and amateur shooting sports known as Three Gun ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l-2maNktXKk ). The special weapon I have obtained so far is a souped up BB gun that has some potential and it's main feature is that it uses very cheaply crafted ammo. However at this point it is fairly weak, and requires you to reload both the pellets and the air pressure. It is also not a stealth weapon as it came stock, as it pulled a group of watcher I was trying to thin out are range. It will likely have a silencer upgrade later.

That's enough wall of text for now. I am still glad for the game at $10 and will keep playing it to see where it goes. Depending on what you like and what you're expecting you may love or hate this game.

EDIT

I came back to edit this review and changed it to 'would not recommend'. I am still in Volga but further along since the original review. I am on the mission to get the rail car and it is probably the most frustrating mission I have ever played in 30 years of PC gaming. For the first time in my life I will likely watch a YouTube walk through and pause it every 30 seconds to alt tab into the game and find the objective. I'm an industrial electrician by trade and have worked in many types of factories, rail repair depots and mills. No one would ever lay one out in the ridiculous way that maze is. I know some players will enjoy the experience, but I definitely do not. If you read forums and Reddit threads you'll find a lot more critical feedback than the Steam reviews.

[h1]"Metro Exodus: A Story That Stole My Heart, Even as a Non-Story Gamer"[/h1]

Rating: 10/10

I've never been a fan of story-driven games, but the Metro series, and especially Metro Exodus, touched my heart in ways I never expected. It's not just another game; it's an emotional journey through the Moscow Metro and into the harsh Russian wilderness in search of a new home. that hooked me from the start.

Metro Exodus offers a gripping narrative without feeling overwhelming. It strikes the perfect balance between storytelling and gameplay, making it accessible and engaging even for those like me who typically prefer action over plot.

The characters are well developed, and their relationships evolve throughout the journey. The choices you make carry weight, making you genuinely care about the fate of Artyom and his companions.

Lastly, the graphics and audio are top-notch. The game's visuals are stunning, and the sound design immerses you in the eerie and dangerous world of Metro.

This game proves that even if you're not a fan of story-driven titles, Metro Exodus can convert you. It's a rare gem that transcends genres and offers an unforgettable gaming experience that touched my heart and will stay with me for a long time. 

Don't miss it.

If you've played and loved previous Metro games, I see no reason why you wouldn't love this one. Metro Exodus has a great story, atmosphere and graphics. It borrows some mechanics and ideas from previous Metro games and incorporates them nicely into several semi-open levels, along with some new mechanics like cleaning weapons, crafting items etc. 

It's not without flaws - I've encountered some bugs, including game freezing and floating objects. Floating objects are nothing serious (and rare), but freezing really went on my nerves. It started happening during the "Caspian Sea" chapter. Thankfully, the fix was easy - switched from DX12 to DX11 and the freezing issue went away. 

If you're interested in picking up this game and you haven't played previous Metro games, I'd advise you to play them before - it's not mandatory, but Metro universe is really awesome and it would be a shame to skip some (important) parts of it mentioned in previous games.

Final score: 9/10

P.S. DLC's are really good, so if you have the $$$ - pick the Gold edition

EDIT:

I've replayed the game this year, but this time it was the updated "enhanced" edition and I haven't encountered previously mentioned issues with crashing. Absolute recommendation.

A Journey Beyond the Darkness - "Metro Exodus" Review

Rating: 10/10

"Metro Exodus," developed by 4A Games and published by Deep Silver, marks the third installment in the critically acclaimed Metro series, based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's novels. Building on the atmospheric and narrative strengths of its predecessors, "Metro Exodus" takes players on an immersive, post-apocalyptic journey above and beyond the confines of the Moscow Metro tunnels.

Storyline : 10/10
The narrative of "Metro Exodus" is a standout feature, continuing the story of Artyom, the protagonist, as he leads a group of survivors beyond the Moscow Metro in search of a new life. The richly woven tale explores themes of survival, hope, and the consequences of humanity's actions in the aftermath of a nuclear apocalypse. The characters are compelling, and the narrative is delivered with emotional depth, making every step of the journey resonate with significance.

Gameplay : 10/10
"Exodus" introduces a semi-open world structure, a departure from the linear corridors of its predecessors. The change is refreshing, allowing for more exploration and environmental diversity without sacrificing the tense, survival-focused gameplay. The blend of stealth, intense gunfights, and resource management remains a highlight, offering a dynamic and engaging experience throughout the vast landscapes.

Graphics and Atmosphere : 10/10
Visually stunning, "Metro Exodus" sets a new standard for post-apocalyptic aesthetics. The environments, from the desolate Volga River to the haunting Caspian Sea, are meticulously crafted with attention to detail. Dynamic weather and day-night cycles contribute to an immersive atmosphere that evolves with the story, creating a world that feels alive despite its desolation.

Sound Design : 10/10
The game's sound design is exceptional, enhancing the immersive experience. From the haunting echoes of distant mutants to the subtle creaks of abandoned buildings, every sound contributes to the atmosphere. The musical score complements the emotional beats of the narrative, elevating the overall audio experience.

Survival Elements : 10/10
Survival in "Metro Exodus" goes beyond combat, incorporating a day-night cycle, changing weather conditions, and the need to maintain your equipment. Resource scarcity and the constant threat of radiation create a palpable sense of tension, emphasizing the harsh reality of surviving in a world devastated by nuclear war.

Conclusion : 10/10
"Metro Exodus" stands as a triumph in storytelling and atmospheric game design. Its expansive world, coupled with a compelling narrative and a perfect blend of survival and shooter elements, makes it a defining entry in the post-apocalyptic genre. The emotional journey of Artyom and his companions, set against the backdrop of a beautifully desolate world, creates an unforgettable gaming experience. "Metro Exodus" not only surpasses its predecessors but also sets a new benchmark for narrative-driven, atmospheric shooters. For those seeking a captivating and immersive journey through the ruins of humanity, "Metro Exodus" is an absolute must-play.

Worth £10 but no more.

I don't think its worth £45 or an AAA title, very over hyped, graphics are ok but it just seems like a Fallout 4 mod, some of the animations are off and there are lots of glitches.
Playing on maximum settings, some of the graphics in the desert seem a little bland and there are no footprints in the sand or snow when you walk, seems to kind of lack detail in places. 

The character graphics are good, and the forest is ok, I think its more the animations and graphical layout of some areas that seem a little last decade.

I like the gas mask  feature the way you have to utilise it, and keep your gear up together, and there are some nice touches like emergency mask repair with sticky tape, wiping the grime off the mask and changing filters, getting the map out constantly is a bit tedious, even with the wrist compass.

General game play is fine and combat is good, you can't blaze away finding and using cover is recommended. The different weapons are interesting the modding of the weapons and finding different parts is well thought out.

The melee sound is hilariously shit! The sound is the same awful crack no matter what you are hitting, it sounds like they ripped a nut cracker sound using a commodore 64. The rest of in game sounds are fine.

I've seen some bad animations also, monsters attacking other monsters and not actually touching them, but seemingly lifting them up on invisible wires.
Lots of floating objects.
Creatures disappearing through walls.
Shooting at ghouls and had them flat out vanish into thin air in front of me.
Characters all speaking over each others dialog and not looking at you while talking (are you talking to me or him?)
I had someone who's gun was constantly firing, even when on her back.
Enemies stuck in walls.
Enemies able to see you through walls.
For some reason reading the map in a van makes you smash your head through the roof so you have to get out then back in to get the driver view back to normal.
Controlling is also a bit old fashioned, having to jump over tiny ramps because he can't lift his leg over a small step.
I've had less glitches in 300 hrs of Fallout 4 than 12 hours of Metro (which says a lot)

Also it's not very open world like Fallout or Skyrim is with a giant map to explore. It has different zones that you can explore but it tries to push you where to go, and having done some exploring there isn't a lot to discover that isn't map marked.
Some of the zones there is pretty much only one direction to go in which is slightly disappointing.

Because of the lack of dialog boxes I have no idea if an NPC has finished talking, so I just get bored of their waffle and walk off, only then to have to come back.
I got woken up by some thugs after a sleep, had a conversation. When I left they said 'oh going so soon?' So I came back presuming they had more to say, only to all stand around with nothing happening (have you finished?) Left again they said 'going so soon?' So presume that's how that conversation ends - It's not very clear when to leave and they do go on a bit.

The story hasn't really grabbed me and the people need to say their shit quicker, there are some very boring or cheesy wank cut scenes that seem to go really slowly and on for a long time, and some interactive driving - hold W do a bit of steering, none of which adds to the game.

Might be worth checking but don't pay more than £10 for it.

This is my first game in the series. I've met a lot of people in my shoes, exodus just appeals more than the others  for some. Here are some tips that tie into the other games aswell.

HERE ARE SOME TIPS FOR PLAYING.

1. Explore every optional objective, and investigate as much as possible. This ties into 3 (And 4 with the optional objectives) because more optional objectives and abandoned ruins explored the more resources, and lore can be unlocked. Make sure maps are fully scavenged!

2. When the game displays "Save file corrupted," take that with a grain of salt. NEVER EVER FOR THE LOVE OF CHRIST press that little 'overwrite' button. It probably wont delete your saves, however there's a chance in there that it will. 

3. Make use of your resources. Loot every corpse you find. Resources can be abundant in this game! however, sometimes your luck will run out. Conserve ammunitio, and make sure to clear locations of any goodies that can be manipulated at the workbench. Also, please make medkits, I cannot stress this enough. Deathloops are super easy to fall into, and make sure your weapons are CLEAN. 

4. Make sure to spare some people. I wont spoil anything, however I recommend you spare AS MANY PEOPLE AS POSSIBLE. This includes; Fanatics at the Volga, slaves (Even the mean ones) at the desert, and anyone else who is not 'evil' through the game. Think of it like RDR's honor system. However, unlike red dead the game will change drastically if you take this route. This will keep your favorite crew members alive, and you will reach a better ending.

Anyway, good hunting, Spartan. Welcome to the Metro, enjoy the endless frustration.

Metro Exodus: Your Choices Will Determine the Fate of the World

[Introduction]

Metro Exodus is a first-person shooter video game developed by 4A Games and published by Deep Silver. As the third installment in the Metro series, Metro Exodus maintains the core elements of its predecessors while taking the series to new heights with open-world exploration and deep storytelling.

[Story]

Metro Exodus is based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's novel of the same name and follows the adventures of the main character, Artyom. The story revolves around Artyom's journey, escaping the life in the underground metro tunnels of Moscow to explore the surface world. This journey triggers a series of events filled with perilous mutants, rival factions, and environmental challenges. The story is centered on uncovering the mystery of character development and how the world came to its post-apocalyptic state. Players will experience an immersive narrative, with their choices impacting the outcome of the story.

[Gameplay]

Metro Exodus offers an intense first-person shooter experience. With a wide range of firearms and tactical options, the game places players in challenging confrontations within its post-apocalyptic world.

[Graphics and Sounds]

Metro Exodus provides a visually stunning experience. The post-apocalyptic world is meticulously detailed and atmospherically presented. The graphics immerse players in this perilous world, with detailed character modeling and environmental design creating a captivating visual spectacle. Sound design is another crucial element of Metro Exodus, enhancing its atmosphere. The environmental sounds draw players in, seamlessly transitioning between the claustrophobic silence of the underground metro and the wild sounds of the open world. The game's music effectively complements emotional moments and action scenes, enriching the overall experience.

[Conclusion]

Metro Exodus stands out as a successful game offering a deep story, impressive graphics, atmospheric sound design, and rich gameplay. The combination of gameplay, narrative, and visual and auditory elements creates an unforgettable experience. If you have an interest in post-apocalyptic worlds or have enjoyed previous Metro games, Metro Exodus is a must-try title.

Rating: 9/10

Overall impression of the game: Worse than the previous games (Metro 2033 and Dying Light) and here is why:

Immersion: Although the world looks stunning, the lighting effects are amazing and the sound design too, all allowing for some really nice stealth gameplay and it allows the player to really chose its tempo, who to kill and who to spare, etc..., But, being that it is now open world game, the iconic feeling of being trapped in cramped metro station hallways and passages is completely lost, with no real benefit, so overall, the whole open world aspect is almost pointless.

Guns: Ammo and attachment crafting is a good plus, but the choice of guns is terrible compared to other 2 games. A lot is removed, and the ones that exist just get boring really fast. 

Enemies: They feel generic. In last 2 games, there were clearly saparated factions, each with its own goals and needs and ways of liiving, which was really cool. In this game, everyone are just in some weird cult and they are all the same when it comes to the bottom line. 

Story: It is decent, but feels so rushed, somehow. I dont know how to feel, the core idea is good I guess, but it could be much better executed

Cutscenes: OH BOY, DO I HATE THEM IN THIS GAME. They are just so anoying and there is no way to skip them. Characters just keep on talking and talking, and you just sit there, literally waiting for them to finish, wanting to smash your PC. And this especially goes for anything that Anna (the in-game character) says, she is so annoying. And all this is 10 worse when you want to backtrack a chapter.

IMPORTANT THING

All these things would be a minor issues, if it was not for the following bug in the game:

At the arround half point in the story, you lose all your loot and guns, but you are supposed to get them back, and you are also suposed to have all old guns and attachemnts saved when acesing the work bench once this whole certain chapter is completed. The problem is: THIS CAN SOMETIMES BE COMPLETELY IGNORED< AND THERE IS NOTHING YOU CAN DO IT TO CHANGE IT, EXCEPT REPLAY 2 ENTIRE CHAPTERS.

Meaning, all your supplies you saved up, all guns, all attachments, ALL GONE, right before the MAIN PART OF THE STORY. 

This one made me mad, really mad, to the point that I dont think I will even try finishing the game.

And I do not even want to talk about some other bugs, like pulling up the map while driving messes up the camera, terrain clipping and render bugs, inconsistant way of showing you how much HP you have, etc...

So overall: A buggy game that in no way can be compared to the previous 2 games. Overall, barely a 3/5 (average game, but being that the average nowdays is CoD and Fortnite, yeah, it aint good...)

Basically, if you want that iconic feeling that Metro games provide, just play the first 2 games, especially Metro 2033 Redux, they are 100 times better.

Update after completing the game: (Long overdue)

So yeah, I did backtrack the two chapters and completed the game.

The ending saved it so to say. Going to Novosibirsk to look for a medicine for Anna was fun. Being back in tunnels, radiation through the roof, feeling like everything is a trap.... I missed it a lot and was so much fun to have some of that too. And a 'Two Colonels' DLC really saved it, I highly recommend getting this DLC. '

I will increase the ranking to a 4/5 because of this, But still, my overall verdict stays: Compared to previous 2 games, it is weaker in its main story, and atmosphere. I can recommend it, but not beofre recommending the hell out of two previous games.

P.S. 'Sams Story' DLC is interesting I can not lie, I would play that part again too

[i]Metro Exodus[/i] is a confusing title for me. 

It's a title where you'll explore vast and beautiful wastelands that fasten you to your seat while at the same time realizing that this all feels a little bit too familiar for you to fully be present there. Occasionally, you walk into rooms where props are floating and you come across various seams lacking the polish that they once had. Now more than ever, this game feels like its progenitor series [i]S.T.A.L.K.E.R.[/i] and along the way you will be able to tell the inspiration of various levels fairly obviously. This isn't to say that [i]Metro Exodus[/i] doesn't offer engaging places to explore and interact with, but, with little exception, the derivative elements were present enough to take me out of the experience from time to time.

The game also has the issue of not significantly rocking the boat for the series outside of its large, expansive levels. The enemies you face will largely be the same as the predecessors and many times certain gameplay sequences will feel borrowed from the previous titles. Unfortunately, it does seem like a lot of the creativity was devoted to transforming to a mini-open-world format rather than unique and new gameplay sequences and types.

Another major change in this title is the loot you gain from exploration. In previous titles, the fruits of checking inside and out for goodies were items such as ammo, health kits, and filters, which is immensely rewarding if you are running low on that specific resource. In [i]Exodus[/i], the main rewards you will encounter are crafting components which is both liberating yet a tiny bit boring. Inherently, it is more exciting to get resources you so desperately need rather than the crafting components for the same item, so even though you may be able to get what you need without stumbling upon resources you don't need, the exploration loop does not feel as rewarding.

There are also a couple of issues I have but they are largely present in previous titles, so if you are familiar with the series, you will more or less know what to expect. Just to briefly address them, here they are: video game-y narrative, poor English voice acting, and gameplay actions feeling tedious as a misplaced desire to be immersive. If you are new to the series, I would recommend changing the game to Russian and making the subtitles as big as you can (as a non-Russian speaker).

Despite the multitude of issues, I have a problem placing this game as "Not Recommended."  When the gameplay elements come together, you feel embraced by the world of [i]Metro[/i] and panic all the more when you hear a pack of Watchmen stampeding your way and you running out of shotgun slugs. And I can't say that anything else has immersed in the Eastern European urge to smoke cigarettes and drink tea with your lover the way this game has. You experience a great amount of lows along the way for this title, but at the end of the day, when the game works, you definitely feel the machine heating and steaming as it should.

As a fan of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. and Fallout series, this game is perfect for me. 
It succeeds in immersing me into a post-apocalyptic world in a fresh new way compared to similar games of the same setting. This review is written after a playthrough of the hardest difficulty - Ranger Hardcore. 
I also played the previous games in the series and can say this is an improvement. 

Things I like: 
+ The feeling of travelling through swamps, abandoned buildings etc, is compelling and tense. 
+ The graphics are great and a testament to the beauty of nature clashing the war-torn ruins of civilisation. 
+ The characters and monster designs are great. Characters are detailed and all distinguishable. Monsters are visceral and terrifyingly awesome. 
+ There are plenty of weapons and gear to engage situations in different ways. There are an assortment of meaningful attachments for each gun too and you'll find them yourself along the way. 
+ The settings are great. There are multiple settings too. It's not always snow. Not always a city or a metro. It's not always linear too, there are a couple open world sections where you're left to explore plenty of areas alone. And they're well designed. 
+ There is more than one ending and it depends on how you play. I got the Good ending, the one I'm told was the best, and I was very satisfied. 
+ Combat feels satisfying. Kills feel they have impact. And there are takedown animations too. It doesn't feel like two choices of guns blazing or sneaky sneaky ninja. It's deciding on how efficient you want to be and what will get the job done in a way that minimises how many deadly shots they take at you. 
+ The end mission is epic. 
+ Story is entertaining. Quite a few memorable moments. Not hard to follow. And the ending is really nice. 
+ There's a new game+ mode with a few additional options for altering the experience for the second playthrough. Including an Iron Man mode, which only saves when you complete a level. 
+ Ranger Hardcore is the perfect difficulty. With scarce but plenty enough loot to have fun and try things out and fights that don't seem unfair, but challenging. Great job! 

Things I Don't Like: 
- You can only play the Iron Man mode when you complete the game. So after completing this, I uninstalled to save space. Then when I returned to conquer Iron Man and double my playtime, my saves where gone and I couldn't. 
- The movement. The way it controls is really off and sluggish. Climbing is really slow. Sprinting is very limited. Sometimes if you sprint and stop and turn real quick, you'll do an awkward slide where your feet are trying to catch up to what you want to do. 
- Sometimes the audio doesnt sync right. Like they'll be talking over each other, answering a question when they haven't finished answering it yet. 
- Audio mixing is also not great. Sometimes you wanna turn a radio up because every thing around it is so loud and abnoxous. 
- Another problem I had with the audio is some sounds are just a mess and don't sound very clear. I get that I've been pounced on by a mutant, but why does my ear drums have to be busted in the process?
- Some glitches here and there. Getting stuck. Characters weapons continuously firing, loud as fuck, when they're in a cutscene. Getting your map out in a vehicle and suddenly growing 3 inches in height so you can't see through the window anymore. Kinda annoying but nothing game breaking. 
- I wish there where more long dungeons to explore on my own in free roam. Seems like the open world ones are small and simple compared to story locations, where you'll sometimes have a companion walking you through it instead of exploring on your own, with the tension and your own pace. 

In conclusion: 
A great game! Some audio problems but it has very good story different from others, likeable characters, fresh locations, amazing immersive post-apocalyptic atmosphere, filled to the brim with loot, monsters, secrets and more. And an epic ending as always. 

Very happy with purchase. 
Would love to see more Metro in the future!

Metro Exodus is a testament to the potential of post-apocalyptic storytelling and gameplay. In this game, players are transported to the desolate Russian landscape, embarking on a journey filled with moral dilemmas and heart-pounding action.

One of the game's standout features is its daring transition to open-world environments. This shift breathes new life into the series, allowing for unprecedented exploration and freedom. The dynamic day/night cycle and realistic weather conditions significantly impact gameplay, enhancing immersion. Metro Exodus introduces a captivating ecosystem where predators stalk prey, and the player's actions affect the world around them, delivering a level of realism that's both thrilling and suspenseful.

A distinctive element in the game is its morality system, influencing the story's outcome based on your choices. This system adds depth and replayability, compelling players to contemplate the consequences of their in-game decisions. Metro Exodus shines in storytelling, providing a straightforward and engaging narrative that newcomers can enjoy without any prior franchise knowledge.

While the game is not without minor technical issues like occasional crashes and lengthy loading times, these shortcomings hardly diminish the overall experience. Metro Exodus emerges as an exceptional post-apocalyptic adventure, exploring themes of humanity, survival, and hope. It elevates the post-apocalyptic gaming genre by focusing on execution over-familiarity.

In summary, if you appreciate post-apocalyptic settings, Metro Exodus deserves a place on your gaming shelf. It's an atmospheric and profound experience that excels in storytelling and gameplay. Whether you're a longtime fan of the Metro series or a newcomer, this game demands your attention.

[h3]No Metro Much Exodus[/h3]
Metro Exodus isn't as [i]epic[/i] as many reviewers have made it out to be. Compared to the other Metros, its quite bad. As a standalone game, it is decent but tedious and boring.

[h3]Should I buy it?[/h3]
No. Go play the first two Metro games. If you want a similar vibe and more challenge, play the three STALKER games and wishlist the upcoming one.

[hr][/hr]
[b][u]PC Settings[/u][/b]
The variety of settings in this 👉[b]PC game[/b]👈 is laughably bad. It doesn't give you any option to change individual graphics settings, not even the AA, and the motion blur can't be turned off in game. Further, there's no way to save a game apart from "Quick Save" ([i]what is Slow Save then?[/i]) and the game maintains like 4 saves which, if you're in a combat zone and it autosaves, means you have no manual save to fall back to.

[b][u]Bugs[/u][/b]
Every game has bugs and I get that. However in Exodus, I've encountered more bugs in the first few hours than I have in the entirety of many other games. Some of these bugs persist throughout the game. Heck, even STALKER doesn't have predictable bugs all the time.
[list]
[*] Characters walking into you and shoving you out of the way. (persists)
[*] Characters talking over each other.
[*] Getting stuck on trash sticking out of the ground.
[*] Wrong location marker for 1 main mission.
[*] Stuck quicktime events where hammering E doesn't do anything.
[*] Taking out & closing map in car lifts your view to roof of the car. (persists)
[*] Characters stuck on ledges/railings will most likely spaz out. (persists)
[*] Save corruption forcing you to pray for a good save since no manual saves.
[*] Enemy AI at most times is blinder than a bat. Harder difficulty just means more damage.
[/list]
Remember, [u]it has been a whole year since this game was released[/u] and they still haven't fixed these.

In addition to its technical achievements and intriguing story, Metro Exodus also features a number of nice jokes along the way. The game's world is full of little details that will make you chuckle, and the dialogue is often witty and charming. This helps to make the game more enjoyable and immersive, and it shows that the developers have a good sense of humor.

Overall, Metro Exodus is a fantastic game that is well worth checking out, especially for Linux gamers and fans of first-person shooters. It is a must-play for anyone who enjoys a well-written story, beautiful graphics, and a good laugh.

[h1]Metro Exodus[/h1]
If i'm being honest, I've never been so avid to get through anything in my life, but it was for 'Metro Exodus'. It went intensively brutal to me when publisher, Deep Silver removed it from the store all of a sudden and put it on further release date. Since then, I've been waiting every moment, searching forums for more info on it, checking store if it's back by wonder. But unfortunately, had to wait a complete year and then, I got it as soon as it released here in a heartbeat. So, here's how it went so difficult for me as a fan and enthusiastic. I had completed it once then and now it's second time.

[i]It is like the 'Interstellar' of video games, unarguably the best to me forever[/i]

[h1]Story[/h1]
'Metro Exodus' brought the continuation of the story of its series and inspired by 'Metro 2035' novel. I'm truly so lifted by it's noteworthy story-line. Let's just say, 'Metro Exodus' shares an endlessly heartwarming love letter to me, a beautifully written story. To say, the story has conjoined a lot of new characters with previous ones and developed them altogether which let them present to us like not just some bunch of associates, more like a family. A family always looking out for each other, supporting in every possible way, and obviously every one of them has their stories going on and build up developing from the very beginning to the epilogue. It is so overwhelmingly saddening to think about a certain one, yet satisfying about how Artyom and Anna's journey met its closure. So, all I'd want to say is, its story expands the diversity of this series and completes it beautifully. I really can't describe how exceptional it is to me.

[h1]In-Game Sight[/h1]
In-Game mechanisms, features, contents contributes same as it's story does. It has enough built-in to provide an immersive experience. Like a lot of interactive opportunities throughout the map, tons of weapons with lots of customization, upgrading gears, optional tasks to build up my morality and more. So, I had more things to allocate and finish alongside, not just story missions. In doing so, It felt so engaging and some undying urge for more exploration into it's beautifully crafted In-game world. About mechanisms, I mostly preferred stealth based movements as I had lots of opportunities to keep it down and knocking out, which worked out just fine. I usually prefer stealth based strategy, but in a very epic way and I profoundly had it here. Also it was necessary to pull out less bloodshed attempts, and keep my morality balanced. Though, I'm allowed to go violent when it comes to parry the mutants, monsters, beasts like beings and I did that.

[h1]Visuals and more[/h1]
Developers really deserves all the appreciation and compliments, like how they've mastered it's visual quality, brought it so close to photo-realism. It does look delightful, photo-realistic mostly at sunset view, worth of a capture. About animations, they're not done by motion capture, but finished as usual. So, those aren't so much appealing like Metal Gear Solid V, but however it is, It's beautifully presented.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
Any situations can be verily impulsive, shivering and gripping if given proper soundtracks. In this case, 'Alexey Omelchuk' the composer of this masterpiece, did it flawlessly with the diversity of his composing mastery. The whole of it, is breathtakingly beautiful, let me point out some of exceptional soundtracks. Like 'Main Theme', 'Race Against Time', 'Dawn of Hope', 'Atonement and Sacrifice', 'Exodus Blues', 'Overture', these are the once which I heard the most of all.

[h1]Impressions[/h1]
Well, 'Metro Exodus' is a love letter like masterpiece by Deep Silver and 'Dmitry Glukhovsky' which unbolts a verily engaging and beautiful story with well-polished visuals, flawlessly fine soundtracks and in-game built mechanisms, world designs. It has so much more to offer, compared to what 'Metro 2033' and 'Metro Last Light' does.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]
So, this is all I've got to say and I'm profoundly recommending it to everyone. With all that, I can assure you that, it's surely something exceptional. But what bothers me is how underrated this masterpiece is.

Rating: ★★★★★

Metro Exodus is hands down one of the best games I've played in recent years. It took me on an incredible journey through the haunting and dangerous world of post-apocalyptic Russia, and I couldn't get enough of it.

Let's start with the visuals. Wow! The attention to detail is mind-blowing. The environments, from the dark and eerie Metro tunnels to the vast and diverse landscapes, are so beautifully crafted that I often found myself stopping just to take in the scenery. The dynamic weather system adds another layer of realism, and I couldn't help but feel completely immersed in this desolate world.

But it's not just about the looks. The storytelling in Metro Exodus is captivating. The plot follows Artyom and his companions as they venture out of the Metro in search of a new home. The characters are well-written and relatable, and their personal stories had me emotionally invested from the start. The choices I made throughout the game had consequences, and I loved that I had to think about what I would do as a human, not just as a player. It made the experience so much more meaningful and thought-provoking.

The gameplay is where Metro Exodus truly shines. It strikes the perfect balance between intense combat and immersive exploration. The gunplay feels solid and satisfying, and the stealth mechanics are top-notch. What I loved most is the freedom it gives you to approach situations in different ways. Whether I wanted to go in guns blazing or take a more stealthy approach, the game allowed me to play to my strengths. The open-world design was a breath of fresh air, giving me the freedom to explore at my own pace and uncover hidden secrets.

Survival is a key aspect of Metro Exodus, and I found the resource management mechanics to be both challenging and rewarding. Scavenging for supplies and crafting my own ammunition and equipment added a layer of depth to the gameplay. It made every decision count, and I always had to think strategically about how to make the best use of my resources.

The audio design deserves a special mention. The sound effects are so immersive, whether it's the distant growls of mutants or the creaking of abandoned buildings. It really added to the tension and made me feel like I was right there in the world. The voice acting was top-notch, bringing the characters to life with believable performances. And the hauntingly beautiful musical score perfectly complemented the atmosphere and added to the overall experience.

In conclusion, Metro Exodus is a must-play for any fan of the post-apocalyptic genre. It combines stunning visuals, a gripping narrative, and immersive gameplay to create an unforgettable adventure. The attention to detail, freedom of choice, and immersive world design make it a standout game. Whether you're a long-time fan of the series or new to the Metro universe, this game will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.
