[h1] what a trilogy [/h1]

It may well be a reflection of the perpetually cheerless news cycle of the last few years, but the video game world is absolutely teeming with post-apocalyptic wastelands at the moment. They all approach their setting with a definably different mindset though, with many treating it as little more than a no-holds barred playground for ultra violence. The misery and hopelessness of the situation doesn’t always come into it, but you could never accuse the Metro series of shying away from the full implication of nuclear Armageddon.

Based on a series of novels by Russian author Dmitry Glukhovsky, the first two Metro games (remastered a while back as double pack Metro Redux) were set in and around the Moscow metro system, where a small group of Muscovites have survived the outbreak of World War III and try to make a life in the tunnels while avoiding the nuclear fallout and lethal mutants above.

The original games were primarily linear first person shooters, but with a heady mixture of other gameplay styles including stealth and survival horror. They also had an impressively ambitious story (also written by Glukhovsky) that used the setting to meditate on humanity’s propensity for conflict no matter the situation, as the survivors gravitated towards the authoritarian extremes of communism and fascism and absolutely fail to learn the lessons that caused their situation in the first place.

Despite a wide span of obvious video game influences, including Half-Life 2 and S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow Of Chernobyl, the Metro titles have a very distinct tone that is very much their own. The scarcity of ammunition, and the need to craft your own, adds a light survival aspect and while there are no stats or dialogue choices the strong narrative drive and exploration also tempts comparison with action role-playing games. The key difference between Exodus and the previous games though is that the new game includes of a number of open world areas, moving between those and more linear sections as the story dictates.

As interesting as the previous games’ stories have been in terms of their allegory of Russian society – and ultimately human society as a whole – the storytelling often got a little muddled and relied too much on familiarity with the novels and reading every little note scattered about the game world. Exodus is a direct sequel to both the games and the novels but has a much more straightforward narrative, that requires no previous knowledge of the franchise.

You play as an elite solder named Artyom, who has become obsessed with the idea that there are other survivors outside of the metro – despite all evidence to the contrary. Set 23 years after the initial missile strikes the landscape around Moscow is less dangerous, or at least less radioactive, than the previous games and it soon becomes clear that Artyom is right and he and his team of soldiers, plus his wife Anna, end up commandeering a train that takes them east across the country. The story spans a whole year in game time, starting off in the Moscow winter and taking in a wide variety of other landscapes, from desert to forest.

With the constant changes of season and location the segue between linear and non-linear maps works very well, with the latter filled with secondary objectives and rewarding exploration. Like Fallout, you’re constantly on the eye out for resources to collect, but you can craft basic ball-bearing bullets and other perishables on the go from your backpack, as well as reconfigure your gun on the fly. This helps foster a great feeling of freedom as you’re given a minimum amount of instruction on what to do, with the game relying on clever signposting more than following the Rockstar route of prescribed instructions.

The open worlds feature a proper day/night cycle and dynamic weather, so it’s often best to wait until night if you’re facing human adversaries, who might be asleep or unable to see as well in the dark, but at the risk of certain mutant animals being more active. There’s a well-established ecosystem at work, as you watch predators attack and eat prey animals, or call in reinforcements (in what is clearly a nod to Jurassic Park’s velociraptors) if one of their scouts spots you.

Even with the ammo limitations it is possible to play Metro Exodus as a straight shooter, but we found it far more rewarding to use stealth. As with the previous games the weapons are jury-rigged antiques and although the gunplay is a little better than before they’re still not that much fun to use, and that seems to be entirely purposeful. The artificial intelligence is noticeably better though and stalking enemies from the shadows is very rewarding, especially as each map is riddled with secret crawlspaces and shortcuts if you take the time to search for them.

Although there are some more arcade-like sections (a grisly encounter in a nuclear bunker being one early highlight) Metro Exodus is a naturally slow-paced game and all the better for it. What particularly impressed us was how it handles ordinary human opponents. Most of the low level schlubs you fight are just doing their job and you have the option of merely knocking them out when you surprise them. They’ll even give up and beg for mercy if they realise they’re the last man standing.

Not only is this vastly more realistic than most other games but the other characters recognise whether you’re being merciful or not and this can significantly affect subsequent encounters and how you as a character are perceived. A good argument could be made that the game should’ve provided dialogue choices and a voice for Artyom (although he does narrate the loading sequences) but as with all its gameplay elements Metro Exodus prefers to keep the mechanics as simple and accessible as possible.

The end result is a game that feels considerably more mature and meaningful than other post-apocalyptic titles. And yet the atmosphere is not quite so cripplingly depressing as the previous entries. It offers a damning indictment of humanity’s willingness to follow orders simply out of a sense of purpose and belonging, but there is a sliver of optimism present in the story and characters that was not so evident before.

What flaws there are mostly centre around the slightly scrappy presentation, with horribly long load times, minor graphical glitches, and an occasional penchant for instantkill deaths that seem to come out of nowhere. On balance though these are fairly trivial concerns and the graphics are astoundingly good for a game whose budget is undoubtedly many tiers below that of rival titles from much bigger companies.

Easily the best of the Metro series, Exodus promotes the franchise into the top flight of action adventures with a blend of genre influences that combine to create an impressively unique experience. It’s the best post-apocalyptic adventure this generation and proof that it’s not how familiar an idea is that’s important but how well you pull it off.

Let’s be fair and square. [u]Want a good post-apocalyptic game[/u]? Yeah, pick it up.

It plays really damn well, has a lot of nice exploration bits and allows you to make it a challenge or a fun shoot-the-things journey. The story has nicer, quieter parts compared to the original two, and by the time you’re done, it’s easy to feel satisfied with the ride. 

There's an undeniable impressive level of attention to detail, not to mention the entire setting is presented with so much authenticity that immersion is practically given in a silver platter. 
The audio is pretty much excellent the whole way, with the lovable stock sounds making a cheeky appearance as well. The only jank I dislike at all is how if you run you slide across the floor on dead stop but that's the slavish specialty.

Gameplay basics aside, both the dub and original dialogue is well directed, and it's unlikely you'll not love the brothers in arms that are along with you for the ride. Every scenario is full of stuff to see and are distinct from each other, and some have their own special elements that make them stand out, even if Caspian outstayed its welcome.

So, yeah, to make it short, if all you want is a good, solid game, just pick it up. Enjoy it.

[u]You wanted a Metro game[/u]? Oh, I have bad news for you. 

The core issue is that 4A changed, tweaked or outright ignored everything that made Metro distinctively unique. When theoretically asked "what's special about Metro" compared to say, Fallout, Stalker or the like, three things would instantly come to mind :

1- Ammunition Economy
2- The Supernatural 
3- Central theme of humanity's love for self-destruction

First, say goodbye to trading. Like, at all. Remember having to think whenever to use crappy ammo or grade rounds when in fights, or save them to purchase weapon mods? Well not anymore, they outright aren’t a thing now. While the dynamic approach is welcomed, it was such an essential aspect of the first two games that missing it makes something feel off to me.

Weapon mods you ask? You can swap on the go, don’t worry about what suits you or making choices before heading on the field, and when in drastic lack of resources, just pop the bag and you now care prepped for whatever the game throws at you. Also check this crafting system that basically showers you with easy resources, making being conservative with your supplies even less important. If you explore a lot, you will never run dry, when in 2033 and LL even the most conservative runs had me hardly scraping by at points.
In a similar note, they completely nerfed the visual identity of the bastard and the shambler due to the weapon customization. They massacred my boys.

Second, gone are the mystical, more unexplained things that pitted Artyom against things beyond his grasp. The supernatural elements of Metro blurred a line between science and fantasy that was the most original aspect of both games, enhancing the narrative’s themes and giving the series something truly distinct from every other post-apocalyptic setting. Without saying much, for 95% of the game, there is absolutely nothing, and even then there is extremely little.

And last, a central theme of the original story was that humanity was either going to have to learn understanding or was doomed to kill itself for good. 
Both games use a morality system that encouraged you to be invested in the world, the execution was questionable (cue the jokes about guitars) but the point was that to save humanity from repeating it’s mistakes, taking it slower and listening was the way to go. 
This is especially relevant in Last Light, where the child would beg for your peaceful discretion and resented the inevitable fights against your enemies. 
Exodus does something similar with the message of humanity coming together to save itself (if you know how the good ending is determined, you’ll know what I mean), alongside trying to make judgement calls interacting with other communities, but to me it failed to also show compelling contrasting factions save for the cult in Volga. None reach the level of tragedy of circumstance like Pavel, or pure evil such as Korbut. 

The moral dynamic of Taiga's children is compelling but it still ends up being interesting worldbuilding rather than an exploration of this theme. Not only that, all of the small scenes were you can sit and just listen to an NPC dwell on and on with stories, while mostly compelling, don't expand on this much either.

The best thing about the handling of human flaw in the series was that it went at lengths to show there were not always inherently bad people outside your group just because they were different. None of the factions you find in Exodus have that element implemented as strongly, if at all, because for the most part you only interact with them for a single chapter.

So yeah. Overall I was quite disappointed with this game. 

If it is the last game in the series, this is a considerably low note for me to end it in. They strayed too far to make a more appealing game that I did enjoy as it’s thing, but is devoid of the heart and soul that I expected from this franchise.

Not delving into deep details, I'd like to recommend this game to people who have played the previous games. If you haven't, I'd suggest playing the older games first. To begin with, the deep atmosphere we love is present, and the world is expansive and intricately detailed. The graphics are top-notch, gameplay is solid with satisfying gunplay, and there are plenty of upgrades to tailor your playstyle.

Now, let's talk about the story. I'd rate it 10/10, but it's important to note that this isn't your typical linear shoot 'em up game. You need to take your time, immerse yourself in the experience, explore extensively, read notes, listen to audio logs, and engage in dialogues. All of these elements contribute to the story, making it meaningful and providing the rich atmosphere you're seeking. I enjoyed previous games just as much as I enjoyed this one, and it's becoming increasingly rare to find a well-crafted, story-rich single-player experience these days. Ukrainian game company 4A Games has done an excellent job. (Thank you; I've had a lot of joy.) I've played the game twice now, and overall, I'd give it a solid 10/10. I'd even place this game alongside titles like Half-Life.

Incredible game with great characters, compelling story, and very atmospheric world. The open world mechanics combined with the travel system with the train is beautifully designed and allows for a seamless and natural progression through post-apocalyptic Russia. Getting the player outside of the Metro was just what this series needed to stay relevant and fresh. 

The very simple and straight forward crafting system gives you just enough incentive to loot around for parts without it feeling like a chore. I have seen too many games shoehorn a complicated crafting system in for the sake of having one. This is not the case for Metro Exodus. Crafting is easy, necessary and enjoyable. 

As with the previous installments the voice acting can be very strange and downright cringy at times but it's fun to laugh at and adds a level of charm to the franchise. The stealth in this game could also use some work but for the most part it does what it sets out to achieve.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing..

[h1] an FPS with diverse combat and environments [/h1] 

This is an FPS with optional stealth elements. Set in the dark irradiated world of METRO, an elite squad of soldiers burst forth out of the tunnels of Moscow, to explore the world beyond they thought was destroyed.

The story is pretty good. The dialogue is a bit odd in cutscenes, but it doesn't detract from the game. It might sound better in the original language instead of dubbed through english.

The gameplay is solid. In many of the encounters with human enemies you can either run and gun, or take a stealth approach, using silent weapons and hiding in the surrounding environment. There are an array of varied guns, each of which is heavily moddable, allowing one to make their own signature weapons on the fly to suit the enemy types of the moment.

The enemies are many and distinct, ranging from human grunts to all manner of mutated creatures which can fly, crawl, slither, swim and run at you.

The world is very detailed. The individual levels range from open-world pockets where you can tackle a variety of missions and explore in whatever order you wish, to corridor-style environments which were prevalent in the previous games of this series. The larger more expansive maps were a great addition, and really break up the pace in a fun natural way. They are packed with details, and often have their own specific enemies, ensuring  each location is refreshing in its differences from the others.
For instance, one of the maps is a desert wasteland containing giant gargoyle like creatures, ready to pick you up as soon as you exit the van you use for traversal. Another location is a forest filled with mutated wildlife such as wolves and bears, which roam the areas between bases.

[h2] If you have already played other Metro games  [/h2] then you will recognise a lot of what this game offers, and might be pleasantly surprised with the new addtions.

[h2] If you have never played a Metro game [/h2] then you can nonetheless pick this one up, but it might be worth your time to play the others first, considering they are excellent games in their own right.

I can highly recommend this title to fans of the FPS and stealth genres.

Overall this was a fun game despite the several issues i had with it and i enjoyed playing it. I think the story alone makes it worth a try.

I love Metro... I truly do... I finished the main story, but it still leaves a sour taste.
This could have been a masterpiece... But they just blew it.
When the game first released, it was so broken that I didn't last 10H before quitting, and I said to myself fine, let's wait a few years until they fix it.
A few years later? It's still broken. I would go as far as to say the game is simply unfinished.

The difficulty scaling has been messed up and very poorly though through.
The IAs are broken and robotic in so many ways... Breaking the whole immersion in the process...
The save system is literally one of the worst I've ever seen. I can't stress this enough. THIS IS ONE OF THE WORST SAVE SYSTEMS I'VE EVER SEEN!!!
The day/night cycle is broken not only because of light issues but it's also flawed by concept;
Do you really expect me to walk through half the map each time day comes to find shelter because if I'm not playing entirely at night every enemy will instantly spot me miles away? Seriously???
The "cannibals" chapter was the worst that ruined my game for good... This is not Metro... This is a slaughter... It doesn't make any fucking sense...
The "tanks" were bad... The bosses meh aswell... Well i mean there's the poorly inspired bear from last light... which comes twice... and yep, that's it.
Even the physics are messed up... I climb stairs and am suddenly sent flying like I've just been catapulted... And this happened several times...

The more I think about this game the more I realize the previous games just did better in every single way.
You wanted a semi-open world? There you go... You have it... Well I wish we had been given something else entirely.

The story do keeps up though, aswell as the characters, obviously the visuals are amazing, the beauty and deepness of the world is really what kept me going through the end, while the gameplay itself is just subpar in every other ways.

So many issues that they clearly never bothered to fix, the complete ripoff of what "ranger" difficulty used to mean... It's just sad.

Metro Exodus may not attempt to do a whole lot of things, but what it does, it does it extremely well. 

The game's beautiful visuals and ominous locations make for an amazing atmosphere, the presentation as a whole is top shelf quality. 

The story is interesting and well written, characters are genuine and you care for them, they are your friends, your family even that you embark with on quite the epic journey across the Russian wasteland. 

The gameplay hits just about right, combat is fun and engaging yet simple. Weapons are extremely well designed, modeled and animated so they feel satisfying to use. Looting and crafting is tasteful and enjoyable, never a burden.

The game's open world maps as well as the more liniar sequences are all done with a high visual fidelity and good level design.

My only one complaint, as with all Metro games, is the binary ending which makes no sense for this franchise. Overall though, I would wholeheartedly recommend this game, it's a smaller and more intimate experience than your Fallouts or Stalkers but like I said in the begining, the few things it does, it does them damn well enough.

To pass the lighthouse bug where you exit the cave and your whole pc freezes you need to NOT LOOK at the sea, instead crouch and keep looking at the floor and to the right a bit so your game doesn't show you the sea. I don't know why this happens but im guessing it has to do with loading the sea and the enemies (in nvidia gpus?).

Metro Exodus: A heavily flawed king of atmosphere, who did not learn anything from past mistakes.

While this review will have a mostly negative outlook, I still recommed this game simply for one reason alone: the atmosphere. When it comes to selling you a bleak, post-apocalyptic vision of the future, there is no better series than Metro, especially those abandoned cities, warehouses, train depos and the titular metro tunnels. When the game gets to those points, where you're left all alone in some dark, god-forsaken pre-war bunker full of dust, cobwebs, corpses and unspeakable horrors lurking in the shadows, it goes HARD.

While I completed the game 3 different times, the review will be from a perspective of my first playthrough on a ranger hardcore difficulty, which I recommend you pick, if you ever play this game. It's definitely the best, and sadly, simultaneously the worst way to experience the game. Ranger hardcore means essentially two things: no HUD and a "realistic" damage model, so everything that lives can die from a single bullet, including you. This game mode also highlights everything that's amazing about this game and everything that drags it down.
Let's start the positives. The list won't be long, but those are some of the highest highs in games. Metro Exodus looks beautiful. Every location, be it a forest, a snow-filled destroyed city, an abandoned tunnel, is simply stunning. The amount of details, the weather effects, the lighting and the ominous shadows. You can take wallpaper-tier screenshot anywhere you look. The game's looks enchance another thing: the aforementioned atmosphere. You can only truly get it, when you're crawling around a damp, "empty" tunnel with little ammo, hearing distressing sounds all around you and then, suddenly, your flashlight starts running out of batteries. You'll never reach for that "f" key faster in your entire life. The enviroments are varied and believable. The gunplay feels smooth and tight, the sneaking mechanics are simple but mostly functional. We gotta talk about the flaws tho, because there's a lot of them.
Remember how I praise the atmosphere of the game? Well, it's great... as long as no one is talking to you. Because the NPCs in this game are pretty terrible. Not only is their dialogue a kinda awkard attempt at literally translating russian manner of speaking that only sometimes works, there's just WAY too much of it. Everyone is constantly talking. Exploring an abandoned bunker? HEY ARTIOM I MADE THE COMMS WORKING! Exploring a flooded train depo? HEY ARTIOM WE'RE LOSING YOUR SIGNAL COME IN COME IN. Please, shut the frick up and let me immerse myself in the game! To add insult to the injury, you can clearly tell that most VAs are English-speaking people trying to put on an awful fake russian accent (eg. Miller's VA). But there are also Russian-speaking VAs talking in English (eg. Krest's VA) and they sound great, so what gives?
You know what else messes with your immersion? Scripts. Blatant, obviously scripted moments. It feels like something scripted is happening every minute to a point, where you can, for example, completly ignore enemies, rush to a scripted door and suddenly everyone behind you disappears. Scripted ambushes, scripted monster encounters, scripted "jumpscares", scripted moments when you're found out while sneaking. And it all doesn't work because...
The game is now "open-world". Kinda. That's what the marketing says. You see, only 3 levels are open-world. Well, actually the third one is so linear and there's no point to backtracking, so I can't really count it as open-world. Those two levels are definitely the highlight, but at the same time... exploring those maps fully is something the game doesn't really expect you to do. Things you find are just tiny bonuses that don't matter to the game's progression. It's not like you're not gonna be prepared enough for the main quest because you skipped those optional places. The other 3 levels are completly linear. And the first one is more or less just a tutorial. So you're looking at... 5 levels in total. And while they take about 15-20 hours to beat it's because of...
A shitton of unskippable cutscenes. Every levels starts with like 5-10 mintues of cutscenes. Every single thing has to be a cutscene. Every dialogue scene - soft cutscene (you can walk around but have to wait for the NPCs to stop talking). Every time you find something new like a car or a new monster - cutscene. I think that almost half of my playtime is just loading times and cutscenes. And you know what makes unskippable cutscene even worse?
God-awful autosave system. You might think "Hey, just save manually!" right? Well, the Ranger Hardcore mode only allows you to use autosaves. They're so broken that it's not even funny. Combine that with the fact that you can die from a single hit and you'll be pulling your hair out over lost progress. Whoops, the last autosave was 20 minutes ago! Whoops, the autosave point was set just ahead of you spawn point, making you overwrite the save slot every time you load in! Whoops, every autosave is just BEFORE the unskippable cutscene! Sometimes leaving the saferooms autosaves, sometimes it doesn't. Sometimes you get 30 minutes of no saves, sometimes the game will save 3 times while you're standing still, listening to some NPC.
Other minor flaws include weird movement glitches (my car flipped on a straight, flat road killing me instantly and I once died while sprinting down the stairs...), tutorial messages not showing up on ranger hardcore mode (I had no idea you can turn around in a train cart and had to do that segment while facing the wrong direction the entire time), enemies not looking at you even though their guns are pointing at you, getting stuck on level geometry.

You know what's the worst part about Metro Exodus? Every single flaw of the game was already present in the previous titles. The autosaves, the cutscenes, the npcs talking all the time, hud elements not showing, janky movement, sounds glitching out and de-syncing, etc... People were complaining about this stuff back in Metro 2033 and after all these years two things have not changed -

- Metro series is still unmatched when it puts you alone in the dark metro tunnel, and it's still, unfortunetly, flawed as all hells. Give it a cautions try.

Metro Exodus is a continuation of the story of its central, POV character, Artyom and thusly it is recommended that you play the first two, well, first. But its not necessary, as Exodus is somewhat unconnected to the events of the first two games. The first two deal with the fear of the environment and rising political tensions within the Metro, you leave the Metro within the first 2 hours of Exodus and don't deal with those factions anymore. Some characters return, but those who've played 2033 and Last Light will tell you that only 2 characters (aside from Artyom) are really important to the series as a whole: Colonel Miller, who you meet and work alongside in both 2033 and Last Light, and his daughter Anna, with whom Artyom works and starts a relationship with in Last Light. Both feature prominently in Exodus, as Artyoms commanding officer and wife respectively.

The story picks up sometime after the Battle for D6; Artyom, now no longer a member of the Spartan Order, but still close with former comrades and husband to Anna, is consumed by an obsession that atop the tower from the first game, he heard a radio signal, proving to him that outsiders to the Metro have survived and he intends to find out for sure-this obsession has led him to visit the surface numerous times at his own risk until one day, him and Anna encounter a train on the surface and their Exodus begins.

From here the story evolves naturally as the goals of Colonel Miller and the group Artyom takes with him change along their journey. The writing is generally excellent, with compelling characters and conversations. The game alternates between its semi-open world levels and confined narrative levels on the train as you travel. During these more confined levels, the interpersonal writing gets to really shine as the player can either skip the level and move on whenever they want, but immersing yourself with these people for 30 minutes leads to strong characterization as your mates drink and cook together, or you can have an impromptu jam session with another character, you can snuggle with Anna as she vents, have a smoke with your mechanic, or take over for your friend shoveling coal into the engine. On the other hand, the semi-open levels have well written factions within them, plenty of good environmental storytelling, etc.

Gameplay is similar to its predecessors, being a shooter with an emphasis on stealth--the AI is smarter than it used to be, and the stealth feels less buggy as well, and as a shooter, it feels all around more responsive and fluid than earlier Metro games. Artyom comes with a variety of throwables, including grenades, molotovs, distractions, and knives. A new feature to the series is the backpack, itself a mobile workbench that allows you to make some items and tools on the fly and modify your weapons attachments whenever; for example, you may find yourself in an unintended combat situation, and quickly switching your silencer for a long barrel or something can make the difference. Most weapons are heavily modifiable as well, meaning the simple AK platform can be turned into an AKM or an AKS, silenced, turned into a marksman rifle, etc. the only flaw is the weapon pacing. 2033 starts you with the most basic weapons, while slowly granting you access to the better ones through combat encounters and vendors and Last Light allows you to just choose your starting loadout, but still then removes them after a period of time, reverting you back to the 2033 style. Artyom starts with the AK by default, and most people will be hard pressed to want to switch that out as until its directly upgraded with the modern version, its the most versatile weapon you have. your secondary is largely up to you, and your choices also include a Nagant Revolver, a break action shotgun, a better shotgun, and a bolt action rifle.

Graphics are excellent, with 4A using a strong style of realism. the improvised weapons of the Metro look possible, are well textured, and gleam nicely in the light. Character models are highly detailed, with lots of bits and bobs on each of your friends' armors, helmets, and plate carriers, enemies are often given a similar treatment. Textures do suffer slightly, as they are pretty old now, but you'll be able to look past them easily thanks again to style and atmosphere. In the Enhanced Edition, Ray Tracing actually works with little impact on performance--looking out at the Volga atop Krest's crane and certain indoor scene with lots of different sources casting light do send me into the high 40s, but those are when it would be most taxing so its fair enough. 

 The Metro series are a rare example of "story first" FPS games and Exodus is no exception, there is only one level that is a straightforward shooter level, all the other levels are meant to be chewed on and approached with nuance. Like the older games, "moral points" feature somewhat and influence the "good" or "bad" endings, but they feel different than older games. In 2033, moral points were almost all tied to subtle choices you made through the game, like accepting or rejecting a clip of MGR as payment, or paying a kid in a station to lead you around. In Last Light, moral points were more often scattered as rewards for exploration, but occasionally with choices too, like sparing Pavel or killing a surrendering enemy. in Exodus, they are a bit more tied to doing side objectives and also how stealthy you are in certain situations. When escaping from a religious groups stronghold early on for example, not getting caught will get you a point. In the same area, there are points tied to rescuing prisoners from the bandits in the area, getting a little girls teddy bear back from a mutant that took it, or finding a guitar for another friend. Enemies will surrender in combat if they are overwhelmed but im pretty sure you can kill them with impunity.

On Ranger hardcore, with full immersion, as long as i played stealthy, i never found the game too hard, even in its all out shooter moments. the only exceptions to this are a section at the end of the Dust chapter when you confront the Baron, and the bear encounters in the Taiga chapter, all of which can be somewhat frustrating. Explore most of whats around and again, be stealthy, you shouldn't run out of ammo or anything. Remember to sleep to nightfall if you're having trouble getting through an enemy camp. The hardest thing about Ranger Hardcore are the moments when Artyom has a range of interactions with a item (like at his desk where he can use the radio and read his notes, or getting ready to sleep) when you can't see what each interaction is.

SERIES SPOILERS AHEAD

Exodus does a great job of immersing you into its atmosphere and vibe, and its generally well written. What it doesn't do so well are its cast of characters. For one, you've only Miller and Anna returning from earlier games (Artyom too), the rest are all new creations for this game. the downside is obvious: none of these characters are known or have an interesting relationship with the player. Duke, Alyosha, and Idiot had no connection to what's happened in the prior two games and Sam was SUPPOSED to help in taking D6 during the first game but was sick or something. That wouldnt be a big issue if these characters didn't have such an established bond with Artyom but they treat Artyom as a war hero (and he essentially is, from the last 2 games, but from rando unknown characters it feels off.) Funny enough, the best characters are the two who don't really know Artyom, Krest and Yermak. They are written as complete outsiders, Yermak having been supervised by Hanza and Krest being from way outta town. These two are the most fun to interact with because they don't reference earlier games; they are here and now. Krest is smart and personable, just glad to have a group of like minded people around him, and Yermak is like Artyom, disillusioned and tired of the Metro and the groups in it.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
Super basic stealth gameplay, a joke compared to Deus Ex, Dishonored or even Hitman. Gunplay is very standard just like the set-pieces that tie the maps (open world) together. Some set-pieces straight up feel like copy/paste form the first two games. You'll find tons of re-used assets, aka you're fighting the same enemies with the same guns from the first two games, just in a dead open world. The gametime padding  is super obvious: forced exposition, walk&talk cutscenes, traversing the maps is super tedious and hold "use" to open containers or interact. Last but nott least tbe controls are jank. You have to select throwables over a ghetto-ass weapon wheel because of the lack of hotkeys.

[h3]Bugs/Glitches[/h3]
I had multiple crashes and bugs where I had to reload because npcs got stuck. If you open the map while driving your car, your camera gets stuck in the car's roof. Enemies spot and shoot you through walls, while sleeping or having their back turned towards you (fun stealth gameplay).

[h3]World/Level Design[/h3]
"Open World" in this game means a couple big maps with some smaller levels sprinkled inbetween. Each map has like 3 bandit camps and barely anything else. Luckily there is no point in exploration because all you find are  basic crafting materials and the occasional gun mod that isn't a game changer. You'll find the later from basic enemies anyway.

[h3]Story[/h3]
A boring and predictable story accompanied by one-dimensional characters that mostly revolves around fetch quests. The dog shite morality system is still in the game to force you into playing a certain way unless you want the bad ending.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
The game isn't terrible but redundant, you aren't missing out on anything if you don't play this game. This feels like a cash grab on the Metro ip. They didn't have any new ideas, so they made the game open world and called it a day, because that's what sells. This game only makes me want to play STALKER or Fallout: New Vegas again.

I would give Metro Exodus 7.5/10. I disagree with a lot of people here, who are calling it a masterpiece, since it has its fair share of flaws. The biggest ones being the writing and voice acting. Its all rather... simple. Something you would find in a 2007 game. The story was serviceable, and the best thing about it is that players new to the Metro series would also understand it, although a quick recap video won't hurt.

The best thing about this game is its optimisation and atmosphere. Runs great on my 3060. The dread when you're exploring a run down building with weird voices in the background is amazing. The exploration is fine, although it is little more than going to question marks and clearing the area. The end of the game is very linear but very atmospheric, so I guess that compensates for it.

Overall, I would recommend it, and it is very cheap during sales. 100% worth the price.

I bought this game at launch and never got past the first big area until recently when I decided to finish it.

First off, the Metro Core is still intact in this sequel. Don't get misled by the "Open World" that gets thrown in the first act of the game, the structure is expertly crafted giving you many vistas to enjoy but also so many claustrophobic and dark places that the metro fans love with A LOT of variety.

Gameplay is fantastic, one of the best in my opinion when it comes to linear story-driven FPS. There's a great variety of enemies and ways to deal with them that makes every encounter feel special and unique. Your arsenal is vastly improved from the previous games letting you now customize so many parts of your guns on the fly thanks to your backpack where you can also craft throwables, cures and ammo.

For the fans, this is a no brainer. For everyone else interested in this type of game, absolutely give it a shot.

[b]Positive points:[/b] 
+ I love this game, I never wanted to quit it. :-) Spent over 75 hours yet. 
+ Story, characters, Spartans.
+ Optional choice of stealth progress, as always in Metro games. I think it teaches that more difficult and time-consuming approach to problems can be also a challenge and fun, and will pay off with good ending. This principle may work also in a real life!
+ 1911 pistol feel in Sam’s story, especially with upgrades. 
+ Possibility to upgrade weapon anywhere by opening backpack.
+ Easy “puzzles” and most of locations to find updates.
+ Rich player can destroy gorillas/librarians at the end of main story. 
+ Beautiful forest areas, I made tons of screenshots. Metro games always seemed well optimalized to me. 

[b]Negative points:[/b]  
- I missed Vintorez and Clapper sniper rifle from Last Light. Any non-lethal weapon with range (or shooting enemies to legs as forcing them to surrender) would be good too.
- Restricted choice of third weapon in the main story (Tikhar or Hellsing, but never none or both).
- Passivity of human enemies, many of them did not explore area that much, even if they knew I am around and I am a danger to them.
- Some of dialogues were too long. 
- Looting should take less time. I catched myself collecting things again and again, and I believe it was NOT purpose of this game, even if the brain of the player perceive it as “reward”. We should focus more on fighting and stealth than collecting stuff from XYZ caskets and boxes.
- Looting again – it is not very efficient to add some weapons to the last part of the game, when there is almost no time to try it, like the railgun from Miller.
- Level design in Sam’s story was strange, some locations were blocked even if they did not look like blocked.

Post-apocalyptic game with elements of crafting, weapon attachments, going stealth or guns blazing, rich story, creative in its story-telling and unique atmosphere. If you're new to the Metro series and just intend on jumping to Exodus, I wholeheartedly suggest you to play Metro 2033 and Metro Last Light first due to the new perspective you'll get on Exodus.

Despite being the third game in the series, it does not try to be anything it wasn't before and stays true to its core, not only that, it builds on what it may have lacked previously.

Truly well-acted and immersive dialogue, each character has their own story that just swallows you in, amazing graphics even for today's standards, great variety of maps and level designs where one map (chapter) is totally different from another with several types of biomes and approaches for each map.

The entire trilogy is one of its kind and Exodus lived up to its previous games.

[h1]A signature game[/h1]

I think they've made the best game that can be made with the technology that's available at the end of the age we're in. 

Love, betrayal, friendship, and Russia.

The flow of the story flows so well that suddenly something happens and when you say "what's the relevance", the answer is given instantly. We go with the flow and we see very deep traces of the real world; human reactions, death effects and so on. 

Politically, Russia's loneliness, being lost in itself and not trusting anyone, as well as the class divisions, betrayals, conflicts and more. 

It felt more like a living environment than a play, and the use of everything very judiciously and in its place felt very natural to me.

There is only one thing to criticize and that is that Artyom never speaks. [b] The answer to this is as follows: Just like Gordon Freeman never speaks (Half life), this is just like that; because you are Artyom.[/b]  I think it's a very reasonable answer, but the fact that he doesn't react at all during all the emotional and exciting moments seems a bit lonely, at least for me.

Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition is now out and is fantastic. 

Metro Exodus is a well made stealth and survival, apocalypse game based in Asia. I like to refer to it as a Fallout lite with a better story. The open world is more linear and not as in depth, but story and voice acting is phenomenally better. 

Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition provides a fantastic improvement on what was already a beautiful game. The graphics are not next generation. However, they hold up very well and present a beautiful game that disguises its age well.

The audio is a bit of a mess. Despite having fantastic audio and excellent voice acting, the Enhanced Edition did not do anything to upgrade the audio. As such, many of the new drivers and format delivery can cause the game to crash. As such, you may find that your headsets, newer surround sound systems and sound bars could crash the game. This has been the only issue that I have run into. I turned off the spatial option, played the audio through an older driver and it stopped the crashing. I have had zero issues since.

Metro Exodus was already a highly recommended game, in my opinion. The Enhanced Edition releases a beautiful enhancement to the game, making the experience fantastic on my 84" television. This game is recommended for those that enjoy apocalyptic story lines, or even a good story game. You do not have to do the open world aspects, but I find them enjoyable as well.

In short, Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition is recommend as a fun gaming experience that holds up very well to today's games. Fallout-lite with a better story and more compelling linear experience.

Where to even begin with.....The whole metro series has been a huge adventure, Although the first two games were linear it never felt so with the level of immersion the games had. Metro exodus has taken it a notch above and succeeds to completely immerse you in its vast world. The world is beautifully crafted with amazing characters you end up loving and caring for, it really gives you a grounded feeling where you actually feel that the world around you changes according to your actions. You totally feel in control and have a sense of responsibility to be a true ranger. The fact that your choices have consequences makes the game even more immersive. The gameplay is smooth and super fun, the different levels of difficulty helps you to tailor your gameplay to your liking as to how realistic you want the experience to be. It's a super fun game with an exceptionally well written story with an amazing cast of characters each with their own unique personalities. 

A must play if you love immersive single player games with a great story, not a lot of them out there these days.....

A fantastic conclusion to the trilogy, and honestly one of the only games that handled the transition from linear shooter to "open world" correctly. 
Narratively, this game is sound, and the journey the crew leaves on will have you genuinely wondering where it goes next for a decent portion of the game, but in a good way! A lot of the cast is just sort of willed into existence as the main characters friends despite the fact they weren't in the prior games, but they have enough decent dialogue and focus that it gets a pass, similar to how Half Life 2 did this with it's cast compared to the prior game. Also, for the cast that was pre existing, gets some incredible character development. Anna is cool. Miller is one helluva father in law and commanding officer, and by the end of the game you may care for these characters a bit!
Mechanically, I cannot praise this game enough. The former games were linear shooters with a focus on stealth and basic survival mechanics, and this game expands on all of that. It keep's some of it's linear style in some levels, but introduces 2-3 open-world-ish levels, where their's a set of main "quests" or objectives you have to accomplish that develop as you do them, but a large space that those objectives are set in. Not large enough to feel empty though, compared to actual open world games they're all quite small, and are navigated on foot, but in between those objectives, are a plethora of well designed areas to search and loot for supplies, enemies to fight or try to avoid, safehouses to spend the night in, and tons of miscellaneous things to encounter. They're all places that feel lived in and well detailed with lots to do, not bland and devoid of life save a set of collectibles like most modern open world games. The new survival aspects also improve the game immensely. Yes, their's crafting but its very simple, their's also a "gun smith" that has an interesting aspect where you can only access it partially in the field, so you have to be careful with what weapons you bring for whatever you're doing. 
It's incredible, and I wish other games got their mechanics improved like this game so wonderfully did.

On January 4th, 2021, I finally completed my journey through Metro Exodus, and it dawned on me that I had just encountered a true masterpiece, one that has effortlessly ascended the ranks to become one of my all-time favorite games. My year-long anticipation, marked by the patient wait for the Epic Store exclusivity to wane, was richly rewarded the moment I acquired the game on Steam. In retrospect, I would willingly have extended my wait to relish the captivating experience that this exceptional game offers.

Though I missed out on the novel RTX technology, I was astounded by the captivating visuals and seamless performance on my trusty GTX 1070. Metro Exodus stands tall among the most visually captivating games available, exuding an unparalleled atmosphere of realism. This realism isn't confined merely to the graphical realm; it permeates the very core of the gameplay, resulting in a remarkable transformation. The weapons and combat mechanics have ascended to an unparalleled pinnacle; each firearm boasts an astonishing level of customization and intricate detailing, down to the nuanced reality of jamming due to excessive dirt accumulation.

With the introduction of fresh adversaries, a revamped crafting system, and the intriguing blend of Open World exploration and Linear Storytelling, the game beckons players to explore the desolate landscapes of post-apocalyptic Russia. The musical score seamlessly weaves into the fabric of the Metro universe, reaching a crescendo that leaves an indelible impact. In the final climactic moments of the narrative, I found myself intricately intertwined with the emotions of the characters, a symphony of goosebumps coursing through my being. What was once a solid gaming experience in the Metro series has now blossomed into an unforgettable odyssey, transcending boundaries.

The storyline, although straightforward, exudes a unique sense of style, brimming with emotion and pulse-pounding action. As for the finer intricacies of the plot, I leave those treasures for you, the intrepid reader of this review, to unearth and relish firsthand.

Nestled securely in the third spot on my personal list of favorite games, Metro Exodus has stoked a blazing anticipation within me to soon embark on the captivating journey offered by its two DLC expansions. For those in search of an extraordinary gaming series that seamlessly blends action, realism, horror, and raw emotion within a post-apocalyptic canvas, I wholeheartedly endorse the entirety of the Metro franchise. As for Metro Exodus, it stands unwaveringly at a perfect 10 out of 10, an unequivocal masterpiece that beckons you to immerse yourself in its world and savor the unparalleled experience it bestows. Don't hesitate – venture forth, play the game, and bask in its resplendent glory.

Overview
Metro Exodus is the third installment of the acclaimed series, inspired to the books of Dmitry Glukhovsky, and set after the events of Metro last Light. Once again impersonating Artyom, players will soon leave the cryptic tunnels of the Moscow Metro to journey on through the entirety of Russia, ending up in a variety of places ranging from deserts to lush forests - accompanied by Colonel Miller and his elite Spartan team. What initially begins as a daring escape soon turns out to be a journey for survival, as unexpected turns of events one after another come crashing down on the squad.

🟩 Pros
Incredible visuals with excellent art direction.
Realistic, satisfying and unforgiving combat system on higher difficulties.
Meaningful exploration with many secondary locations.
Excellent narrative and character building.
Overall good variety of content, situations, enemies and tools.

🟥 Cons
Karma system, which determines the ending, was reworked in a bad way.
In Ranger Hardcore mode, Autosave frequency is inconsistent and can lead to significant progress loss.
Rating: Excellent

Exodus' visuals are amazing, possibly the best available on PC to this day. Each environment is recreated with masterful art direction. 
A Screenshot of Metro Exodus
By: Brinda


Starting with the good points, the strongest feature of Exodus as it was with the prequels, is the atmosphere and world-building, which deliver an uncompromisingly realistic take on the nuclear post-apocalypse. This time it's not confined to the cramped Metro tunnels, but shows in full the entirety of Russia's wastelands, and does so flawlessly. Fighting any kind of enemy on the higher difficulties is a tense and unforgiving affair, where all but the weakest attacks mean certain death for both yourself and most enemies.

This realism is complemented by accurate gunplay and good variety of murder tools to use. Exploring the wastelands is not only spectacular but also worthwhile, as every map contains a bounty of secondary locations often hiding unique upgrades for Artyom's suit and weapon mods. They will make your life easier once acquired. The narrative and characters stay true to the excellent book series and do not disappoint in the slightest.

There are however a few dents to an otherwise flawless execution. The Karma system has been reworked and forces players to take on the majority of situations with complete stealth, without also killing anyone in order to get the good ending. This goes as far as penalizing you for killing someone that shot first and is openly hostile, while the consequences will influence your companions' very lives as if some "higher power" was there to punish you - which makes no sense.

Overall, Metro Exodus remains an excellent open-world FPS that delivers the quality already made famous from the previous chapters, at the same time enhances the gameplay in new ways bringing it to a new level that surpasses the previous ones in almost every department. It took me around 25 hours to finish the game on Ranger Hardcore, while exploring thoroughly every map and completing all side content. For the price of 40€ and excellent quality, I can recommend buying at full price.

By: Brinda


In-Depth Breakdown
🎮 Gameplay Analysis
Gameplay is divided into Exploration, Character Management, Quests and Combat.

Exploration
Is performed on foot most of the time, except in a particular map where there will be a truck at your disposal. Ziplines and boats are also used sparingly to traverse otherwise impossible paths. While exploring, keeping an eye out for mechanical and chemical components - both used in crafting - is one of the primary goals, as you'll need them to craft supplies. Of course you can also find already made ammo, medkits and filters, but that's a more rare occurrence.

Certain specific places hold unique modifications more or less hidden, and this is what makes exploring every corner worthwhile. A global map will display your position and all the discovered points of interest, highlighted on the map by using the Binoculars on a high place. Safehouses are sparingly set around the world and they can offer a safe refuge to wait night or day, craft at the workbench and more importantly save the game if you play Hardcore. There is no fast travel.

Character Management
Can be done on the fly with the portable workshop in your backpack, or in a more complete manner at a stationary workbench in a Safehouse. You will be able to modify any of your weapons with previously acquired mods at any time, as well craft simple ammo types such as arrows or steel balls, medkits and filters. More complex crafting requires a full bench and that includes changing your suit upgrades, crafting bullets and as well throwables like grenades, cleaning weapons to prevent malfunction.

Quests
Are not numerous in the game and usually are about retrieving a specific item for one of your travel companions or another character. They do not always award anything other than achievements or Karma, but still they are worth doing for the sake of storyline and to explore new places.

Combat
Is one of the most consistent elements of the experience and at least on the higher difficulties, is a brutal and unforgiving affair where even just one shot can instantly kill you, as well as enemies. Ammunition is fairly limited, while grenades and throwables are powerful bit very expensive to create - using all your resources, stealth as well, is key to prevail against overwhelming numbers. Nothing prevents you from going in guns blazing but on higher difficulties it's a good idea to take out at least some enemies silently before doing so.

Foes range from your average bandit with a shotgun to nine feet tall abominations with the strength of twenty men, passing from mutated shrimps and venomous giant worms. Each foe has strengths and weaknesses for you to exploit, for example most animals will be scared by fire or your vehicle. Human enemies are definitely smart and use tactics such as flaking, cover and grenades to overpower you, other than having swift reflexes and excellent aim - on Hardcore at least. Being accurate, fast and conservative are the pillars of Metro's combat.


Not only humans, but also all kinds of beasts mutated by radiation will be your enemies. Some of them will act as powerful bosses. 
A Screenshot of Metro Exodus
By: Brinda


Technical
PC Specs: RTX2080Ti, Ryzen 3900X, 32GB RAM DDR4
Critical Problems: None.
Optimization: Resource usage is within expected parameters for the quality, no problems to report.
Performance: The game runs without issues in 1440p, 85Hz on Ultra settings.
Bugs: Key rebinds do not work properly for certain keyboard configurations.
Other issues: Save system on Hardcore difficulty has frequency issues, might be a bug, unconfirmed.

Final Thoughts
Metro Exodus is definitely a worthy successor that expands the prequels' gameplay, taking it to new heights, but not without some drawbacks. Fans of the series and those who like atmospheric games will not be disappointed.

Metro already has been known as a franchise that offers solid storylines. Not just the lore and story but also the way it serves that to the player is fantastic. That is definitely still here with exodus. A fantastic voyage thru this universe that Dimitri Glukhovski created. Exodus is based on and starts with Metro 2035 and adds a lot of details to it afterwards. 
10/10 

2)	COMBAT / MECHANICS: This is not your typical FPS game. Carachter movement is so slow and far from being nimble. Mobility is highly restricted. You have to watch not just your back but also everywhere because there is no escape if you do a mistake. Same story with the ammunition and resources. So in terms of mobility and resource management, Metro Exodus is stingy. I love that tho. But clearly its not refined. I don’t remember how many times i got stuck in the middle of something important because of some weird terrain and game control interaction. So its unique, fun and good enough but feels far from being perfect.
8/10

3)	ATMOSPHERE / VISUAL DESIGN: Clearly the strongest part of the game with the story. Metro Exodus is kinda a 10-15 hour ingame engine playable cutscene. Illustrations are unbelievably good. Scenes and details are well made. Enviroment of the linear parts of the game are probably the best ones i have seen. At least one of the best in the gaming industry at the moment. Lightings, music and everything is nicely done. Every single part of the game pushes you to different emotions. Sometimes you feel the disgust. Sometimes you cry. 10/10!
Unless you have arachnophobia or herpetophobia. Gonna say it from the start, if you have one of those you are definitely not gonna feel comfortable in this game in a bad way. There are so many disgusting creatures and enemies you will encounter. And some of them are really common. Game has 3 different small but highly detailed open worlds that have different bioms, side activities that will add more to the main story and different mechanics in it. You will spend around 2-3 hours in each. Also at the start, end of the game and between the open worlds there are unique linear sections that will take around 5 hours in total as well. In total this is around 10-15 hours a beast of an experience.
10/10

4)	OPTIMIZATION / PERFORMANCE:
I am not very positive here. It works fine in terms of frame rates years after its release except some specific areas. But the way it performs and the layering is kinda weird. First of all crashes are common enough to make you angry. Also freezes and program not answering problems are still going on. Rarely but still there sadly. And the problem i talked about in the mechanic section, terrain and 3D model interactions are weird for NPC’s too. I have seen someone teleported or stuck for 2-3 seconds a lot.
6/10

OVERALL: Probably one of the best and most unique FPS games we have seen lately. Not gonna say this is a must play for everyone or a classic but definitely deserves a shot if you are into something different than the other FPS game campaigns we did get last 5-6 years. A perfect storytelling sweet spot between a disgusting thriller piece that will make you uncomfortable in a good way, an emotional storyline that follows interesting areas and enviroments and a super heavy stealth based action. One of my favourites for sure!
8.5/10

Metro Exodus (and on a smaller degree Last Light) is the answer to what happens when developers forget what made their previous title (which isn't that good to begin with) enjoyable to others. "Let's go bigger, grander, do what others are doing and failing miserably". Metro was enjoyable when Artyom was in claustrophobic tunnels fighting against other people and/or waves of mutants and that's why it feels good to play through The Dead City. Metro's story was better when it was about the political struggles. Metro's characters were never that good, but surprisingly, one of the only improvements over the other two this game has is characters.

This story isn't bad, but there's a caveat. 2033 was Artyom's first game, and if we break it down, the whole story revolved around him wanting to save his station. It's a personal story for Artyom, but we may not share his passion for saving Exhibition as we've just been introduced to him. We've had more than enough time with Artyom by Exodus so we (or at least I) could relate to his motivations - wanting to live outside the Metro and later in the story, saving Anna. Weakest part of the story is that it breaks apart if you don't care for Anna. I think the game does a good job of making you care for the characters, since in-between missions (and during them) you'll be spending decent amount of time interacting with them.

I played Last Light for the first time when it came out. By the time Exodus came out, I had forgotten my hate for Anna and in my first playthrough of the Exodus (little over a year ago - pirated copy) I liked her a lot. Recently I went back and replayed both 2033 and Last Light and I definitely understand why people hate(d) her. This game redeems her a lot and other characters are fun to be around as well.

Metro games can be a bit janky and this one is no exception. I had crashes from time to time, which isn't that big of a deal. Here are the three major ones that took me out of the game:
1) Sometimes when I pulled out my map and put it back down again, my point of view would be higher than intended, meaning I couldn't see the road and had to exit the car and get back in again.
2) In the Caspian level, I punched someone and got stuck inside a cage.
3) I also got stuck inside a container in The Dead City level and it made me reload a checkpoint.
4) During Two Colonels mission there's a scene in the 2nd act which makes me crash every time.
There were more bugs but rest of them are very minor issues that I can tolerate.

Another improvement this game has over its predecessors is how it deals with endings. I don't like the morality system in the previous games since some moral points don't make sense at all. I haven't gotten the good ending on 2033 or Last Light, but I have gotten the good ending on this game twice, despite not trying that hard. The contextualization of gameplay in the form of your ending is very effective.

Last but not least, game redeems itself a bit with The Dead City and Two Colonels missions. Finishing The Dead City and riding towards the moon makes me feel things I can't quite put into words. A sense of accomplishment, perhaps? Two Colonels mission is a lot better than (most of) Last Light's DLCs and Faction Pack was the only worthwhile DLC in that game.

The Metro series is just getting better and better and I can't wait for future games.

Let me just start out by saying that the game is pretty good. Replay ability? For me: zero. 

The game is marketed as an open world, but the gameplay and story is rather linear. Think of Half Life 2 and a fake sense of open worldness. Fallout series felt more open world. But it doesn't mean the game isn't well crafted. It is definitely fun to play, the morality system is BS, the way Anna portray her love feels like some kind of Japanese dating sim which irks me.

Also the developers obviously rip the basic game mechanics from Unreal Engine and it is obvious. One of the most prominent "bugs" is the running slide bug. If you ran toward an edge you somewhat defy the laws of gravity and get sent flying off the edge instead of rolling down the hill which result in fall damage. Anyone who dabbled with Unreal Engine will notice a bunch of jarring mechanic rip in what is deemed a triple A title. I can't blame them for streamlining with an already available kit but still, it feels bad.

Overall: 7/10

[h1]Almost, but not quite[/h1]

This game was [i]almost[/i] great. I liked the art style, the sound design, and the atmosphere. I wasn't a big fan of the story (mostly because I found it hard to follow), but it was fine enough, and I could see how it would appeal to some. The level design was passable. Artyom being a silent protagonist was weird, but it wasn't too bad. And I disliked the "morality" system (dear GOD the good ending requirements are an exercise in masochism), but I mostly just ignored it.
But there were two things that ended up being what caused me to put this game down for good. Even after taking a year long break and coming back, I still simply could not get into it. 

[h1]Oversimplification[/h1]

I like complexity. I'm an engineer; solving practical problems is what I do. Which is why it was such a letdown when I found how little depth the game's systems had.
Crafting was very simplistic. Only two types of resources - Metals and Chemicals. Both are abundant, meaning that by the end of the second level I had more resources than I knew what to do with. Weapon cleaning was basically just a Chemicals tax - hold E on your gun at a workbench, spend a few chemicals, and boom, it's clean as a whistle again. Ammo was cheap to craft, and there was no special ammo types, at least not within the first few chapters. 
Multiple other mechanics were also oversimplified. Radiation is basically harmless, as putting on your gas mask basically negates it, from my experience. Magazines aren't tracked. You can't swim. These are just a few of the mechanics I found to be too simplistic. 
On it's own, this simplicity was annoying, but not game breaking. However, in conjunction with my next point...

[h1]Enemy AI[/h1]

I absolutely [b]despise[/b] the enemy AI in this game. Not because it was too hard, but because it was too [i]easy.[/i] 
I have played games with good enemy AI. S.T.A.L.K.E.R Anomaly had absolutely stellar enemy AI. They used cover, and used it well. They flanked. They sneaked up on you. They coordinated with their allies. They rushed you when you tried to hide or heal. They could chase you. They felt [b]real.[/b]
Hell, even in an "unrealistic" game like Battlefield 1, the enemies in the story mode were relatively smart. They did pretty good with using cover, investigating noises when you try to sneak around, and felt not "real", but still presented an interesting problem.
Metro Exodus enemies do none of that. They hide behind cover, but they expose themselves too much. They don't move positions after shooting at you. I never felt at risk when I was healing in the middle of a fight. I never felt like I had to worry about being flanked or caught off guard. 
Sneaking around was comically easy. As long as I wasn't near a light source (and you could douse most light sources), it felt like I was practically invisible. They never investigated the noises of their friends' bodies hitting the floor. Even if I got spotted, I just walked into the shadows, they lost track of me, and then I resumed backstabbing them. I never died to a human once. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

If you're looking to shoot stuff and walk around, then you'll probably enjoy this game. There's no complex weapon maintenance systems to engage with, and you don't have to have military training to win gunfights.
But if you're like me, and you like depth, than you might want to either wait for a big sale (like I did) or just look elsewhere.

4A Games have delivered an epic that stands tall as true brilliance that transcends the boundaries of the gaming world. From its breathtaking graphics to its engrossing story and characters, this game is a prime example of how video games can be a form of art.

Graphics and Presentation:
One of the first things that captivated me is the game's awe-inspiring graphics and presentation. The post-apocalyptic world of Metro Exodus is beautifully rendered with stunning attention to detail. The environments are hauntingly atmospheric, from the desolate, irradiated wastelands to the claustrophobic tunnels of the underground metro. Every scene feels meticulously crafted, drawing players deeper into the gritty and immersive world.

Sound Design:
The sound design in Metro Exodus is nothing short of extraordinary. The ambient sounds, eerie echoes, and heart-pounding music blend together to create a palpable sense of tension and unease. The audio cues play a vital role in amplifying the game's atmosphere, making every encounter feel nerve-wracking and intense.

Gameplay:
Metro Exodus shines through its gameplay mechanics, offering a mix of intense action, stealth, and exploration. The game strikes the perfect balance between these elements, allowing players to approach challenges in various ways. The freedom to choose between lethal and non-lethal approaches adds depth to the gameplay, giving players a sense of agency in crafting their personal playstyle.

Story and Characters:
At the heart of Metro Exodus lies a captivating and emotionally engaging story. Artyom's journey to find a new home beyond the tunnels of the Moscow Metro is a compelling narrative that touches upon themes of survival, hope, and humanity. The game's characters are well-developed and relatable, making players genuinely care about their fates. The emotional connection with the characters elevates the overall gaming experience, making choices and interactions feel more significant.

Immersive Setting:
The game's setting plays an indispensable role in making Metro Exodus a triumph. From the moment I stepped into this post-apocalyptic world, I was immersed in an environment that is as captivating as it is treacherous. The diverse landscapes, ranging from snow-capped mountains to sweltering deserts, offer a sense of exploration and wonder rarely found in video games. The haunting beauty of the world serves as a constant reminder of the devastation humanity endured, making players ponder their role in shaping the game's outcome.

Conclusion:
This is undeniably a brilliant in every aspect. Its breathtaking graphics, compelling story, rich characters, and immersive setting combine to create an unforgettable gaming experience. This game successfully blurs the line between a thrilling interactive adventure and an artistic masterpiece. Whether you're a fan of first-person shooters or a connoisseur of storytelling, Metro Exodus delivers an unparalleled journey that will leave a lasting impression on anyone lucky enough to embark on it. I already knew Metro Exodus would be an amazing game, but it still blew my mind and made me itch for more.

Throughout my experiences in the previous Metro series games, I originally had high hopes for this game, and I wanted to enjoy it more than I anticipated.

Metro 2033 had been nothing but complete boredom of your guide gameplay, with barely any given freedom to explore around. The stealth mechanics are also ridiculous; enemies immediately go full alert if you did not fully kill, enemies able to spot you even on completely dark places. Until I play Metro 2033 redux, which is a remake using the same system as Metro Last Light, making the gameplay and stealth mechanics slight more bearable. I manage to give myself a try and finish the redux version rather than the original game, but overall it's decent. It's not bad on its own but it's also not good either.

Metro Last Light is supposed to be a better sequel with better gameplay and stealth system. It was originally enjoyable from start to finish, and I even played multiple times for different endings and different approach, only to be interrupted by crash that force me to manually restart my PC. Strange enough, Last Light Redux doesn't have that crash, despite the fact that there's almost no noticeable changes compare to the original Last Light. 

Now, for Metro Exodus. Regrettably, I have not finished the game, and I really wish I could. The game environment looks a lot more immersive, gameplay has a lot more variety, game gives you so much more freedom to explore around, it's everything. It's way better than I expected, and it's so good that I literally can spend so much time on the game to fully immerse myself into the game.

THAT IS...if the game does not randomly crash. My game has crashed like at least 10 times for no reason, I have searched up some forums to fix the crash, despite multiple attempts and it finally worked, only to experience another crash in different areas. I mean I could look up for another forum to fix the crash as well, but I really don't want to waste the opportunity to literally enjoy the game without experiencing another crash. Restarting the chapter to avoid the crash is already bad enough on its own.

My PC specs are high end itself, and I don't think it's my PC that can't handle it, otherwise I would have experience the graphical lags and set the settings to low and be done with it. I would have continue playing this game rather than writing this review if it wasn't for the unnecessary crash.

So, is the game worth it? Perhaps, that is if you don't experience any crashes like I do.

There is a hard crashing bug in the lighthouse (4th level if you take the start as a level) and from investigating I got to know about other crashing areas. After playing the other Metros I think this is unacceptable (yes, my PC outstands the RECOMMENDED specs) Right now I find myself trying to enjoy more of this awesome game but can t because the developers couldn t care to entirely fix it after 3 goddamn YEARS. Super recomended if you are willing to spend a day or two trying to bypass a bug

Metro Exodus has positively surprised and immersed me.
My first playthrough lasted for 30 hours and I would like to point out some of the things that I found most enjoyable. Firstly, the atmosphere is unique and well worked out. The story, the characters and the story are quite solid and well fleshed out. The gameplay accommodates both stealthy and guns blazing playthroughs. The decisions that you make throughout the game not only impact the end result but also motivate you to play in a certain style. If you are the type of person who would like to avoid violence, you will do your utmost for a non-lethal approach and the game will provide you with means of achieving that. 
However, it is worth pointing out that some of the mechanics are not as fluid as I had expected and that the dialogues may seem cheesy at certain parts but all in all I don't remember the last time I was so invested in playing through a single player game without the intention of finishing it.
If you are an enjoyer of games that you can play at your own pace, be emotionally invested in it and learn more about the setting you are placed in, this is a game for you.
Cheers, 4A games!

Metro Exodus is a remarkable first-person shooter and a true gem in the gaming industry.It takes players on an unforgettable journey through a hauntingly beautiful and immersive post-apocalyptic Russia. With its engaging storyline, breathtaking visuals, and refined gameplay mechanics, Metro Exodus surpasses its predecessors and stands as a standout title in the franchise.

Visually, Metro Exodus is an absolute marvel. The game boasts stunning graphics that bring the harsh, desolate landscapes to life. From the snow-capped mountains to the decaying ruins of cities, each environment is meticulously crafted with attention to detail. The lighting effects and weather dynamics create a dynamic and atmospheric world that is both haunting and beautiful. The level of immersion is unparalleled, making every moment feel tangible and realistic.

Gameplay in Metro Exodus strikes a perfect balance between tense stealth and intense gunplay. Players have the freedom to approach situations as they see fit, whether it's stealthily taking down enemies, engaging in gunfights, or using a combination of both. The game rewards strategic thinking and resource management, forcing players to scavenge for supplies and craft weapons and equipment to survive. The addition of a day-night cycle and dynamic weather conditions adds an extra layer of challenge and variety to the gameplay.

Furthermore, Metro Exodus boasts a level of replayability seldom seen in linear story-driven games. The game's open-world structure allows for non-linear exploration and encourages players to discover hidden areas, side quests, and alternative paths. Multiple endings add further incentive to replay the game, as your choices and actions throughout the story have consequences that affect the outcome.

In terms of audio, Metro Exodus excels with its haunting and atmospheric soundtrack that perfectly complements the desolate world. The voice acting is top-notch, immersing players in the emotional journey of the characters. The sound design, from the creaking of floorboards to the distant howls of mutant creatures, adds an extra layer of realism and tension to the overall experience.

In conclusion, Metro Exodus is a tour de force in the realm of post-apocalyptic gaming. It successfully combines a captivating narrative, stunning visuals, refined gameplay mechanics, and a haunting atmosphere to deliver an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether you are a fan of the Metro franchise or a newcomer to the series, this game is an absolute must-play and undoubtedly deserves its place among the best in the genre.

Personally I have experienced 3 crashes from this game and that's a shame because I wanted to give a higher rating for this masterpiece of a game.
