[h1]A Stunning Journey Through Post-Apocalyptic Russia - Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition[/h1]

[b]Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)[/b]

[b][url=store.steampowered.com/app/412020/Metro_Exodus/]Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition[/url][/b] takes players on an unforgettable journey through a beautifully crafted post-apocalyptic world, offering a fresh and immersive experience that captivates both newcomers and long-time fans of the series. Developed by 4A Games, this enhanced edition serves as a remarkable upgrade to the original game, showcasing stunning visuals and improved gameplay mechanics.

One of the standout features of Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition is its breathtaking graphics. The developers have painstakingly created a visually striking world that is both desolate and hauntingly beautiful. From the dark, claustrophobic tunnels to the vast, open landscapes, each environment is meticulously detailed, bringing the post-apocalyptic setting to life. The enhanced lighting and ray-tracing effects further enhance the atmosphere, making every moment a visual treat.

The story of Metro Exodus continues the narrative of the previous games, following the journey of Artyom and his companions as they seek a new home in the devastated Russian landscape. The game successfully maintains a sense of tension and desperation throughout, as players encounter various factions, mutants, and environmental hazards. The well-paced storyline keeps you engaged, with emotional moments and unexpected twists that add depth to the characters and their relationships.

Gameplay-wise, Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition introduces a more open-world approach compared to its predecessors. Players are given more freedom to explore the vast environments, complete side quests, and scavenge for resources. This change in design adds a sense of exploration and discovery, allowing players to make choices that impact the story and the world around them. The survival elements, such as managing resources and maintaining weapons, add an extra layer of challenge and immersion.

Combat in Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition has also received significant improvements. The gunplay feels more refined and responsive, making each encounter thrilling and intense. Players can choose between stealthily eliminating enemies or engaging in all-out firefights, adding variety to the gameplay. The AI has also been enhanced, making enemy encounters more dynamic and unpredictable.

While Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition offers an exceptional gaming experience, it does have a few minor drawbacks. Some players may find the pacing a bit slow, especially during the game's early stages. Additionally, occasional technical issues and glitches can detract from the overall immersion, although these are relatively rare and not game-breaking.
[hr][/hr]
In conclusion, Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition is a must-play for fans of the series and anyone seeking an immersive post-apocalyptic adventure. Its stunning visuals, engaging storyline, and improved gameplay mechanics make for a truly unforgettable experience. Despite a few minor flaws, this enhanced edition showcases the dedication and craftsmanship of 4A Games, solidifying the Metro franchise as one of the best in the genre.

I purchased this game for $5.99 US. At that price it's an outrageous bargain.  In spite of the seemingly endless cut scenes that dominate the early part of the game. Once you get to the Volga, they taper off a bit. One of the people who reviewed this game said something like it's not like other Metro games, and more like Stalker. In a sense (very loose one) that's true, and that's not a bad thing. Problem with the first two Metro games, is that they weren't games, they were mildly interactive movies. This one, starts out that way, then turns into a game. That said, if you are looking for an "open world" experience, play Stalker or better yet, play Fallout 4. This game is most decidedly not open world. It's on rails, and you are dungeon crawling even if it appears to be outside. You can't just go wherever and do whatever, but you do have some control (limited as it may be) over how you approach your objectives. So yeah, for the $$$ I paid for it, it was very worth it. I would have paid 3 times that much, and felt pretty good about it. Good game, for any money under about $20 US. As for bugs, I keep getting save corruption messages, but my game, it's always there, I mean, it always loads right where I expect it too, so, not sure what to say about that. So play, and enjoy!!!

“WAKE UP FROM ICE COLD DREAMS”


Mastering the art of combat is not enough for this game. You need little bit more than FPS skills to deal with the real situations with very mature logics of game programming. Every bullet, every step counts, every checkpoint will need proper assessment of the situation and plans to go through it. If you die, plan might keep changing until you give up or come up with a plan. Running, being silent or stalking are additional skills on top of combat sometimes. You will be  instructed to use jump button when you run which will help you to run faster. Filter of gas mask will ring just at the moment of serious combat but won’t actually bother you like first two parts of the metro. Specifically, when you leave Moscow, radiation will be bit flexible in the villages. Medicare has real scarcity I would say, wound doesn't heal completely until you take the medicare . Mutants are expensive to kill sometimes. I acquired the train at Moscow in stalk mode mostly but struggled a bit to find cover from the turntable room. The whole game is designed to struggle with securing cover when you fight, expects you to be bit aggressive in some places or totally silent. any wrong entrance, wrong forwarding will cost you excessive medicare. Will face the problem with supply of ammo when you’ll be aggressive. As I said, you will need more than FPS skills of body movement, aiming and covering in the situation of combat. A world class army back-pack will be provided by Russian army, so just have to be bit active to pick up scraps on your ways. Dont forget to sleep at night and assemble supply. Metro Exodus takes players on a daring and ambitious journey beyond the confines of the Moscow Metro, expanding the horizons of the franchise and delivering a breathtaking post-apocalyptic odyssey. With its expansive open-world, immersive storytelling, and captivating gameplay, Exodus offers a fresh and thrilling experience that surpasses its predecessors.

The storyline of Metro Exodus is a compelling continuation of Artyom's saga, as he and a group of survivors embark on a treacherous expedition across the devastated Russian landscape in search of a new home. The narrative explores themes of hope, sacrifice, and the indomitable human spirit against a backdrop of relentless danger and uncertainty. The characters you meet along the way are deeply layered and evoke a range of emotions, adding depth and humanity to the immersive storytelling.

The transition to an open-world setting in Exodus breathes new life into the Metro franchise. The game's environments are vast, diverse, and visually stunning. From the frozen landscapes of a nuclear winter to the lush and overgrown remnants of once-thriving cities, every location is teeming with detail and atmosphere. The dynamic day-night cycle and weather system further enhance the immersive experience, making the world feel alive and unpredictable.

Gameplay-wise, Exodus offers a satisfying blend of stealth, combat, and exploration. The open-world structure allows for more player agency and freedom, giving you the choice to tackle objectives in various ways. The gunplay feels solid and impactful, while the stealth mechanics provide tension-filled moments of sneaking through hostile territories. The survival aspect adds an additional layer of challenge, as you scavenge for resources and manage your equipment in the unforgiving wilderness.

A highlight of Metro Exodus is the meticulously crafted level design. Each area feels distinct and is filled with hidden nooks, side quests, and secrets waiting to be discovered. The game strikes a balance between linear storytelling and non-linear exploration, allowing for a sense of discovery and rewarding those who take the time to delve deeper into the world.

The visual and audio presentation in Metro Exodus is simply breathtaking. The graphics are stunning, showcasing realistic lighting, detailed textures, and impressive environmental effects. The haunting musical score and the atmospheric sound design further immerse you in the desolate and dangerous world, evoking a wide range of emotions as you navigate the post-apocalyptic wasteland.

In conclusion, Metro Exodus is a spectacular and ambitious installment in the Metro franchise. With its expansive open-world, immersive storytelling, and captivating gameplay mechanics, it pushes the boundaries of what the series can achieve. If you're a fan of atmospheric storytelling, dynamic open-world exploration, and challenging survival gameplay, Metro Exodus is an absolute must-play. Prepare to embark on a journey that will test your skills, tug at your heartstrings, and leave an indelible mark on your gaming experience.

Metro Exodus takes the journey from snowy and radioactive Moscow and its dark tunnels, to the vast, diverse and beautiful Russian far east. Enhanced version is the way to play, if you can run raytracing. While gamma correction is a bit off, causing some areas too bright or too dark, and there are occasional glitches, enhanced version has much better ambient illumination, less image noise and the ability to turn off motion blur completely and adjust FOV.

Metro Exodus not only has great stealth and excellent gunplay, but also an enjoyable amount of realism, such as the need to prioritize stealth and avoid combat as resources are scarce in a post-apocalyptic world. Weapons also start to wear out with more dirt and mud covered, causing jamming and damage and accuracy loss (the game provides a hardcore realistic difficulty as well). Additionally, the ability to customize weapon parts automatically wins a score from me. However, some design choices of the game are not to my liking (they are not bad) and some are just plain bad.

Metro Exodus has a unique approach to characterizing. The game often has five to ten minutes of just people talking to fully immerse players into the role of listener, from which you can learn valuable insights of the characters: their pasts, motives, traits, stands and thoughts, fully fleshing out the characters and forming a connection between them and players. Some of these stories are very entertaining with clever sarcasm about real-life social phenomena, and I totally respect this immersive way of characterizing. However, as a psychopath who always watches videos at 1.5x speed, I find these conversations too lengthy and I prefer something shorter and more condensed.

The moral point system dictates a good or bad ending in the Metro series. Previous games have harsher requirements such as listening to every lengthy dialogue. Fortunately, Metro Exodus does not require it, but you still need to take a non-lethal approach in many missions, which handicaps players. It is not just me being a blood thirst maniac wanting to kill everyone, it effectively strips away lots of approaches on dealing enemies taking away many gameplay features, and you have to read walkthroughs a lot. While it can be frustrating, the good ending is so beautiful and all seem worthy.

Let’s dive into the bad side. Though Metro Exodus is a good game, the pacing is far from being good, and the lack of long and consecutive levels is the root cause. With levels being relatively short, after finishing one level, the game tends to put players through long story sequences or require them to traverse a long distance in the open world, before they can have another short-lived level of action. The open world session pacing is the worst, with the much better and tighter pacing in late-game linear sessions and DLCs. It feels like the developers didn't have enough content in the middle of the game, so they stretched out what they had for far too long.

Metro Exodus changes to a semi-open-world-semi-linear structure, marking the first open world title in the series. However, the open world is the weakest part of the game. It is partially to blame for the sloppy pacing as reason mentioned, and it is vast and empty. Though the emptiness fits in the post-apocalyptic setting, it doesn’t justify the emptiness itself being lackluster in terms of gameplay. In fact, I really think the open world is unnecessary. Extra exploration for upgrades in the open world can easily be rearranged as linear levels, which not only paces the game better but also addresses the lack of long and consecutive levels to some degree. That said, it is at least better than those mundane checklist open worlds created just for the sake of making the game longer.

The story of Metro Exodus is based on a premise I find hard to believe (I didn’t read the novel), that there are people outside Moscow but was kept as a secret for years. From what I can recall, previous games did not foreshadow this, and it makes events in the last game look like a joke. The transition between knowing the truth and accepting it is also stiff and awkward, but it pales in comparison to the laughable silent protagonist.

The last two Metro games both have a silent protagonist, which was popular in the last two decades. I never found it jarring in the last two games, due to writers taking such good care of the fact that Artyom (protagonist) doesn’t talk, hence they never put him in a position being asked for a direct response. But the writers of Metro Exodus did not have such a heart. There are numerous occasions someone on the radio asks something like “Artyom, what is going on”, and Artyom responds with nothing but awkward silence, which completely breaks the immersion. This game goes the extra mile for immersion and realism in gameplay and storytelling, but somehow, they screwed up something so prominent. In stark contrast, DLC protagonists can talk, and you can immediately tell DLCs have a much more immersive presentation than the base game.

From the resource management focus combat to the bold storytelling design that might not win everyone’s favor, Metro Exodus is a slow burner compared to traditional FPS titles that are usually fast and thrilling. It suffers from poor pacing and a mediocre open world and is flawed in story and writing, but I still think it is a unique and excellent game after all. Two DLCs are also of high quality, with emotionally contagious plots, good level design and new weapons and parts (you only get the silent sniper rifle in DLC). These two DLCs are must-play as I think they even transcend the base game in many aspects.

Metro Exodus is the third game in the Metro series and represents the biggest leap forward.

Graphically, the game is a 10/10. It's fantastic. There's no comparison to its already visually appealing predecessors. The story once again surpasses its predecessors and casts them into shadow. Exciting, incredibly immersive, and extremely emotional, it's one of the few games that brought tears to my eyes. It's a journey that everyone should experience at least once.

However, the gameplay differs from its predecessors and might deter some old fans. There are now small open-world or rather open maps. These are extremely well-crafted, highly detailed, and offer a lot to do. The beauty of it is that there are no unnecessary side missions; there's no simple checklist to complete, and the story unfolds beautifully within those areas. At the same time, there are still plenty of tight and horror-like passages that target the hearts of old players.

Metro Exodus is a game that shouldn't just be played through; it should be savored and experienced. There are so many beautiful dialogues and details that the game thrives on exploration and soaking up as much as possible. The replay value is also much greater than in its predecessors.

For me, the game is a 10/10 and my all-time favorite game. I can only recommend that everyone experiences the pinnacle of the Metro series for themselves. Play it, and you won't regret it.

I only have good things to say about this franchise. Gameplay is awesome. There are usually several ways of doing something or proceeding through an area: kill, distract or evade. I personally like to kill everyone, but I quickly understood that that's not the correct way of doing things. Some people are not entirely bad (up to debate) and you can't kill them, or you'll get bad karma, which will affect your ending. But you can knock them out cold, so that's fun too.
There are a ton of weapons and upgrades, some that'll turn your weapons into precise killing tools. Perfect to test on the wasteland-roaming mutants.
You'll fall in love with the characters, and feel the emotional rollercoaster of their trip.
It is an amazing game.

This is a very painful review to type.

Metro 2033 and Metro Last Light are among the top 5 best games I played in my life so far. I liked them so much, that I got every achievement in both games, just to show off, and the experience was surprisingly rewarding in the process. Anyway, this is just to say that this bad review is not just about general or unjustified hate.

I had to wait a whole year to play the game because my graphics card was bellow the minimum requirements at the time. So, if I ever tried to play it (even at bare minimum set up), I'd get 15 fps. This was the first bad sign. I knew that I would not be able to run the game at ultra or anything "high end" graphics wise, but I'd expect to be able to run it at least with bad graphics. Anyway, I upgraded my graphic cards and the game finally opens!

The open game world they tried to make just sucks. It is a good story (I've read the books), but it did not work so well in the game. I admit that the graphics look very good, but that's it. Everything seems so generic: the locations, omg some of the new monsters just do not make sense in the Metro world. The workbench, that can produce ammo out of anything, this also does not make sense.  In previous metro games, we had choices that would costs us very much. In this one, I can roam freely and see just a few monsters, run and reach my objective. I am at my frist playthrough, at the highest difficulty available, and I feel no challenge.

I will continue to play expecting a "generic good" experience, but far from the Metro experience I had in the past. Again, it pains me to write this.

Since I was not already expecting much, I decided to switch to easy to test all maps. I am currently at the sand/Mad Max one, so called Caspian. What was already too bad gets even worse: it looks literally like Mad Max map and with mad max features: scraps and etc (now I see where they got this from). Mad Max is a great game, played it until the end. But this is Metro, it did not blend in well. The story gets even shittier. When Artyom finds Anna, no emotions, nothing. When he finds a picture of the mother of the lighthouse lady, also nothing. In previous games, the story is filled with emotions. Finding the maps of D6 was very creepy in Metro 2033, even in easy. Finding the damn maps to whatever the fook, only spiders. No badass cutscenes. Previous metro games had so badass cutscenes!

Damn the last level, Dead City!!! So good. That last level is what metro actually shouldve been the whole game. The end was nice, all things considered.

Metro 2035 is damn near my favorite Atmospheric FPS serie ever. This time they tried the "OPEN WORLD" formula but did they succeed ?

[b][u]Like always in Metro games[/u][/b]:

[b]• Absolute killer visual work[/b], many said this is one of the only game pulling an unreal engine 5 type of performance on Unreal 4, and they arent lying! Maxed out; the lights, particules, smoke and so on, are really, really well done. And all of that with excellent performance on a good PC. (RTX3070ti / i5 12600k 4.2ghz / pcie4 SSD / 4x8gb DDR4 3200mhz)

[b]• Unmissable look, identity[/b], Metro keeps its truely unique aesthetic with litteral tons of attention to details. Recharging the flashlight to make it brighter, pumping my tikhar rifle to send those pellets at deadly speed, wiping the gas mask, patching it with a piece of cloth in an emergency, GOD I SWEAR I LOVE THESE LITTLE QUIRKS AND FUNKY MECHANICS SO MUCH !!!

[b]• The sound design is god tier[/b], every sound is near perfect, satisfying, makes sense. Don't care much about music but the SFX ? Omg, great stuff !

[b]• Immersion, ambiance, vibe[/b] are top notch.


[b][u]But what about the transition to open world ? Well, I'd consider that a mild success only[/u][/b].

[b]• The games starts real well[/b] , the 2nd act in the sandy desert feels weird in the serie's context but that's what they were going for. The game picks back up after that, but the middle part of the game feels a bit out of place for what you'd imagine a metro game to be like.

[b]• Points of interest feel a bit too scattered and disjointed[/b], specially in the caspian sea level.

[b]• We definitely lost this anxious feeling of will I have enough gas mask filters to survive?[/b]  Even on a blind hardcore difficulty 1st playthrough!

[b]• [/b] Overall, exiting the metro to get back up to the surface was one of the best aspects we lost with this open world formula. 


[b]In the end, excellent game like fery few can muster[/b] but you're left with the impression that they missed the boat on what they could have done. An ideal open world Metro game should take place in a big moscow like city, with more explorable devastated buildings, landmarks, covered in that eternal snow, less sun, less desert. I know to make a game as visually polished as this one, you have to respect certain limitations but I just wish they'd stick more to the original look of the first 2 games.


[b][u]DLC's[/u][/b]:

• [b][u]TWO COLONELS[/u][/b] campaign : [b]7/10[/b]. 
Starts fantastic with a real moody underground clean up with your flamethrower, then a way too long narrative sequence kills the rythm, I wish the entire dlc campaign was more about burning everything in dark gloomy underground tunnels but no, they tried the typical "learn more about the main plot through someone else POV's" of which I don't really care much. Just let us burn more stuff next time ok ? ;p 

• [b][u]SAM's STORY[/u][/b]  campaign : [b]9/10[/b].
 Really good all throughout, less story focused, more exploration based. Perfect DLC campaign to me !

This game (or the whole Metro series) is a story for both Ukrainians and Russians, a revelation for all people who have lived in a post-Communism state. As the real world goes so disappointing, the story has become more cherish-able than ever.

It provides a reflective, but sober view on what heritage from the Soviet Union shall be kept. The ecosystem of Metro, both in Moscow and Novosibirsk, in the story, was built on fables. Many people, like two colonels, believes such fables are for goodwill, while those who benefits the most from it don't. This is a metaphor to how Soviet Union told their people about the oppression from the Western states- many people, till today, still believe those propaganda are for good.

However, another part of the Soviet Union's heritage was kept. All the rangers are dressed in Telnyashka, an iconic uniform for Soviet airborne troops. "If not us then who" has appeared repetitively in the character's dialogue-which is the motto of Soviet airborne troops. In the game, loyalty, bravery, resilience- those qualities on the icon of a paratrooper (or any good soldier) shall be restored, no matter what ideology it comes from. 

The Eastbound train was named "Aurora", which was the name of the Cruiser which fired at the Winter Palace in October revolution in 1917. This symbolizes rebelliousness against tyranny, as well as equality practiced by the Spartans in the story.

Also, each chapter is actually a metaphor towards some specific doctrines or interest groups that are active in the post-soviet age. This is different from the two former games, in which main forces stick with a broader, more general doctrine: Stalinism, Nazism, and Laissez-faire capitalism (or mercantilism). For example, the "Baron" in the Aral sea correspond to Oil oligarchs that are active in Russia and Central Asia. The cult group in Volga is also a metaphor of the rapid revival of religion in Russia in 1990s. The reflective, holistic view to the game is extremely interesting and inspirational.

In all, this is probably one of the best RPG games I've ever known, except some bugs in the last chapter in Novosibirsk. 10/10

At the heart of Metro Exodus lies fundamentally a very human story. I could recapitulate how the visuals on display here are breathtaking. How the gameplay immersive and captivating. How the gunplay visceral, solid and ultimately satisfying. But I'd be wasting my precious time. And yours because you know this already.

No, what sets it apart is its soul. Something humanity only has ever and ever fading glimmers of, the more we venture into the dark forest that is the 21st century. Exodus is unapologetic in its sincerity in a world irrevocably poisoned by post-irony in which sincerity itself has long since become a commodity.

It's ironic then that humanity has indeed lost its humanity, and I am thoroughly convinced now that mass extinction here would be a mercy.

Yet in all this disgusting, disheartening mess there are beacons of hope such as this is. Metro Exodus despite all odds is profoundly lyrical and cautiously optimistic. Unlike the first game which is pure doomer fuel. Whilst its sequel regressing into self parody. The third game of the series grabs you by the shoulders, looks you in the eye and smiles right at you with openness that only a child is capable of. It smiles through pain, through bruises, scars and torn off flesh. In an act of mischievous rebellion conquering fate.

The essence of Metro Exodus is not in the spectacular set pieces, in the majestic vistas or in its impeccably written story. It's the moments of unmistakable humanity that permeate wholly throughout. This is what elevates an already great game into a one of a kind one. A legend.

A single song echoed by two acoustic guitars is worth a countless number of desperate assaults on a nuclear submarine. It made me cry, not just shed a tear. I often forget that I'm human and moments like these, sadly fewer and fewer and farther between, remind me of that despite all this, whatever this is supposed to be, may it all burn in the brightest of flames.

With all that being said, would I recommend it? You tell me. Do you think you're still human, or are you merely in touch?

So finally after getting the aurora edition when it released , sadly as epic store exclusive, never finished the game on there, because my hardware was simply not up to snuff back then. 

But now after years of backlogging the game and as a massive fan of the all three novels from Mr. Glukhovsky, especially the second one and the last light game aswell I managed to play through the entire game, the enhanced edition I might add. And because the EE doesn't have a separate steam store page I had to download another 80 gb of data and play the game for a 15 minutes so I could at least leave a review.

Where to start? I guess I'll start with the original games, The metro 2033 holds a special place in my heart, because I was in college when it released and I remember quite vividly how insanely unoptimized it was back then and how much of a power hog it was. Basically no machine could run it even at stable 30 fps. But after a year or two it was possible to play it and it was a blast. Shame that they remade the game in the last light engine along with some other major tweaks which ruined the game for me, but hey at least we can still enjoy the original, if you bought it on steam you still have it in your library. The sequel, last light is quite possibly the best metro game to date, even after i played through exodus. It's simply unbeatable in terms of raw atmoshphere, the gameplay, gunplay and I dare to say even the graphics look much better in last light that they do with exodus. But let me get back to that.

Metro exodus is a somewhat controversial game, its still a metro game, but it lost it's splendor and the atmoshpere when transitioning into a semi open world game where you have a free choice to explore the various environments and there are quite a few in metro exodus. Somehow I did not like neither of them, the best of them, the cannibal tunnels was just a short action flick where you couldn't basically explore anything. The moscow level was too short, but the other maps, like the sandmap or the taiga level were incredibly boring for me. I did like the story behind the taiga level, the three factions that were basically playing like kids, the pirates, the forest hunters and the bandits. I loved the backstory and it was interesting to listen to their conversations. That part of the game was a definite high point of the game. Unfortunately there is where the fun stops. The gameplay, tedious long boring animations, uninteresting unskippable conversations,, amateur dubbing in english, absolutely terrible...was a low point for me. The gun play still holds quite good, even though the game is much more action oriented than its both predecessors. The stealth is also and option but it's boring this time, simply because of the map and environment design. I hated the part where i had to use the car to explore the desert area. It was tedious and boring for me. I did not like the enemy and monster designs aswell. They were too generic, less detailed than in last light, especially the monsters. It seems to me like this part of the game was rushed by the developer. The change of the engine was imo not a good choice either. Even now with i9 13900k and rtx 4090 there are noticeable framedrops at everything maxed out at almost all the levels, especially the winter one and the taiga one. The game doesn't look that hot either. I even dare to say metro last light looks, plays and has much more atmosphere, it's in abundance there. In exodus it's missing.

Overall I enjoyed it, the story dlcs were surprisingly fantastic, short, but sweet. They added so much to the main story.
I liked the game, even though it's most definitely not he best metro game out there, it's a solid entry though. For me the book aswell as the game is the worst out of the entire trilogy.

The main reason for the negative review are the frequent crashes, especially when you attempt higher difficulty levels. A few too many particles or certain objects in the frame and the game just crashes on a loop. One example was a terminal I had to interact with. A dozen crashes in a row until I managed to get past it after loading the game in safe mode in 720p. Many negative reviews focus on the same problem, so I know I am not alone and this should not be acceptable from a high profile developer.

Other than that, the game is a bit of a hit and miss. There's a lot of beautiful stuff, but the gameplay is kinda boring and the story predictable and dull. Developers tried to take the storytelling off the rails (pun intended) and let you explore an open world, but didn't know how to make the open world interesting. There is technically stuff to explore, but you should really just head towards the main objective. Most of the places you can visit are reserved for a future objective and feel broken and empty until it's triggered. Plan to mop up the stuff you missed as you prepare to leave for the next map, not the other way around.

I think the writing is one of the things that put me off the most. The main character doesn't speak, but constantly interacts with people who deliver forced exposition via long, cheesy and unnatural monologues. You can tell the writer is the sort of person who really likes listening to their own voice.

I think the DLCs are actually where the game was most fun. They are shorter experiences that are more linear and have much better pacing.

Exodus is a great looking game that somehow bungles the gameplay.  In the intro you crawl down into the metro once again and the claustrophobic tension immediately comes rushing back.  A distant clatter of a tin can sends you swirling around looking for what made the noise.  Every hole is suspect, every opening an avenue of attack.  It's exhilarating.

Then for some reason you leave all that behind to go ride a train around brightly lit Russia and slowly row boats around a river.  Tense underground engagements are traded in for well above ground walks in the park.  In previous games, going above ground was filled with dangerous beasties stampeding down empty streets, or swooping in from overhead to carry you away if you so much as dared to stand under the sun.   However, now you can mostly run past the odd group of two or three mutants since the levels don't force any engagements on you.  The tension of being forced to go outside your comfort zone to seek filters has been replaced with breathable air.  The changes from previous games are numerous and for the worse.

It's a shame really, 2033 and Last Light are masterpieces in the fps genre.  If you've never played a metro game, you may have fun with this one.  But if you're coming off of that last stand from Last Light and jumping straight into this then you're out of luck friendo, this ain't the continuation you were hoping for.

The Bottom Line: A fun romp through USSR locales, though neither the story nor gameplay is anything truly groundbreaking. 

Firstly, a note for capital-G gamers. Swallow your pride. Setting the difficulty higher than “Normal” in this game turns it into something of a trying slog. On difficulties where quicksave/quickload is unavailable, some sections may feel utterly trying. Play through without the handicap first, then see if you want to re-experience the gameplay loop with more unforgiving fundamental laws of gameplay-physics.

On non-masochistic difficulties, the game is a blend of stealth-action and guns-blazing-action. You shoot a lot of dudes, and a lot of mutants. There is an element of resource management in that you need to make sure that you have enough filters for your gas mask to survive whatever time you need to spend in hazardous environments, and don’t run out of ammo and healing supplies while you’re at it. 

As a side thing/progression element, you [i]will[/i] accumulate various weapon attachments and weapon variants over the course of your unceasing murderization of the aforementioned lots of dudes. These make the prospect of getting through yet another gunfight at least a little bit more interesting than the base level of fun inherent in capping heads.

Not to say that the head-capping is bad; on the contrary, it’s rather nice gunplay once you’ve got your weapons set up the way you like them. Since ammo is a precious resource, headshots are encouraged, moreso the closer you get to the NG+ Ranger Hardcore masochism singularity. The guns sound and feel good. I definitely smiled once I realized that a significant chunk of the game featured a crossbow. Once you kill or subdue a majority of the dudes in a given place, the rest will throw up their arms in surrender, which feels badass.

The main things, gameplay-wise, that ground my gears were the segments where the game threw frustrating mutants at the player character, and the segments where non-lethal stealth was presented as “the ideal option.” Most of the monster-fighting is perfectly fine, but there is, effectively, a “mini-boss” in one of the later chapters that felt like utter horse hockey to fight, each time he showed up. I was also seemingly too stupid to realize that the monster-fighting in the last chapter could be avoided, and so was likewise frustrated by it then.

As for non-lethal stealth… Okay, so, the post-apocalyptic Union of Soviet Socialist Republics isn’t exactly teeming with magic sleep darts à la Dishonoured. If a guy needs to go to sleep, but not permanently, the only way to make that happen is to sneak up to that guy and press E (for “go to sleEp.”) You are told at several points in the game that a certain group of Armed Dudes What Shoot You are not actually [i]that bad,[/i] but just misled, and that you should not kill them during some mission or another. Choosing this “high road” entails disengaging from the fun gun-shooty gameplay and becoming the Thing What Hugs Heads In The Night. This is bad, I do not like it.

Lastly, this is sort of a take-it-as-it-is thing: This game is heavy on scripted sequences and cutscenes. They’re fine. It’s the philosophy the devs took to designing the game. Some of the sequences are quite okay. Some drag on. How you feel about them depends on your opinion of the overall story.

My first playthrough was with Russian VO and Russian subtitles, so I can’t speak to the English performances or any changes made in localization. The performances are fantastic, but the story overall is almost entirely paint-by-numbers. If you can’t see the obvious twist coming… well, maybe you need a remedial education in plot. The characters didn’t feel all that interesting to me, with the Colonel and Anya especially feeling like cardboard-cutouts. That the protagonist is silent makes little sense especially in the multiple segments where it would really make sense for him to radio in to Home Base. Maybe really immersing myself in literally all of the dialogue that is on offer might have changed my opinion on these issues, but I don’t know. The moment-to-moment writing is good, but the plot and character arcs overall feel meh.

That said, the mediocre plot rides through some truly excellent settings, which might be worth seeing by themselves. The Volga chapter starts strong with the cult of the Tsar-Fish, and it only gets better from there. Exodus goes to the zagranitsa of the Moscow Metro and it’s beautiful out there, which honestly made me a little sad whenever I had to go back underground.

In any case: I don’t regret spending my time with this game, though I wish the writers were a little braver in putting together the plot, and the designers went a bit lighter on the scripted sequences. I’ve started a Ranger Hardcore NG+ playthrough and may or may not report back once I’m done with that.

The third entry in the Metro Trilogy (all played on hardcore): SPOILER WARNING

The developers spent a lot of time making the game as graphically pleasing as it can be. However, this means only users with mid to top-tier hardware can run the game and enjoy the intended graphic fidelity. Still, the game suffers from poorly implemented HDR, which results in obvious "washed out" colors, particularly black, which is important for an environment that is to be bleak, dreary, and dark. Four years later, the developers have not fixed this.

The graphics are perhaps the only thing to have improved compared to Exodus's predecessors. The gunplay feels weak and fake. Guns don't feel like they do any damage, except the .44 mag pistol. OG 2033 felt like guns had weight and did something against mutant and humans alike. The weapon customization is linear and boring, meaning new upgrades are simply upgrades with little to no drawbacks instead of players carefully choosing what to sacrifice and what to install. The player is forced to carry around a Tikhar the whole game (a pressurized pellet gun) which is frankly OP but boring to use.

The crafting system is also weak: the ability to make bullets, gas mask filters, and med-kits out of scrap metal and glowing mushrooms is laughable. No longer are military grade bullets a form of currency anymore, nope, its just scrap metal and mushrooms that are important. 

The combat AI from other humans is predictable and boring as well. Every human AI acts the same, no matter the enemy. This has been the case since Last Light Redux. OG 2033 human combat AI is relatively good. At least mutants are still fun to fight as bad AI is excused by animalistic behavior. 

Stealth is easily a downgrade from OG 2033, where there were varying levels of light. In 2033, full light meant you are going to be spotted, spotty light meant you are somewhat safe but need to get in cover soon, and no light at all meant you are safe from human AI. In Exodus, you can sneak past enemies in full ambient light and make all the noise in the world and no one will notice. This was carried over from Last Light Redux. Oh yeah, remember the HDR problem? Well, the white-washed darkness makes stealth really underwhelming. 

The main story and side stories are also weak and predictable with over-used cliches from modern entertainment. Unlike the first installment, 2033, the characters and factions you meet are either good or bad, and they all fit into a particular niche which makes the individuals predictable and uninteresting. For example, in the Caspian Sea area, the area is ruled by the oil barons who were around before the war. They and their cronies have enslaved the native population and indoctrinated them with a religion to make them subservient. Therefore, the player feels no empathy at all for the oil barons or any of the cronies, but must feel bad for the native population. It is terribly black and white AND boring. Contrast 2033, the player meets the Bolsheviks and the Fascist factions in the tunnels. The player is exposed to dialogue shared among the common soldiers that gives a glimpse of understanding into their worlds and how they believe what must be done to keep their families safe from radiation, mutants, and fellow humans. 

It can hardly be called a Metro game as very little of the game is spent in the Metro. In fact, only one level felt like I was playing a Metro game (Yamantau).

The player is forced into obviously moral choices, which makes stealth and refrain from killing (at least the "neutral" or "good" guys) the intended gameplay. At the end, I got so tired of trying to play in character and how the game wants me to play, I just started gunning down most NPCs. Honestly, it was the most fun I had in this game. 

They could have gone all out with the NATO/American occupation and it would have been a much better storyline. Imagine sneaking through enemy lines and outposts, trying to find the besieged Russian government. The whole game would have been suspenseful, where any of your comrades could easily die with one mistake. Instead, you run into a bunch of niche groups: cultists, enslaved natives, bandits, summer campers with their own factions (lmao what even), oil barons, and an endless horde of cannibals (seriously how many cannibals can there be if they ran out of food years ago?) all the while trying to cure your sick girlfirend. *Snore*

I would not recommend this game, especially not for the $30 price tag (which I did not pay). If interested still, I would recommend you watch some form of a "Let's Play" on Youtube and save your time and money.

TL;DR: A brilliant addition to the Metro franchise, which is unfortunately bogged down by the most awful rendition of a morality system that the series has seen yet. Still, Exodus is probably the most fun that post-apocalyptic Russia has ever been. 

...

On the surface, Metro is pretty -- sure. But for most of the game, that beauty hides expertly crafted open-world zones, which are a delight to explore. The game is also a surprise heavy-hitter in terms of its plot, which felt authentic when compared to the vibe of the novels. The title strays from the books' general direction, but the world feels like it has been crafted by huge Glukhovsky fans.

This also translates to a smooth gameplay experience. There are minor hiccups here and there, then some nonsensical glitches, which are fairly easy to step in to, but nothing game-breaking. The core of the loop remains fun and enjoyable almost until the very end. 

But this entry in the franchise has one big issue: the morality system. I'll provide a quick example: throughout my playthrough, I enjoyed all the outcomes that I witnessed. The events felt truthful to the characters they featured and impactful to the plot. Moreover, they felt world-changing, which is typically the mark of a solid plot. Yet, in the end, I was punished with a bad ending that did not feel deserved. 

The morality system in this series has always been its biggest flaw, but in Exodus it hits a pinnacle so high that it almost ruins the entire experience. The choices the player is expected to make in order to receive the good ending are extremely subjective and way too political in nature for it to make any sort of narrative sense. 

But it is hard to lie -- the game was a blast to play. If you can close your eyes for the morality system and just accept the game as a fun and emotional ride, you'll likely enjoy your third visit to Artyom's world. Then, just watch the Good Ending on YouTube and craft a proper headcanon.

At its core, Metro Exodus is still the same type of game as its predecessors, [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/286690/Metro_2033_Redux]Metro 2033[/url][/i] and [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/287390/Metro_Last_Light_Redux]Metro Last Light[/url][/i]. It's a [b]first-person-shooter of the 'tactical' FPS type[/b]. Meaning: It doesn't take a lot of bullets to take you down, so every fight is risky and intense (and sometimes frustrating, admittedly).

However, the Metro series has always stood out amongst shooters by [b]taking this (relatively) believable approach to gunfights and applying it to lots of other aspects[/b] of the game as well: Fight with your gas mask on and it might take damage, leaving you to suffocate. Fail to clean your weapons after exposing them to grime and water and they will end up becoming less reliable. Taking out your map or looking at your inventory will cause you to put away your gun but it won't stop time, leaving you highly vulnerable. Take out your zippo lighter and you'll only be able to shoot using one arm, decreasing accuracy dramatically. And so on and so forth...

All of these little details create an [b]underlying layer of game mechanics that serve to immerse you deeply into the game world[/b]. Metro Exodus thus becomes a highly detailed tactical shooter without ever losing itself in survival game elements – or evolving into a full-fledged immersive sim for that matter. Unfortunately, Metro Exodus also retains some of the more annoying aspects of the series, such as [b]long scripted sequences in the middle of gameplay[/b]. If you're looking for a fast-paced arena FPS, this clearly is not the game for you.

At this point, returning Metro players might wonder: How exactly does Metro Exodus differ from the other games in the series, then? Well, Metro Exodus is the series' first foray into [b]open-world-ish game design[/b]. I'm calling this 'open-world-ISH' because this game is actually a linear sequence of multiple medium-sized open-world maps and some straight-forward corridor shooting interspersed between them. Most importantly, though, the design of the open-world areas is [b]far beyond what people have come to expect from 'open-world' games[/b] made by the likes of Ubisoft: Metro Exodus' maps are detailed and intricate, with lots of unique areas to explore. So instead of working through repetitive side-missions along the lines of "take out this enemy base... and this one as well", you'll find yourself immersed in the world, plotting out your path through an area, making sure to avoid known dangers. And you'll do it simply because you'll be thinking: "I wonder what's over there..."

Finally, a few (spoiler-free) words about the plot: I feel that in recent years (or maybe decades), there has been a distinct lack of games that make you feel like you're actually on an adventure – a journey into the unknown, never knowing what might happen along the way. Metro Exodus does not follow this trend and [b]I thoroughly enjoyed every aspect of the 'road trip' adventure story[/b] the game offers. Yes, even the [b]often drawn-out and sometimes kinda clunky dialogue sequences[/b]. And I enjoyed the cast, which [b]lends the plot an amount of humanity which you'll not find in many other shooters[/b]. I found myself rooting for these characters, worrying for their well-being and even genuinely getting close to tears at one point. And that's more than most recent shooters have managed to get out of me.

As a fan of 2033 and Last Light, I was deeply disappointed by Metro Exodus. The shift towards open-world and non-linear levels felt out of place in the series, taking away the intense atmosphere and the thrill of navigating through dark tunnels. The side quests turned out to be boring and repetitive. Even though elements like scarce resources and stealth options remained, the decision to allow enemies to one-hit you, including through melee attacks and broken auto saves felt frustrating and diminished the overall enjoyment.  "The Two Colonels" DLC, was the only positive aspect i took away.

I strongly recommend you buy something else.

To put it simply, this is a good game (exceptional environment with horror built into the environment and a great story), but there's a reason why I think it was so good for me...
A lot of people HATE being forced into stealth, however when building a horror game you want the feeling that you're always the prey, so use a higher difficulty trust me.

A higher difficulty allows you to use force, but simply limits the ammo you get. This may sound small, but most engagements will be running away from the enemy or trying to conserve ammo by hitting head shots in an place where you want to spam bullets so you don't die. It works SO well to remind you that you're really not invincible even though you can still pack a punch. It sounds like an annoying mechanic, but it simply isn't.

So instead of being forced into stealth, you get to choose to be stealthy (at least until you get discovered). This only helps you in the long run and it can actually be nice motivation to do stealth which really helps in the horror aspect.

*Spoilers*
1 negative. There is this device which allows you to track surrounding enemies, I used it, but it kind of ruins the game. I know when any jumpscare or ambush is going to take place. So I can look around the eerie world and be like "Is a dragon going to kill me?", but look on my scanner and see there's nothing there so it boosts my confidence. In my opinion, this needs to be nerfed or removed, but it won't be since this game was made eons ago. Also a few bugs, but being stuck inside a shelf with giant gorillas running around or a leach clipping inside your boat until you're at the bottom of the lake only adds to horror so fair play.

I don't like it, and I think that's because of mismatched expectations. I was expecting an open-world version of the first Metro, which I liked. I was hoping for something closer to the Stalker series. Instead, I ended up with too much of a cinematic experience? I think that's the best way to put it. I've only played the first few hours, but it feels like I don't really have a lot of control over the experience, like I'm a passenger. Control is taken away from the character too often and it leaves me just sitting there watching something happen through someone else's eyes. This even happens in combat. It ruins the immersion. It actually happens so frequently it started giving me motion sickness.

The "open world" part of it actually just feels like a reeeeally wide hallway where there is no reason to wander and with a world that does not change in response to your actions. There's no decisions to be made, and no way to feel like you're actually interacting with a living world. It just feels like a big pile of set pieces. Even the monsters feel fake, like they're all just popping up out of the ground because it's "time to fight an enemy".

I don't like it. I can see that there are people that disagree, and I can understand why some people might like it, but not me. It's not for me. I'm going to go back to looking for the next Stalker.

Metro Exodus is caught between the excellent older games and the desire to modernize the series and is much less compelling as a result. I can clearly see how the developers wanted to incorporate the structure of 2033 and last light while doing something new... but the failure to commit to either has produced a lesser game. I think the best example is the continuation of Artyom as a silent protagonist with Metro Exodus (an unpopular opinion I imagine). It worked well in the previous games because you largely met people in passing, but it's just forced in a much more noticeable way with the story of Metro Exodus. Groups are much more diverse and the story feels like there should be a lot more choice involved, instead your two options are to slaughter everyone or sneak past. Your crew too, feel more like NPC's without any method of two-way communication which undermines the genuinely awesome work put into humanizing the characters in between areas. Other minor decisions with location, combat (the AI is noticeably bad for a 2019 release), and the story itself just strips away what makes a Metro game a Metro game for me.

**Do not select Ranger Hardcore Full Dive, it strips away all UI, including ammo count and important prompts. You will be spamming buttons to try and operate a radio while Miller is yelling at you to hurry up and there's not way to turn it off once you start a game**

Summary: I like it, and I got the game at a very good discount. The game is beautiful, fun and challenging. I'm not a big fan of horror elements but I loved them in this game. Overall, buy it, play it and enjoy it. The pros and cons will explore some spoiler territory, so continue with caution. I have added a lot to my cons, because I'm good at complaining. 

Pros:
-Super immersive, one of the few games where I felt connected with the world and wanted to explore all elements of the map. At a certain point your knowledge of the map can come into play and use it against the enemies, especially if you understand patrol patterns and mutant behaviors. 
-Shooting. Its a lot fun to shoot shit.
-Sound design, the element that sold the immersive experience of the game.
-As someone who played the original 2033 and Last Light, I think this would be fitting ending for Artyom's story in my opinion especially with my ending. 

Cons:
-The maps feel like when you are writing on a white board and after a while your text is smaller than it was at the start. The game is broken into several sections that have a dedicated map to each of them. The issue comes from the fact that the first 2 maps (there was another section between those maps but it was a short section) are open and free to explore. The first map is amazing to explore and learn about. Perhaps the most immersive experience in the entire game. The second map is as detailed but spread out from each other a bit more. The first 2 maps are great fun but it's the last 2 that feel like it became a more linear experience much more reminiscent of the other metro games. I don't like that, it messes up the cohesiveness of the gameplay and it feels like they could have been more than what they are. Especially the last map has us returning to a metro system, which I wish we could have explored more of. The hospital section was also sort of dreadful, but that made some narrative sense because it's one building. 2/3 of the game is great but I think the last part was not as great or memorable.
-Story, there were several moments where you are not surprised that this event occurred. Especially, when you encountered the trap in the mountains like it was so obvious! The story has moments of frustration and also moments where I wish we could have explored more of. 
We had Damir, Duke, Alyoshka (I don't know how to spell his name) and Katya who played some role in each of the maps. I wished we had a side-quest with them pretaining to their character in each map or a companion section similar to the communist friend we made in Last Light. I wished we could have more of them. 
I wished we had a section where we explored our new home near Baikal.
-New game plus is a buggy mess especially if you want to play with your weapons you had in the previous playthrough. Really frustrating trying to get it to work. Plus, I started a NG+ and I lost all of my gear now so no going back.
Outstanding game! Outstanding story! 10/10. Metro Series is one of my all time favorites. Wish the books were like them...

Got it on a sale. Good story and the game play is satisfactory. I feel this is what Fallout 4 should have been like. 

Pros
- You scavenge most upgrades from your fallen enemies. If you have the upgrade already, you get resources instead. This was a welcome change than having an inventory just fill up with the same guns just having different mods attached. 
- The story. A lot of the story was interactive rather than just cut scenes. Whilst concise, it can be somewhat tedious at times (some scenes go on to long) some can be skipped. I found it to be a nice change from the usual pushing-you-to-become-the-next-god/boss
- The levels. Whilst large enough that you can go off track and explore, they are small enough to push the game along so you don't get bogged down looking through the same building all the time.

Cons
- As mentioned before, you scavenge most of your upgrades from fallen foes. Problem is, if you miss an upgrade on any one particular map, chances are you missed it for good. ***spoilers*** At one point you can lose some of your coveted upgrades (permanently) due to the story if you aren't aware (and if only found in one area, for good). 
- Gameplay feels a little too linear at times. Some Mods and Gear can be hard to find if they aren't made unmissable. Replayability doesn't feel particularly high on the list. You may get 2 rounds (first time through, then on new game+) before you shelve it.

Would be keen to see the next title in the series to build into a much larger map akin to the Fallout Series but keeping the rich storytelling.

Metro Exodus is a good game in terms of gameplay, atmosphere, sound design, voice acting, and almost every facet of what makes a game good, except for the endings and the fact that the main character is still, agonizingly, silent. I would recommend Metro Exodus to fans of Metro games and FPS games in general. 

The good:

The Metro series has always been about crafting an excellent atmosphere. They do a great job of selling the world and up until Exodus, have stuck mostly to the same settings of Moscow, its metros, and a few locations in-between. Exodus brings the world building to a wide variety of new locations, really breaking the mold of the previous two games and manages to keep the same high quality world building and sells you on the continuity of its setting. 

Crafting and equipment management is really good and drives the experience. Inventory management has been important in Metro games, and the ability to craft really opens up the inventory management to a new level. Unprecedented weapon and gear customization options drive the feeling to satisfying management. 

The cast of characters are well voice acted and the graphics are great. Sound design it top quality. 

Missions are generally interesting and well written. I was never bored, and the relaxing breaks in-between major chapters were nice and welcome. I enjoyed the characters. 

The bad:

There is almost no incentive to fight any of the monsters, because they don’t drop crafting materials or loot and you generally use more resources than are returned. It makes coming across them a pain in the open world sequences, and you mostly just sneak around them. 

Without spoiling anything, the “good” and “bad” ending situation is lame. You get the “good” ending by not killing any “innocent” people (even though they try and kill you and the game labels them as enemies). This is never explained to you, and the endings literally have nothing to do with the innocent people you have spared. According to some research, getting the “good ending” requires you to follow some strict guidelines and is hard. I find this to be annoying. I feel like I was robbed of a more satisfying ending because I didn’t read spoilers ahead of time and just played the game how I wanted. 

As I mentioned before, having Artyom remain a silent protagonist is excruciating. He meets many characters during his journey, and they have whole one-sided conversations with him. Spilling their guts and most intimate details of their lives to someone who just says nothing and will randomly leave. The supposed love of your life, Anna, talks to you for long stretches of time without a response. Your comrades will be desperately trying to hail you on the radio, but you never answer. It is just awkward at this point. 

All in all, Metro Exodus was great and brought the Metro series to a whole new level. I would recommend this game for sure.

Metro Exodus takes players on an extraordinary post-apocalyptic adventure, delivering a truly fantastic and emotionally touching story. With its outstanding dialogue and unique combat mechanics, this game stands as a testament to immersive storytelling, making it an absolute must-play for gamers seeking a memorable experience.

Set in a world devastated by nuclear war, Metro Exodus follows the compelling journey of Artyom, a protagonist on a quest for a new home beyond the confines of the Moscow Metro. The game's storyline is a masterpiece, blending suspense, mystery, and a profound exploration of the human spirit. It immerses players in a harrowing and desolate landscape, yet manages to evoke a range of emotions, from hope to despair, as you accompany Artyom through his trials and triumphs.

What sets Metro Exodus apart is its ability to touch players on a deeply emotional level. The game's characters are vividly brought to life, each with their own struggles, dreams, and flaws. You'll form genuine connections with these individuals, sharing in their joys and sorrows. The game's remarkable visuals and haunting soundtrack work in harmony to enhance the emotional impact, creating a truly immersive and cinematic experience.

The dialogue in Metro Exodus is nothing short of outstanding. It is meticulously crafted, breathing life into the game's world and its inhabitants. The writing is rich and nuanced, capturing the essence of each character and the unique perspectives they bring. Engaging in conversations with companions or encountering strangers in the wasteland feels organic and meaningful, adding depth and complexity to the overall narrative.

While the combat mechanics in Metro Exodus may differ from traditional shooters, they offer a refreshing and challenging experience. Survival and resource management play a crucial role, as stealth and strategic thinking become essential for success. Adapting to these mechanics might pose a slight difficulty curve, but the payoff is immense. Engaging in intense firefights and facing off against hostile creatures and factions becomes deeply rewarding and exhilarating.

In conclusion, Metro Exodus delivers a captivating and unforgettable journey through its fantastic story, touching moments, outstanding dialogue, and unique combat mechanics. Despite the initial learning curve for combat, this game is a must-play for anyone seeking an immersive and thought-provoking gaming experience. Prepare to be swept away by the haunting beauty and emotional depth of Metro Exodus.

For as much as I do want to recommend this game to others as a very fresh take in the Metro franchise, I can't do it with a good heart because of all of the technical issues I encountered in my time playing it. I think about 1/4th of my playtime was troubleshooting the issues I ran into which had some of the most maddening and odd fixes to them. I encountered: 

A bug at the mid part of The Caspian Sea when you exit the cave and have to reach the lighthouse by the boat. For some reason, crossing the boat would lock up my game. The only way I fixed it was by forcing the game into "Safe Mode", looking down at the ground when exiting the cave and walking forward hugging the right side. The hitrate isn't 100% (I think it took 3-4 tries before I got it right) but I got pass it after a lot of headache.

A bug at the end of The Caspian Sea where the level transition would crash my game. I noticed some missing dialogue at the final cutscene for that part and knew my most recent auto saves were corrupted by [spoiler] enemies not spawning in to the kill room and my ally just being gone [/spoiler] so I had to go back to my most recent auto save [i] 3 hours back [/i] Also... One manual save slot!? Really?! I honestly expected better. But, I somehow fixed it, which I think I did by [spoiler] entering the temporary hideout after the train ambush in the level [/spoiler] which gave me the final dialogue and made the load trigger not crash my game

And the final bug being in The Two Colonels after the first level where it trying to load the cutscene for the next level would softlock the game. For some insane reason, turning V-Sync on fixed it for me.

Like, don't get me wrong, when the game works, it's fun. The combat is fun (albeit the stealth is the same dumb shit as always), the gun customisation is fun, the story is good and the graphics look as peak as always and run stable in that regard. But I can't recommend it with all these issues. I don't know if I got really unlucky, but still, beware because I doubt too many people have the patience I did troubleshooting all this.

Absolutely love this game!!! 
Just completed for the 2nd time a few moments ago... what an absolute masterpiece!!!
One of the best story driven FPS ever made!!!
Other game developers could learn a thing or ten about game design and depth of lore from this game!!!!!!!
Brilliantly crafted characters, deep emotional story and dialogue, beautiful and dramatic landscapes, a huge, exciting and emotional rollercoaster of a journey, I would recommend to anyone that loves gritty post-apocalyptic adventures!!!

So much detail everywhere, everything feels logical, real life, organic and decayed, wild and desolate, with isolated moments of beauty and tranquillity, so many different biomes the graphics can be outstanding if you catch the sunlight in the right way while crawling out of a dark hole into the world above...
A decent mix of linear and semi-open exploring with scripted action and random encounters, but its the story and world itself here that really excels, the shear amount of detail and lore in this game is incredible, you can sometimes spend hours just exploring the world see what you stumble across, or relax just listening to the stories of the various survivors in your group between each mission, go smoke a cigarette with your friend at the front of the train as it chugs across the land, or discuss the plan with another, it really helps set the stage as your group slowly grows in size!! 
Missions involving team mates actually feel worthwhile, the team plays a genuine part in the mission, covering you, or assisting you with enemy scouting or info on your objectives, You can customise and service you weapon loadout in a ton of different ways to suit your playstyle, stealthy or guns blazing, long range or close quarters,
Choose to kill anything that moves and suffer the judgement and dislike of your group, or go the humanitarian route and try to avoid unnecessary bloodshed...its a really cool game!!!!

A few negatives...
 I got a bit of stuttering as the game autosaves and sometime loads areas, which is a little annoying, I've had two crashes on but who knows whether its the game or my PC..haha
Also some of the initial loading times are inhumane!!!!

Overall a fantastic, in-depth, gritty post-apocalyptic experience with some very minor forgivable quirks, well worth it!!!!

I’ve played last 2 metro series games beginning to end for better or worse they were playable as stealth focused type of game. This game imo is horrendous & frustrating. My key negative feedback are:

1) Enemy AI straight dog sh#t. I would often crunch/stand and just watch enemy NPCs switch weapons right in front of me and then do a several turns before trying to bum rush me. They seem to be stuck on some ‘if’ loops when facing the player in direct combat 

2) stealth mechanics hit & miss - seems to be proximity based and if you have flashlight etc. will trigger. But the game generally presents NO stealth challenge to impossible due NPC density spawn. There’s no middle ground or balance.

3) game design highly pushes player to explore said open world for attachment unlocks etc. but the world is mostly uninteresting, sparse and there’s some issues with player climb detection and ledges/invisible walls like climbing ruins in 2nd map after moscow

4) frustrating game design choices like stripping player of their gear and forcing players to use crossbow towards late game when most of the game had been building your inventory and weapon upgrades seems very counterintuitive, unnecessarily punishing and jarring. This is compounded by fact the crossbow chapter of late game highly de-incentivise player from killing most NPCs so you’re stripped of your weapons and forced to default back to stealth type gameplay in a semi-open world late game (morality/karma system).

5) expect lots of backtracking and retracing your old steps in-game which in modern games is generally mitigated by intuitive level design to minimise loop backs. Not metro exodus though, The devs here says fu & would love for you to backtrack between your shelters and PoIs where you are encouraged to explore but punished by forcing to go back to explored locations.

6) the game takes a overall dull artistic tone fit in-game asset designs. This means there’s often no intuitive way markers or indicators to the player on where to go. This adds to unnecessary backtracking to point above.

Recommend save your hard earned money and play better games in this genre like stalker (older series but better designed game in soviet FPS/stealth/RPG open world type genre) or Wolfenstein series (if run and gun is more your style).

Metro Exodus takes place in a post-apocalyptic Russia, where a devastating nuclear war has left the surface world uninhabitable, and the remaining population lives in the underground metro tunnels. Players assume the role of Artyom, who leads a group of survivors as they embark on a journey to find a new home beyond the metro tunnels.

The game offers a compelling storyline that immerses players in a harsh and unforgiving world filled with danger and despair. The graphics and visuals are stunning, and the attention to detail in creating the world is remarkable. The game's sound design and atmospheric music also add to the overall experience, making it feel more intense and immersive.

The gameplay is a mix of exploration, stealth, and combat, giving players the freedom to choose their approach. The game's open-world design allows players to explore different environments and encounter various hostile factions and mutants, making the game more challenging and engaging. The game's crafting system is also well-implemented, allowing players to scavenge for resources and upgrade their weapons and gear.

One of the game's most significant strengths is its level design, with each area feeling unique and offering different challenges and opportunities. The game's narrative is also well-written, and the voice acting is top-notch, making the characters feel more relatable and adding depth to the story.

In summary, Metro Exodus is a fantastic game that offers a gripping narrative, stunning visuals, immersive sound design, and challenging gameplay. Its open-world design and attention to detail make it a standout title in the post-apocalyptic genre, and its combination of exploration, stealth, and combat make it an engaging and memorable experience. If you enjoy first-person shooters or post-apocalyptic settings, Metro Exodus is definitely worth checking out.

One of the best parts of this game is the story. It manages to be very subtle until it sneaks up on you and show how big the stakes are. It has one of the best endings that I have ever played in a video game that even manages to get emotional. It was unexpected but very welcome to see a shooter with such a heavy emphasis on story. Tied with that are the characters. The game does a good job of getting you invested in the characters which further supports the story. I also appreciated how most of the levels were focused on one of the other rangers in your group, which fleshed people out more. 

The gameplay is also good. I liked the upgrading mechanics and making ammo and materials out of scrap, which was implemented well. On the other hand, I wished the gear upgrades could have been building capability over time not having to pick and choose. The guns are satisfying to use although in most of the levels you are forced to use a certain type of weapon or another which restricts you in what weapons you carry. The sniper rifle was also a really fun weapon but unfortunately there werent too many opportunities to use it well. 

The game is a mixture of open world levels filled in with linear levels. I consider it a bold move but I think it worked well, although there should have been at least one more open world level. It feels short despite it being a well-contained story and game. Being above ground and having an open world made it a lot different than the last two games. I dont have a problem with that but I can understand if that put people off. The graphics and models looked so much nicer than the last two games, even if things like cobwebs looked like a downgrade from the others. Lastly, the game features a point where you lose all your gear and are forced to start over, which is a gaming pet peeve of mine. It was tied to the level unique weapons and it could have been fine without it. 

Overall i'd give this game a 9/10 and strongly suggest you play it if you think this might be for you. You will not regret it.

You know, I've played the Metro games quite a few times. Metro: Last Light is easily one of my favorite games of all time. I loved it so much the first time I played it I played through it 3 times back to back. But this game. I have some issues with.

First off I have to say I do love story, the ending between Artyom dying (or nearly dying) and sadly having to say goodbye to the stubborn badass that is Colonel Miller was truly heartbreaking. Getting the good ending felt good. Finally being able to find a safe place for the people of the Metro to live and live out Anna's dream of finally being able to raise their kids in a safe and clean place. It felt great, personally was very choked up seeing all of Artyom's friends standing by the Resting Place of Miller and realizing that after all of the Metro games and all of the hard work and truly hard times that Artyom has been through, he finally made it. The man has cheated death. At the end of the day, the story felt great. I loved it and personally felt like it was worth the play through.

But with every great game comes with issues. I am not a fan of the "open world" type levels. Yes, I do understand there intention and they do make sense for the story, but I truly don't like it. I always like having levels that were more of Point A to Point B but with actions that provide consequences. It was especially frustrating because they aren't even technically open world. The collectibles prove that. On the winter map Volga I missed a Postcard at the beginning. Which was an area I couldn't go back to because I needed a boat, and the game removed the boat from the area so you can't even go back. So really, it wasn't even "open world" but the idea is good. Just the lack of being able to go back to the areas you were previously was not great, and honestly frustrating. Now I feel obligated to replay these levels to get the postcards I missed. So in summary, I liked the other games level structures better but that doesn't mean that the levels suck. Because I would be a damn liar if I didn't say they weren't beautiful looking. Even in an apocalyptic wasteland, there were a lot of times that I said to myself... wow.

Now, the most frustrating part of this game was combat, the shootouts were fun. The ending to the DLC "Sam's Story" I just ran through and shot everyone but actually liked it and enjoyed the heat of the intense moment. But the thing that always drove me to the Metro games and especially as to why I LOVED Metro: Last Light was the stealth. I don't know why, but stealth is not very good in this game. Some parts it is very difficult because it is outside and day time and you can't find a waiting place. But you make do, and you adapt... but where my main frustration with stealth comes in is this: The Caspian... there is a section where you can infiltrate a Bandit ruled area and eliminate the guards and free the Bandits. You can find a breaker to kill the lights so I did, then I saved. Now it is dark and you can kill the guards stealthily without causing a ruckus. But if I got detected, I would reload my save. But then... the lights are back on. Now I'm already on the other side of the facility and can't go back and turn the lights back off. At one points I tried and when I got over there all the lights on the breaker were Red. Which means they should've been off. That was by far the most frustrating but I have ever seen in a game. I'm also not very supportive of them changing the Stealth Kill button from V to Q which is the same button as the Medkit. Couldn't tell you how many times I ended up healing myself and getting detected then performing an execution. I also don't understand the point of Silencers when I head shot a bloke and the people on the other side of the facility start looking for me when no one even found the body.

I do love the idea with the backpack and the crafting. i like that the gas mask gets damaged and you have to repair. I do like that you have to clean your weapons. But you really shouldn't have to do it nearly as much as you actually do. I'm weapons expert but it seems a little too much. But the system and the idea is good.

Well, I don't really have anything else to say. Metro Exodus was a great game, has a lot of issues to be sure but I would give it a 87/100. The story was amazing good DLC's an okay combat system, poor stealth mechanics and the environment in all of the levels are truly breathtaking.
