Alright so it is not a bad game. But there are some things that I couldn't get over.
- Like total disregard for the previous games' story or lore. Right from the start the game ditches everything established by the franchise so far and does it so abruptly, unceremoniously, so in haste and with such a bad writing it is ridiculous and a bit embarassing.
-  It is just another needlessly open world turned franchise. The world is sometimes pretty sometimes not. The forest and swamp levels are nice and unique. The desert level is empty, dull and totally unoriginal. The story is dumb for the most part but the dialogues between the missions get better, to the point where you start caring for the characters. Which is something the previous games rarely achieved.

- My main problem however, was that while this is a game with an optional stealth approach to missions, the devs screwed up night lighting really bad this time. In some parts of the game is so bright during the night that it is hard to pretend the enemies do not see you. Which breaks immersion a lot.

Metro Exodus, developed by 4A Games, is a game that truly deserves all the awards it has received and more. From its immersive storytelling to its breathtaking visuals, Metro Exodus is a game that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

One of the standout features of Metro Exodus is its world-building. The game's post-apocalyptic setting is expertly crafted, with each location feeling unique and alive. And the game's attention to detail is unmatched, creating a sense of immersion that is truly impressive.

But what really sets Metro Exodus apart is its storytelling. The game's plot is expertly woven into the gameplay, with each mission revealing more about the world and its characters. And the game's themes of survival, hope, and humanity are explored in a way that is both thought-provoking and emotionally resonant.

Of course, no review of Metro Exodus would be complete without mentioning its incredible visuals. The game's graphics are some of the best in the industry, with each location feeling like a work of art. And the game's use of lighting and weather effects creates an atmosphere that is both beautiful and haunting.

All in all, Metro Exodus is a game that truly deserves all the awards it has received and more. If you're a fan of first-person shooters, post-apocalyptic settings, or just great storytelling, then this is a game you simply can't miss.

The best Metro game to date. I was skeptical at first about the open world but after playing, I was impressed. This is not the marker infested garbage of Ubisoft or Witcher 3, but an actual map that you hold on your hand in real time which has nothing marked on it unless you have actually explored the map. The gameplay changes like weapon modding, ammo crafting on the go at workbenches scattered throughout the world are welcome changes. Weapon jamming and degradation are fun additions which I personally haven't seen in any fps I've played since Far Cry 2 and Stalker. The story hits hard especially if you have been following the previous games. My personal complaint was that there weren't many claustrophobic sequences like the older games, but the ones that were there were nothing less than phenomenal, specifically the final level which was scarier than most horror games. However, this is the perfect direction for the next Metro games. A 60-40 split between carefully crafted linear horror sequences and open world sandbox gameplay.

Metro Exodus is one of those games that really makes you appreciate the amount of effort and love that was put in creating such a good, immersive and atmospheric storyline, that is accompanied by interesting and likeable characters and of course a really darn fun gameplay loop. I for one am completely in love with the Metro series, finished all the games, and also read all the books. There really is something about the claustrophobic world of Metro that really pulls you in. Whether you are struggling to survive the merciless radiation filled wasteland, the tug-o-war between the different factions hungry for power, or the mutated creatures that want you dead for all intents and purposes, you won't be finding yourself out of things to do or adventures to partake in. Metro Exodus really upped the ante by throwing you outside the dangerous, yet familiar and weirdly comforting claustrophobic metro tunnels into the unknown. The world opens up and begs you to explore its each and every cranny. The story follows Artyom and his crew in their search for answers. Are there still people out there? Is the war still ongoing? Or was it all just a big fabrication? You are taken through a whole year, through all the seasons, each section of the game containing a different mini open world with different enemies and weather conditions to explore and conquer. From start to finish, your journey is a perilous one and twists and turns happen at every corner. You'll find yourself get invested in your crew, start getting worried when they are worried, confused when they are confused and desperate when everybody begins losing hope. This is the kind of game that you need to really take in by having a few days off and really take your time and immerse yourself in this masterfully crafted world. You won't regret it.

Finally, and I try not to base my overall decision on recommending something on this, but the game locked up and crashed 3 times on 3 separate occasions.  With not a lot to pull me back in, this last crash was the final nail in coffin.  Play the first Metro game, skip this one.

Oh, how I love this game. This review is split into two parts: the good stuff, the stuff they could have worked on a bit more, and the bad stuff. 

[h1] The good stuff [/h1]

The game is really greatly optimized. I mean, I was on Mid / High details the entire time, and only rarely did my game dip under 60 fps. And my PC is obsolete by today's standards.

The open world is great. There are only two real open world sections, so it doesn't overstay it's welcome. But, at the same time, these two sections, Volga and Caspian, are crafted with great care, and attention was paid even to the smallest details. They did go wild with ideas of what to put in them, and their creativity has paid off. At the same time, the linear sections were amazing as well. 

The gunplay is great. The weapons feel good to use both in stealth and loud approaches to various situations, and they really feel like they have the power they should hae.

I am so glad that the devs had finally managed to nail down stealth. Usually in the first two games, if I wanted to get the good ending, I had to go with stealth approach most of the time. However, let's be frank here, 2033 and Last Light had obnoxious and atrocious stealth sections that were a sheer punishment to get through. However, in this game, I chose to do most missions in stealth just because how fun it was. 

One thing they nailed down perfectly was the difficulty balancing. What makes the stealth so great is that in certain areas, the devs anticipated both loud and stealth approaches, and made them both equally viable. In loud approach, you will go in guns blazing and will most likely shoot stuff up really quick, with the downside being that you are just as vulnerable as your enemies are, and you will be having more trouble getting resources for that. In stealth, you will spend much more time waiting around for the perfect opportunity, but the payout of saving your resources for the scripted loud sections is sure worth it. 

The monsters are so great. There's more of them now, some of them are even just good old snakes lurking in the grass. I love how with enough time spent in the open world, you can spot actual behavioral patterns of monsters, be it solitary monsters, entire packs, how monsters behave when they meet monsters of other kinds, or how they behave when they are in their hives / burrows. I also love how Demons are now an actual threat that always looms over you from the distance. If you are in the open world, there will always be at least two demons flying around the map, and you will be praying the entire time, hoping that the demon didn't notice you and isn't flying in your direction right now. I also love Blind Ones, they are actually terrifying, and I haven't been scared in the last five years by a monster in a game as much as I was scared by them.

The DLCs. Yeah, yeah, many people say that 4A can't really do DLCs. And I see where they are coming from, Last Light's DLCs were bad. But this time around, the DLCs actually give us a good story, along with good gameplay. Two Colonels was a tad bit short, but great and well paced with a story that manages to make me feel sad for Khlebnikov's fate. Sam's Story was a bit longer, but an interesting conclusion to Sam's Story (and it was clearly open ended for the sole purpose of letting them create another DLC or even a full game based on Sam in the future). Many people complained about the DLCs, but for me personally, I loved them. 

The english dubbing is finally good, and dare I say, even better than the russian dubbing. In the past games, it was the exact opposite way for me, but not this time.

[h1] The bad stuff [/h1]

The russian dubbing is atrocious. The voice actors were overacting the entire time, and they sometimes sounded like they were applying to become North Korean TV presenters. 

There are many visual bugs. Floating objects all around. Nothing game breaking, but dear Lord, they did not polish the small visual details at all. I understand some very minor visual bugs, but every few minutes there is a random object just floating in the air. That's fine, it's a big game. But what really bothers me is the object displacement in cutscenes. You know, the one thing they should have actually paid attention to. When one character gives something to the other, it just straight up floats through their hands. Because they filled the world with content, and it's a great content tuned to the smallest details, but when it comes to actual fluff that is supposed to fill up the empty spaces in the environment, then they treated it as an afterthought.

The whole sewer section with the big worms in Novosibirsk. I loved the entire game and every part of it, but I outright DESPISE this section, and I absolutely hate it. They shouldn't have included this sh*t stain in the game at all. First off, it's a buggy mess. This was the one section where it took me about four f*cking hours just to get through, because I kept dying to random stuff. My mask would just start breaking for no reason while I was driving the boat, and even when I was shooting the worms on the wall and nothing was shooting vomit at me, THE GAS MASK KEPT BREAKING FOR NO REASON. Then, for some reason, when I got to the second boat in that section, whenever I got hit by vomit, and the projectile managed to hit me and the boat with splash damage, I JUST OUTRIGHT FELL THROUGH THE FUCKING MAP. This one part literally took me an hour to finish just because I had to keep restarting and positioning myself in a way that would let me get a few shots in first before the worms even had a chance to hit me. Sometimes, after the first part of the bossfight with the worms was over, the steering on the boat would break for no reason. 

Dead City was too long. Yeah, I get it, 4A had all of these great set pieces planned out, but this part of the game felt like it was just time padding. The game already felt long enough, but it took me to finish Dead City in just about 10 hours. The entire section could have been reduced down to about 4 hours at best.

Artyom has no dubbing. The DLC characters have dubbing, but NOT ARTYOM. WHY? It makes no sense, as the diary entries in the loading screen are narrated. 

[h1] The unfinished stuff [/h1]

Well, all of the random floating objects in the world. There is too many of them.

The audio balancing. I don't get why the audio in this game is so unbalanced. In one second, the stealth section has great sounds, your stealth goes wrong, you have to start shooting, and all of a sudden, your head is getting blown up by the sheer volume coming into your ears, but then you enter a shootout somewhere else, and you can barely hear anything, because the shooting is now quiet and the sounds are cancelling out each other.

They should have made the boats in Volga a lot faster. They are about as fast as walking, and since having any vehicle in this part of the game isn't possible due to the map design, it is really obnoxious to use the boats. Especially since they are prone to have their handling break at random, which can be only fixed by saving and then reloading. 

[h1] Final thoughts [/h1]

Well, here we have it. Exodus has it's dark spots, but the greatness of this game still manages to make me forget that there are parts that I hate. While they paid attention to details, they forgot to pay attention to decorative stuff. The stealth is finally good, the english dub is finally doesn't induce sheer cringe, and the DLCs are finally good as well. 4A managed to overcome their weaknesses in programming, and finally created a product that is not fatally flawed.

[h1] Who do I recommend this game for? [/h1]

Of course, fans of the old Metro games, story-based FPS fans, and post-apocalypse genre fans. Casual gamers might feel overwhelmed by the amount of content tho.

[h1] Final verdict [/h1]

For it's minor flaws- a solid 8/10.

I always wished that Metro games were just a bit less linear and Exodus makes that wish come true allowing more player freedom and exploration without losing any of the previous games' cinematic flair and narrative focus. I think devs found more or less a perfect balance between linearity and open world design (at least when it comes to Metro series).
The strongest aspect of the series was always the atmosphere and the sense of claustrophobia and the move to more open areas surprisingly doesnt lose that, for the most part at least. Like the previous games, visually Exodus is a feast for the eyes. Attention to detail is incredible and you do get a sense of being in a real place, it is one of the most immersive gaming worlds there is.
Gameplay wise, Exodus feels mostly great to play. Gunplay feels good and each weapon makes a solid impact making combat feel satisfying. Stealth is, like in most games, a bit broken in the player's favor. Enemy AI is..questionable and it's the most obvious during stealth when you can stare enemy in the face from a meter away (Skyrim style) and as long as there is no light directly above you he will remain oblivious to your presence. Still, it is fun. Another big part of the games is the crafting system. Crafting is simple, fast and unobtrusive. It feels natural to the game world and not like a pointless time sink.
And now, the story. Story in Exodus kicks off incredibly weak thanks to some "coincidences" in the narrative and a very "questionable" voice acting and writing. It took me a while to get into the story but thankfully the further the story progresses the better it gets. It all leads to a fantastic finale which is genuinely emotional and meaningful which was a huge surprise for me. Metro's unique morality system is back, although this time it's less punishing and nicely implemented. But both the game's biggest narrative strenght and it's biggest weakness are it's inbetween chapters sections which you spend on a train with your group of comrades. Again, this started incredibly weak but as I got to spend more time with these characters these sections somehow turned into my favorite moments. I began to care for these characters, engaged in singing and drinking with them and the moments Artyom (player character) spends with his wife Anna are incredibly sweet. Despite some characters having terrible voice acting, after a while I got used to it and they started feeling real. It reminded me of Red Dead Redemption 2 and taking care of your camp mates, although it's not nowhere near that level of commitment. 
One big downside to the train sections and the story in general is actually Artyom. Artyom being mute was always a bizzare choice especially since he ACTUALLY TALKS during loading screens between chapters. I usually have no problems with silent protagonists especially in RPGs and FPS games but only when it's a game that is trying to make you the player character. Artyom, however, is not an avatar. He is a written character. You are not roleplaying as Artyom, you are playing as Artyom. This leads to A LOT of really ackward moments and turns every single dialogue (and they can be really long) into a long winded, mindnumbing monologue. Exodus is quite dialogue heavy and the characters are actually asking Artyom questions and talk with him (not to him) and when all of that turns into a monologue it's noticeable, it's weird and it's bad. It is the game's biggest flaw.
Another huge flaw is the atrocious save system. While you can quicksave (sometimes), the game mostly depends on autosaves that can leave you hanging in some terrible situations and, while I haven't personally experience this, has led players to have to restart entire chapters. Not to mention, there's a big chance your save file can get corrupted or you may just get random messages about it being corrupted for some reason. 
On the technical side, Exodus runs fine for the most time. It is a demanding game on the hardware but it's one of the best looking games out there. I did experience a few crashes in certain spots (that required restarting my PC) which is not that big of a deal until you realize these exact crashes have been present for years now and devs never bothered to fix them.
Despite this, Exodus' strengts far outweight it's weaknesses. When Exodus fires on all cyllinders it is a phenomenal experience, an 11/10. When it faulters, however, you notice it. It is at the same time both the best and the worst Metro game. It is definitely worth a try though.

What can I say, this game is fantastic.

I won't know why, but I put off playing this game for ages even though I loved the previous games and the STALKER franchise. It's Metro, but with so much more added to it. 

Gun-play is the same as the previous entries, so still great. Customisation of gear by exploring points of interest and exploring the world is a very welcome addition. In the same vein, the open world sections of the game really makes me wish for a fully open world in this universe. 

Graphics are amazing just like the first two games. Loads of animations for lots of different situation, you can just tell the animators had a great time with this game. The scenery is awesome as well, one of the few games where I was constantly taking screenshots because of how great it looked.

The best part of this game for me however, was the story. I really enjoyed the whole thing as there aren't any parts that feel like they don't matter or that they aren't important. Some parts are cliche, but I just loved the story. Spending the sections where you hang out with the crew and getting to get to know them was really rewarding in enjoying the narrative all the more. 

I also played the DLCs as well. If you get them in a bundle, I would say they're worth playing for sure as I did really enjoy them. However, I wouldn't go out of my way to play them though, if they hadn't come with the version of the game I got.

Even though this game is fantastic it does have a few bugs and some annoying parts. There were a few times I had to reload as the game completely bugged out where characters wouldn't talk to me or I was stuck floating in a triggered animation. Gravity and platforming is super floaty as well. Found myself sliding up and down ladders or inclines to my death quite a few times. Fall damage is super high as well, so you'll find yourself dying more to falls than anything else.

Another note is that the devs recently released the SDK for this game. For those who don't know, that means mod support has officially been added and the community can make a load of wild stuff with the game and all its assets. I think it should be celebrated every time this happens as its a huge gift to the fans. 

So, THANK YOU 4A Games!

All in all though, this game is amazing and you should definitely play it. All the more if you're a fan of story based shooter games in general, you should not miss this one.

[h1]  DAA BEACH IZ HIDING THAER  [/h1]

This game is seriously strange.  On one hand it gives you a badass arsenal of guns that look good, sound good, and are real fun to shoot…but it gives you so little ammo for those guns that you never want to shoot them.  Then it gives you a relatively big, carefully crafted and good looking open world that seems fun to explore…until you realize that there isn’t enough loot or ammo hidden in that open world to justify its exploration.  You see, the irradiated animals you meet in this open world are aggressive.  They can take a lot of punishment, and they can give it out too.  Oh yeah, and they don’t drop ammunition when they die, so one intense firefight could theoretically drain all the ammo that you spent the last hour carefully collecting.  And even if you do spend that ammo to kill them, they’ll just respawn a few minutes later anyway.  From a resource perspective, exploration in Metro Exodus doesn’t make sense unless you’re killing enemies that drop ammo.  And so, which enemies drop ammo in this game?  Humans.  And how can you find humans in this game?  By mainlining the story.  And here’s my main complaint: if the developers had wanted to give us a linear and curated experience, then they should have just designed and marketed their game that way.  Instead, they’ve made free exploration in their ‘open world game’ so attritting that the player is forced to follow the story in a linear fashion.  And oh man the story.  Now, I don’t need my action games to have good plots; Fallout 4 had a dumb story too.  But Bethesda at least had the good sense to let you decide how you wanted to play the darn game, and didn’t use weird negative reinforcement to corral you into the main story.  Like I said, this game is seriously strange.  Oh yeah, and the save system is literally broken, so there’s that too.  

Now, the curious reader might be wondering “hmm, if you shouldn’t fire your guns, and mobs are aggressive and everywhere, how is the player supposed to move around in the world?”  Well I’m glad you asked.  The answer is: press down the control key with your left pinky, and keep it down until you get carpal tunnel syndrome.  At its heart, Metro Exodus is a stealth game.  The mobs in the world respawn but your ammunition does not – you therefore have no choice but to avoid conflict whenever and however possible.  Yes, you may have just picked up that 8-cylinder semi-automatic shotgun with a reflex sight, extended mag, long barrel, and laser point that you’ve been dying to try out…but don’t you dare press that left mouse button!  Instead, you should hold down CTR, move agonizingly slowly from bush to bush, and hope for the best.  It doesn’t feel heroic, and I don’t personally find it fun.  I do, however, find it funny to imagine my character slinking through the tall grasses while carrying: an empty pneumatic rifle; an empty AK47; and a freaking Gatling gun, which also is empty.  My God, why is there a Gatling gun in this stealth game?  It doesn’t make sense.

Anyway, is this game good?  Uh, actually yeah certain parts are pretty good, and that’s what’s so frustrating.  I feel like there’s an A tier game hiding inside this C tier confusion, and I’ve had a few moments running from cover to cover out on the Russian steppe that were genuinely tense and exciting.  But for every one of those great moments there have been at least ten that were really, really annoying.  And so after 26 hours I am done with Metro Exodus – the gun game where you shouldn’t shoot guns, in an open world that you shouldn’t explore.

A gorgeous, moving, thrilling, ambitious shooter! If you like shooters with deep stories and strong characters, survival elements, and RPG-style upgrading, this should be on your must-play list. I dont even know where to begin, metro exodus is one of the most beautiful games ive ever played its a rare experience these days. It’s exactly what you want from a story driven survival horror game. The game is genuinely pretty scary at times as the threats that you encounter at any point in the game are still forces to be reckoned with. Scavenging is very important and without proper preparation it is very easy to be overwhelmed in a situation but the game offers clever players ways out of tough situations. For example if you run out of ammo, you can hide from the enemy and carefully pick them off, sometimes the last guy will even surrender. The story is incredibly immersive as you encounter real problems you would expect to see in a post nuclear wasteland for example radiation, drought, and lack of supplies. The game also offers you a sort of morality code in the game by giving you choices to help people or reserve from hurting people even though it might not be to your immediate benefit. This goes on the macro scale and the micro scale. A larger example might be that you free some slaves from captivity from bandits. But it can also be something as simple as approaching unfriendly locals with your weapon holstered, the locals will then start talking about you in a way that shows even though they still don’t like you, your not as terrible as they expected. the game doesn’t necessarily reward you for these actions but it’s those little conversations that really make the game immersive because you don’t get rewarded for everything you do in real life. The smallest example Would be that in stealth you have the option to kill your opponent or knock them out. They both achieve the same function and one does not ensure success more than the other leaving it completely up to the player to decide whether the enemy is worth killing or simply knocking out. Anyway very good game would definitely recommend it to fans of fallout, horror games, survival games, and story driven games.

Metro Exodus is a Metro game without the Metro setting. It's Okay-ish.

[h1]New World, New Level Design, New Problem[/h1]

The biggest change in Exodus is that the setting is not strictly set in the underground metro anymore, but has a more varied location to explore. In search of the ideal living place, the characters will explore places from winter wasteland to desert. The level design also changed, previously Metro was a linear game with some small variations on how to progress, but Exodus levels are now semi-open levels (similar to Far Cry 1, Crysis 1, or STALKER). I think it's a nice change but 4A Games implementation does have its problem. Being semi-open feels nice because it gives the player some agency on how to tackle the objectives, but there are not a lot of things to do on the level, so it still feels a bit too linear. The environment is very nice to look at, graphic is incredible. But what missing is that nothing is going on in the world. Let's compare it with STALKER which IMO is the most similar to Exodus. Walking in that game feels like living in an evolving world because of the A-Life AI System. There are people doing patrols, mutants roaming around, and they even interact with each other. In Exodus, it's all static. NPC and monsters will always stay in their pre-determined places and won't go anywhere, it makes the world doesn't feel "alive". This is a problem that I think even the developer is aware of because in the later chapters, it becomes more and more linear. Still, I commend 4A Games to experiment with new stuff, though.

[h1]Meet the New (and Old) Mutants[/h1]

Old mutants are back, with some new friends joining. It's kinda disappointing though, being outside of Moscow, I was expecting some more varied mutants will show up, but there are not a lot of variations (shrimps, fuglies (something like the ghoul from Fallout), and fishes (?)). The new ones also don't have a lot of interesting gimmicks, so yeah not a lot to say about this.

[h1]Craft and Shoot[/h1]

Metro has always had a unique feel to its shooting mechanic, and it remains mostly the same. There's still the funny gun that still needs to be pumped and players will still need to scavenge stuff before they can start blasting stuff. There's a new addition to the system, crafting. Crafting is introduced to give the player a bit more freedom on what the player wants to use. You can create more medkit if you get hurt as often, or if you play more of a long-ranged sniper, you can stock up rifle ammo more. The thing is, I don't like this system, it feels tacked on and half-assed.  First, scavenging becomes more of a slog because now you are looting for "ingredients" items, not the finished product (like ammos, filter). The game also doesn't incentivize you to craft stuff if you play for the "good" ending (you will have enough items just looting unconscious bandits), so I don't find any point for this system. Oh yeah, there's also an upgrade weapon system. You can add parts for your weapon (new stock, new sights, etc.). I like this one, it gives you more choices to approach a combat or stealth situation.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

Sound Effects for guns are still good and mostly the same. Environment sounds are okay. I do find that on cutscenes it's inconsistent, though. Like stabbing sound in the gameplay can feel crunchy and loud, but in cutscenes, it's so quiet. What's unfortunate is Metro was a game that is set underground and previous games excelled in creating this harrowing and spooky atmosphere of the place, which sound effects highly contribute to achieving this. Now, because the game is set outside of the Metro, there are not a lot of situations that need to use those sounds. Enviroment sound outside of the corridor stuff is at worst, passable.

[h1]The Story of the Exodus of Spartan[/h1]

NOTE: I played this in English subtitle + Russian Voice
NOTE AGAIN: There's no spoiler in this review

The Metro station setting in a post-apoc world is always the strong point of Metro. So it's a bit worrying when I was told that the devs will explore more outside of the metro setting, and sadly I don't think they succeed in creating an interesting world on this. Gone are the histories of the settler of Metro, Gone are the conflicts of the Nazis and The Reds on the world, now it's replaced with a "journey in a post-apoc world" stuff. There are not a lot of unique spins that you can find on the previous metro game. Religious zealot is the same zealot in other story, bandits are bandits, and such on.

The story, well, has a good base for an interesting story, but damn the execution is so rushed and clunky. Everything happens so fast, there's almost no build-up in every climax scene. This is also coupled with bad dialogue and performance by ALL OF THE CHARACTERS (the Russian voice remedies this by a little bit, but the performance is still just awful). Not to mention this is the game with the most cutscenes in the series. Trying to learn more about the characters is also a slog. 

It basically goes like this: Wait for the cutscene to finish -> stare awkwardly at the character you like to "talk" to -> wait for them to tell you an essay about something boring -> Done, move to other characters -> Oh wait, they're still talking actually -> Wait a bit, while still awkwardly staring at them -> Okay, finished, move on to other characters -> repeat.

Added that Artyom is a "silent protagonist", it feels very, VERY clunky and not engaging. 

Still, this game is based on a Novel. So maybe some stuff needs to be cut down. Metro 2033 and Last Light also had this problem. I love Metro 2033 and Last Light, but this one just falls short. They tried to innovate and expand the gameplay loop but ultimately made it way worse. Not to mention the constant game freezing and crashes on specifically The Caspian level. This game has been out for 4 years at the point and they have not fixed these issues. However, yes I still recommend it.

First off, the game looks phenomenal. I honestly think this is the best looking game I have ever played. Gunplay feels amazing as it has in both of the other games. (I should mention I only played the redux versions) The story is there and I'm happy it continued after Last Light but I just generally don't like the relationship you have with Anna. It's probably just because Artyom is a voiceless protagonist but I feel 0 connection between the two of them. Regardless, I think the story is still enjoyable and the Yamantau level was exactly what I wanted from this game. 

This game runs terribly for a game that released in 2019. Constant freezing in every level when you're in the open map. As I mentioned the Caspian level is noticeably worse causing my fps to drop as well as lag. On top of that the game crashes a ton in that specific mission. For a game that is supposed to be immersive it feels terrible to constantly be taken out of it because the game was not optimized after 4 years of release. 

I want to preface this next point by saying I don't play on ranger mode so it could be different but I really dislike how it feels like I am playing a video game. I hate that there are side missions and materials that you can pick up off the ground. The side missions are not interesting either, they're just fetch quests. I didn't play in ranger mode in either 2033 or Last Light but I was able to immerse myself in this world but here it's so difficult to do so. The backpack conceptually is interesting but it's just another thing that takes me out of it. I also hate the decision to "hold e" for every action. Not only is it tedious but it is the most immersion breaking mechanic in the game. I could be wrong and feel free to correct me if I am but in both Last Light and 2033 if you just walked up to a ladder or tight space it would just automatically put you through it! I would be fine if you just had to press e, but no you have to hold it. There is no option to turn this off which I find ridiculous. 

A small point I also wanted to mention is that the enemies can be extremely cartoonish at times. As great as I thought the Yamantau level was, the cannibals were silly. I can understand if it was meant to be that way but I could not take the threat seriously. It felt like I was playing a borderlands game blasting some psychos. I will say though I do find it really cool that they will call out where you are and this is a huge plus to immersion. 

I'm so sad that this game did not live up to the amazing games that are Metro 2033 and Metro Last Light. This game is just a complete and utter disappoint to me. I really hope that the next game in the series is closer to those two games than this one. That's most likely not going to happen but I can hope. If you are a big fan of metro I still think this game is worth buying just don't expect it to be as good as the others.

Final thoughts after finishing the story - Honestly the final sequence of the game was amazing. It finally felt like I was playing a metro game again and it was magnificent. The Taiga level was also by far my favorite level and the most fun. I think that Volga and Caspian were interesting ideas but I don't really want to see content like that in another metro game. I had a significantly more enjoyable time in the linear levels than any of the open world levels. Overall, everything else I said in this review still remains true but this game is definitely less of a disappointment. I really wish there was a mixed option because I think this game is still worth playing no matter what; despite it still being a let down compared to the other games in the series.

[h1]Flaws and Nitpicks[/h1]
However, there are still some things I disliked or downright despised.

The stealth is still half-baked. You still cant move bodies, a staple in all *real* stealth games. And then the game cant make up its mind if they want you to use stealth because sometimes enemies will just be alerted because "story". And they also do the thing where every enemy knows where you are when one enemy sees you. And enemies will go from being almost blind in the dark to better than 20/20 vision the second you enter alert state. Overall the stealth is barely passable.

The game also cant make up its mind if it is a survival game, a regular shooter, or a stealth game. The game will just disable stealth and throw tons of items at you when you're in a "shooter" section. But then the story decides you're in a stealth section and demands you not kill anyone. And then you get to explore the world and the survival elements actually matter a little. I guess it's not really a huge issue, but it just feels weird.

My last gripe is the over-reliance on quick time events and cutscene actions. It's so frustrating to be playing the game and the game decides to lock you in a poorly named "quicktime event" that makes you mash a button, as the exact same cookie-cutter animation plays for way too long. It's the exact opposite of a doom glory kill. And sometimes the game grabs control to force you to make stupid decisions so the "story" can play out. I have a message for the developers: In as much as you are able, DO NOT DO THIS NEXT GAME. See Callisto Protocol if you need another example of why this crap is unacceptable.


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Overall I thoroughly enjoyed my time with the game and look forward to any sequels.

Solid third game in the series. One of the strongest aspects of the Metro franchise was its atmosphere, as for post apocalyptic games there is nothing that comes close. In the transition to an open-world game I did not feel as the quality of the atmosphere dropped, but rather improved upon it. The hand-crafted environments give the appropriate emotion for each setting. From crazed swamp hicks to cannibals the game made each with respect to how it would be in post-Russia. 

Story: 8/10, That story is straight forward but its grounded connection to the relationships between characters is what creates the immersive atmosphere. For a silent protagonist (besides journals) I think they did a great job of putting you into the character, with an emphasis on dialogue and everyday actions. Compared to the previous games this one strays away from the "Dark ones" and focuses more on the dreams and aspirations of Artyom and Miller, which for better or worst, makes the world closer to reality.

Gameplay: 8.5/10, Another one of the strongest aspects of the game is its first-person survival horror elements. For someone like myself I love the small touches of cleaning your gun, gas mask, and charging your batteries. Playing this game on Spartan hardcore (the one that gives some HUD), contributed greatly to the immersion of the game, and while I see only around 3% of people finished the game with this setting. I would recommend at any skill level to play on this difficulty. While you die in a couple of shots the AI is rather easy to manipulate and gives you a sense of urgency and avoid bullet sponge tropes. Gathering and collecting resources to craft ammo and survival equipment also added the sense of scarcity, this conservative mindset changes the dynamic of interactions, should I stealth past? Or risk some of my ammo to take this fight. My only downside to some of the combat was the boss battles which took away from some the creative ways to solve problems from the game and changed it to a simple firefight. 

Music and Sounds: 9.5/10, another must have in the franchise, I'm very happy with the soundscape considering the differences with environments in previous games. The music added to the setting and worked in conjuction with the ambience. Having to work with such a diverse set of environments was a challenge and I believed they did a great job transitioning out of the "metro". No complaints from me.

Graphics 9.5/10, I have a 2070 Super which at the time of release was one of the top cards, I didn't play the enhanced edition considering it would reset my progress, but with how good the base game looked. I am very happy even without RTX mode on. This makes me want to save up for a 4080 when the budget allowed me! Also, depending on what monitor you have will greatly affect how the game looks. I have a nice 1440p LG monitor for around $500 however, this monitor sucks with dark environments which was a total bummer since it gives a "bleached" look. Regardless, the game still looked good with this defect.

Overall 9/10: I'm happy to see that even after two games of similar nature, they still managed to make a refreshing post-apocalyptic title. Compared to previous games, getting different endings was much easier than last light (which is bollocks). Pick this game up whenever now since its relatively cheap! Looking forward for the sequel!

As an enjoyer of both 2033 and Last Light, I really wanted to like Metro exodus. Sadly, aside from a few exceptions, this game underdelivered for me. 

The first few hours were unremarkable, but enjoyable enough. The opening felt like a good return to classic metro, with familiar claustrophobia-inducing metro tunnels, mutants and some decent set pieces. Acquiring the train was fun, and the first “real” chapter by the Volga river is not bad. The shooting and the stealth mechanics haven't worn out their welcome yet, and there are some engaging side quests involving a teddy bear and a guitar. Plus, the exploration felt rewarding. For me though, there was a distinct lack of atmosphere, since it mostly took place in wide open areas in the daytime. I also didn't care much for the paper thin characters and story. The voice acting is not great (I made the correct choice by switching the language to Russian halfway through), and characters constantly talk over eachother, resulting in very stilted and awkward exchanges. I longed for an option to skip these conversations on the train. 

However, the following chapter, Yamantau, is bad. There’s no other way to go about it. On the story end it’s the most predictable turn of events imaginable (you get tricked by a group pretending to be the remaining members of the government. Surprise surprise, they’re actually cannibals) and it turns into a shooting gallery set to russian heavy metal music? You’re shooting hordes of goons in tight corridors for 30+ minutes. In another game like F.E.A.R., that would be great, since the combat in that game is strong enough to carry it entirely. On the other hand, I would call Metro combat functional, but not good.

- Most weapons feel floaty and underpowered.

- Enemies hardly react to getting shot, leading to very little in terms of satisfying player feedback. This is worsened when you take into account that many enemies, especially mutants, are bullet sponges.

- The AI is rarely good enough to make for engaging foes. Enemies constantly hide behind non-existent cover, and very rarely surprise you. 

- World bullet collision is often inconsistent with what you actually see. Get used to bullets not hitting your target, even though your line of sight is completely unobstructed. 

With this in mind, I don’t think it was a good idea to lean so heavily on the combat in this area. You're throwing away any immersion and atmosphere for mid-tier shooting. I get that this area was probably meant as a change of pace. I do like variety, but I don’t like when the new pace just sucks, frankly.

It was at this point the game turned into a slog, especially during the Caspian desert. Just hours and hours of filler walking or driving through barren locations trying to get to the mission area. There is less interesting content than Volga, stretched over a much bigger map. Some missions are decent, and are a clear callback to the style of the earlier games. Though, these areas cannot compare in the slightest to the highlights from 2033. The worst missions are the ones where you’re forced to follow an uninteresting companion with the walking speed of an old, confused tortoise. I know this happened sometimes in 2033 too, but it was less of a problem in that case since it didn’t feel like that game was actively trying to waste my time outside of these moments. There are also some bugs here which range from annoying (if you check your map while driving, your FOV will double and your camera will be placed in the roof of your car) to gamebreaking (some areas can apparently ruin save files). The boss fights in Caspian and Taiga are legitimately atrocious, too. Dumping 40 crossbow bolts into a bear, twice, while circle-strafing sure is fun! Again, the combat is not very good – why put so much emphasis on it?

I did find some enjoyment in the very last level of the game, thanks to some good tension-building and the welcome return of the librarians, but it was too little, too late.

I wouldn't say this is a terrible game by any means, but it did not appeal to me. The open world undermines the atmosphere which made the earlier titles so engrossing for me, and the game doesn't improve on other fronts like the combat or storytelling to make up for this loss.

One of my most favourite games of all time. I love the series, but this one just really struck a chord in particular.
I don't usually get hit so emotionally with games, but this one took me a few days to kinda get over. Luckily I had the DLC to soften the blow and get just a little more Metro before wrapping it up.
Best game ever!!!

Edit: I am very biased but just hear me out 

I have been a fan of the Metro Trilogy for a very long time, and I have to say Metro Exodus is quite a different style than 2033 and Last Light. It is an open world phenomenon and I'm still taking my very time to enjoy as much as I can of the game. The graphics, even on my shitbox of a laptop, is gorgeous, and I'm not even playing on the PC Enhanced edition. 
I may be slightly biased, but if you are a fan of FPS games, you will love this game. 
Don't even get me started on the soundtrack. Alexey Omelchuk's musical composition is amazing. I love each and every piece in the Exodus soundtrack, as well as the songs in the 2033 and Last Light soundtrack's. 
The story of the Metro Trilogy is based off of Dmitry Glukhovsky's Metro 2033, Metro 2034, and Metro 2035. I highly recommend reading them, they are great books.

"Having played the previous two games in the series, I was excited to see where the story of Artyom and his companions would go in "Metro Exodus". I'm happy to say that the game exceeded my expectations in every way.The graphics are absolutely stunning, with a level of detail and immersion that I've rarely seen in a game. The post-apocalyptic world of the metro is brought to life with incredible attention to detail, from the dilapidated buildings to the mutated creatures that roam the surface.The gameplay is also top-notch, with a mix of stealth, exploration, and combat that keeps things fresh and exciting. The weapons and upgrades are varied and satisfying to use, and the level design is cleverly crafted to provide multiple paths and approaches to each objective.But what really sets "Metro Exodus" apart is its storytelling. The characters are well-developed and believable, and their interactions are filled with genuine emotion and tension. The plot is engaging and thought-provoking, exploring themes of survival, morality, and the nature of humanity in a world that has been all but destroyed.Overall, "Metro Exodus" is an incredible game that lives up to the hype and surpasses its predecessors in every way. Whether you're a fan of the series or just looking for a great first-person shooter with a compelling story, this game is an absolute must-play."

It gets a little stale after a while. Nothing really changes except the scenery, and that doesn't change until you complete the chapter you're in, then you're loaded into the next space. I don't recommend combing over every square inch of the spaces, I recommend following the intended path and exploring along that. The metal detector upgrade kind of ruined exploration for me and just devolved looting into moving my camera around until I heard the beeps. I purchased this game in order to play it on Ranger, ie. hudless like Metro 2033. But you can only play on Ranger mode on Hardcore difficulty, and it's the dumbest decision they've ever made. The only way you can play without any hud or button prompt is to play on a difficulty where everything is a 1 shot. 
Although I gave Metro 2033 various amount of shit, their Ranger mode was pretty good and was at least accessible on multiple difficulty. Now, if you want to have the maximum immersive experience, which is the sole reason I bought the game for, is by playing as a wet pringle of a character where a stray bullet grazing your hair will kill you.

Oh, and Motion Blur is always on. You can't disable it and there's nothing you can do about it. No game in existence, and certainly not a FPS should force you to play with motion blur.

The game's story is captivating, taking players on a journey through a devastated world, filled with danger and despair. The characters are well-developed and relatable, making the player invested in their fate. The game's mechanics are intuitive and easy to understand, allowing players to focus on the action.

The game's combat is challenging, yet rewarding, with a wide variety of weapons and equipment available to the player. The game offers a good mix of stealth and action, making it enjoyable for players who prefer either playstyle.

Metro Exodus (ME) is a first-person shooter game with survival horror and stealth elements. It has been developed by the company 4A Games and published by the company Deep Silver.

[i] Pros & cons: [/i]

++ Journey across the post-apocalyptic Russia on a train with your heavily armed friends. Revisit the claustrophobic tunnels of Moscow, shake hands with cultists on Volga's frozen tundra, liberate slaves in the desert of the Caspian, play hide and seek with the tribes in Taiga's lush forests, and sneak around blind gorillas within the irradiated ruins of a dead city.

+ I like most of the characters because they are well written, and the game gives you enough opportunities to support them. My favourites are Stepan and little Nastya; I could not refuse her plea for the heroic rescue of a teddy bear.   

+ Solid addons. Both of them illuminate the events around side characters that you will encounter during the main storyline. 

- The depiction of Colonel Miller, a hardened veteran and military leader, as a naive and irrational commander lacks credibility. And believe me, thoughts of mutiny crossed my mind several times.

- Occasional FPS drops, irregular crashes, and corrupted save games. I have experienced all of it, and it boils down to... *switches to a Russian accent* completely normal phenomenons.

-- Taking the game out of the Steam store, two weeks before its release, is referred to as a d*ck move in the gamer scene.

[i] Summary: [/i]

I consider ME to be a great continuation of the series, and the strongest part of the franchise. It has surprised me with its open world aspects and gripping storyline. 
Alas, the overall impression is tarnished by technical issues, and the rushed cooperation with the EPIC Games Store for temporary exclusivity. You can do better 4A Games and Deep Silver.

Recommended for fans of the post-apocalypse and gas mask fetishists.

 [i] Achievements: [/i]

Estimated time for 100% completion: +50 hours

Singleplayer achievements: 68
Multiplayer achievements: none

here's some really important tip that I experienced myself after having my second playthrough on the main game, and not the enhanced edition: I played Metro Exodus probably a year ago for the first time *without* playing Metro 2033 and Metro Last Light. I didn't really understand the game, characters, story and everything much. I thought the other two games might be too old to play, and in result, I didn't enjoy Metro Exodus much. please whatever you do, play Metro 2033 and Metro Last Light before playing this game. those two games are absolutely amazing too and they can really affect your experience when playing Metro Exodus. I did this on my second playthrough, and now I love this whole series so much that I would gladly play it all over again right now, even though it's been only 2 hours since I finished the game in my second playthrough lol.

All kinds of flavours going on here, from forest wilderness to a huge bunker populated by cannibals, and you travel from place to place on a steam train. The secondary characters really get fleshed out in this game and by the end you really come to care about them, which makes the story more rewarding. My favourite 'level'(for lack of a better word) is the Caspian Sea...this part is a tantalising glimpse of what a true open-world Metro game might be like. The DLCs are both good too, although Sam's Story is definitely the better and longer one and has good replay value. If you haven't checked out the Metro games before, you'd be crazy not to buy them now they're on sale as they really are- all of them- exceptionally good.

This is not Metro, it's Fallout with a slightly better stealth. Game lost all the uniqueness going for a more generic post apocalyptic wasteland. Levels are huge open world full of nothingness with respawns of generic beasts, Fallout ghouls or generic Mad Max wasteland barbarians. There is some salvageable stuff in the first two chapters but the rest is just boring and stuff you have already seen a thousand times. Generic enemies, generic Fallout ghouls, an entire Mad Max themed level with slaves, people going around eating each other dressed with kitchen pans.
The idea of a mobile base on a train was cool, I love trains, but guess what you see it once for level, for the rest you have the usual Ubisoft's "free the outpost, gain a safehouse" where you can craft stuff. This is just an example of how much generic this game has become.
The only saving grace of this game are the first and the last level which, to no surprises, are a callback to the original games with the metro, mutants, hallucinations and an extremely better narrative. The open world levels are useless, reaching the last level it's a kick in the nuts, you scream at the monitor "where have you been the last twenty hours? Why have you wasted time to give me absolutely nothing?". It's like the middle part of the game has been done by different people and only the beginning and the end are done by the real devs.
The Two Colonels dlc is adding insult to injury, you have a full fledged metro adventure like the old times and you see the devs till can do their job. Why isn't the game like this?
Sam's story has a semi-open world hub which could have been a way better level in the main game than the wastelands or the taiga. It also has way better characters.
It's a terrible delusion for a Metro fan like me and I sincerely hope this franchise never see another game unless they really understand what the fans want.

A very successful third part of the Metro series, with great atmosphere and story. Artyom and his companions take a train on a journey to find out if there is any other life out there, also to find a possibly more livable place than the Metro.

Two of the four levels are very open and expansive, one could almost call it an open world, one is very linear and one is something in between. This is one of the biggest innovations compared to the predecessors, which both consisted of fairly linear levels. There are quite a few outposts and smaller tasks to do.

You now also have resources and a kind of crafting system to keep your equipment in good shape and produce ammunition/medicines, and you can attach various modifications to your weapons in the different slots.

The two story expansions aren't bad either, The Two Colonels is a rather small about 2-hour DLC that is relatively "adventure"-heavy with little shooting, and Sam's Story is more or less another open level that offers another few hours of gameplay.

There are some things I like about the game. I'll start with them.

The modding system for the guns is awesome, I loved the feeling of customizing and changing your weapon. One of the best gun modding systems in any game I've played.
Some of the map design is really good, you can tell they put a lot of thought and effort into creating a path or two that you can sneak around with if you find them. They aren't so obvious that it makes stealth unnecessary but they aren't so hard to find that you get frustrated.
The backgrounds of some of the cities were stunning, there was clearly lots of effort put into the dilapidated buildings and the streets of the ruined cities that the train rolls through.
I liked how even on hard difficulty one headshot was generally enough to put down an enemy. It made skill feel more necessary than other games.
The way the characters talk to each other and interact is really cool, they feel real when they are communicating with each other and the main character is not involved.

Now onto why I cannot recommend this game.
Your character never talks, which makes every conversation feel incredibly odd and stilted. They did a good job writing the conversations in a way that makes it so that your character never has to talk, at the cost of losing a level of immersion you get when your character interacts with others. 
A lot of the story was predictable. Most of the characters were cliche, and had no story arc or very cliche arcs. 
The world building didn't seem real. How is it that so many people survived, but they all turned out to be psychopath nutjobs? Where are all the normal people? Throughout the entire game you meet like 4 that aren't already part of your group. 
And wow the colors are really bad in parts. I may have just messed up my settings, but there just so many shades of gray that eventually it felt like the game was in black and white. The forest level was like looking at the game through dirty toilet water. A lot of the time the enemies are the same color as the background as well, so they are incredibly hard to see. This was probably just me though so I could look past it. 
The worst part of the game, and why I can never play it again, was the unskippable dialogue and cutscenes. They were so obnoxious and brought the game to a complete stop so many times. Completely negates replayability, I'm not gonna sit through 6 more hours of mediocre cliche dialogue in order to get to the good parts of the game. So, while I think there is a solid game in here, the tedium is too much for me to recommend anyone try to find it.

As a big fan of the Metro franchise, I am in love. I'm extremely happy to say that it exceeded all of my expectations and delivered an unforgettable experience. The level of detail put into the environments is absolutely mental; each location felt like a living, breathing world with its own unique set of challenges I had to come across. I found myself constantly in awe of the beautifully rendered landscapes and dynamic weather effects, which in itself made the game so much immersing. The storyline was equally impressive, with well-developed characters and an engaging plot that kept me invested from start to finish. The game's blend of action and stealth mechanics kept things fresh and exciting, and I was constantly on the edge of my seat as I navigated through dangerous parts of the levels. What really set Metro Exodus apart for me was its emotional impact. The game tackled some heavy themes, and I found myself genuinely caring about the fate of the characters and their struggle for survival and the eternal "freedom" from all the post-war chaos. Though I got the bad ending, I am still happy with how the whole experience turned out. Overall, Exodus was an unforgettable experience that I will never forget. Thank you Metro, what a ride it was!

I tried to give this game a chance.  I really did.  The graphics look great (when the game's not having an aneurysm at 15 fps; turns out this was usually caused by having the xbox controller connected with bluetooth, for some reason; other games are just fine), the sound design is nothing special, but fine.  My main complaint is that I just don't think the people who made this game really understood the world they were supposed to be portraying.  If this were a stand-alone game, not about Artyom or the Metro, the story and environments would have made more sense, but the writers just destroyed the lore to fit "open-world."  Open-world doesn't mean I have to be able to walk around a fricken field and be able to walk in any of the 360 degrees at any given time.  It means I'm free to choose my objective and my path to that objective, without having to pause to load a new area, neither of which this game actually does.  The "open world" is split into several levels, each with miles and miles of walking to the next semi-interesting thing.  While I am able to (for the most part) choose what direction I want to approach from, the objectives are extremely linear.  You do this set of objectives now. 
 If you do the main objective first, you missed the others; too bad, start the chapter over.  They could have made an open-world game underground in the metro.  Let me try to find my own routes between stations or whatever.  That would've fit and sounds really fun to me.

The developers tried to add a crafting system to the game.  Sounds cool until you realize that it makes the whole game a collect-a-thon gathering only TWO resources.  They're always just scattered around feeling more random than "level design" and they're annoying and hard to spot.  If you don't bother with them, you'll run out of ammo, because every enemy has a fricken angel on his shoulder that dissolves his ammo upon death, just so you can't pick it up.  There are no military-grade rounds anymore and they didn't replace them as a currency with anything else, so there's no bartering in the game.  If you want bullets, you make bullets.  I have been playing on normal, taking my time and getting headshots for most kills and I am still struggling with ammo.  Most of my play time has been going back to old spots hoping to find more stuff to make ammo with and hoping the stupid enemies won't respawn, which, just in case anybody hasn't figured it out yet, IS TEDIOUS AND BORING AS ALL HELL.

Also, escaping Moscow on a steam train?  Are you daft?  Game says it went 3906 kilometers on ONE FRICKEN HOPPER OF COAL and ONE TANK OF WATER.  Fired up the dormant steam train at the beginning of the game in two minutes (It takes several hours to fire up a steam train, especially if it's dead cold.  It has to be done slowly so the thermal expansion doesn't cause pressure leaks, plus you're heating up a WHOLE LOCOMOTIVE; it takes time.), then had Miller have to explain that he was keeping shit from you but for some reason chose to bring the whole squad that also didn't know what he was talking about?  The writing is just so unbelievably lazy that every time I start to get invested, someone says or does something so dense or out of place, that I just lose interest again.  I got to the desert, where the new sniper rifle I found does less damage than my silenced revolver and gave up.  The sandstorm was kind of cool, but my comrades were warning me that it was coming for about ten times longer than the actual storm lasted.  One other point; if making your game open world necessitates adding a fricken car to drive past all the empty, boring nothingness, maybe your game shouldn't have been open world.

Oh, also there's a point where they tell you that you're only able to swap your weapons at the workbench on the train, so when I got the crap sniper rifle in the desert and wanted to swap it back for the Kalash, I drove back to the train and wasted five minutes trying to figure out how to get inside, only to realize that the game had lied to me before and the special "weapon collection" workbench had been moved out of the train and into a local building.  That seems like what you would do when a warring tribe of bandits is angry at you and you might need to leave immediately.  Good thinking, especially after telling me "it will always be here."  Really though, who wrote this garbage?  Maybe it wouldn't bug me in something sillier like the Fallout franchise, but in a story world that used to pride itself on the gravity of the situations playing out, the lack of thought put into making this game really gets under my skin.

I really liked the game's mechanics and story, and I'd be happy to recommend it to others. However, I encountered far too many technical difficulties during my time, which made the experience very painful. I'll go through a few of them below.

For those who want a short answer, I would say not to get this game unless you are confident that you can figure out how to fix or get around any issues you encounter, as I had far too many technical issues during my time that made the experience very painful.


To start off, this game is the sequel to Last Light and is a continuation of the "Good Ending" of that game. The game, like the previous two, places a strong emphasis on its narrative and shares many features with its predecessors. Without giving anything away, I'll just say that the setting is very different from the previous two games. The story is well written and, in my opinion, holds its own against the other entries in the series. Still, it takes a different course than the other two.

The game's core mechanics are excellent, and the ability to modify weapons in-mission and craft resources on the fly is a welcome addition. which I think plays amazingly well with the entire feel of this game.

NOTE: This is my experience and may differ from those others have had.

This game is great, and I had no problems with it at all during my first playthrough. However, after that point, I started having problems one after another. The first thing I had an issue with was NG+ with "My Weapons" not actually carrying over to the new game, so I had to collect everything again. This wasn't a game-breaking issue, but it was inconvenient and clearly not the intention of the feature. I did manage to get it working for my third playthrough, though.

Next was "Crashes." I had crash after crash, and this started during my second playthrough when I was doing the Iron Mode achievement, which meant only saving between missions. and every single mission I did right at the end, the game would crash, making me run through the entire mission all over again from the start. Because of this, the experience was excruciatingly unpleasant, and my runs took twice as long as they would have otherwise. and I sometimes crashed twice during a single mission.

Lastly, I had some trouble getting past a black screen during a cutscene in the DLC Two Colonels. which took me a while to figure out how to get around. without getting around this made the dlc uncompletable. 

This game would have my full recommendation if it weren't for all the technical issues I ran into while playing it. Again, this is just what happened to me; some players have had a trouble-free experience with the game. So if you're feeling brave, by all means, buy the game. And as always, hold off until a discount comes along.

This game (after the 1st hour) plays as a open world game, but instead of the entire game taking place in 1 map, it's across multiple different locations. There's new mechanics such as crafting, weapon cleaning and morality for what enemies you kill instead of just specific actions. There's also weather events and side missions. Stealth and combat is still really good in this game. Battles are tense and stealth has been improved with the game telling you whether enemies will be able to see you. You also play through many areas solo, but you have allies fight alongside you a few times which is nice and makes sense since you don't travel alone. I also like how some anomalies from the first game return and are more of a threat that don't happen at one scripted point. Crafting is a big part of Exodus so exploring is even more important than previous games and also more rewarding. Instead of finding ammo for a gun you aren't using and getting stuck with low ammo for a gun you are using, you'll find crafting pieces. These are much more common but ammo is scarce. This works a lot better since you have more control over what ammo you have instead of being at the mercy of what ammo the game gives you. If you like the previous metro games, you'll like this one and if you like open world games, you'll also like this.

Metro Exodus is an outstanding video game that has been crafted with incredible attention to detail. The game's storyline is captivating, and the graphics and sound design are truly exceptional.

The world of Metro Exodus is both immersive and beautifully rendered, with each location offering a unique and detailed environment to explore. The gameplay mechanics are seamless, blending action, stealth, and survival elements to create an engaging and challenging experience.

The weapon customization and crafting system is a fantastic addition that provides players with an incredible level of control over their equipment, making it both satisfying and empowering. But what really sets Metro Exodus apart is its cast of characters.

Artyom, the game's protagonist, is a well-realized hero that players will become deeply invested in. The supporting cast is equally well-written and expertly voiced, creating a level of emotional depth and complexity that is rare in video games.

In summary, Metro Exodus is an exceptional video game that should not be missed. Its outstanding storytelling, gameplay, and design make it a true masterpiece of its genre. If you're looking for a gaming experience that is both immersive and engaging, Metro Exodus is an excellent choice.

metro exodus is an ultranationalist ode to the lost russian empire, regardless of its soviet or royalist nature. as a narrative, the game brings the storyline of the past two games to a boiling point by taking artyom out of the cave of the shadows he was living in, where remnants of the nazi and socialist past still seemed real, and brings him to a larger image of smallscale and seemingly unimportant fights in relation to the greater threat out there: extinction of a once great nation now fragmented into an archipelago of nameless wastelands. still through all this ugliness one thing shines and it is the diverse nations of russia and the vast landscape they once called home persevering and living the last breaths of russia's great past well into the nightmare of the present. here the character of miller and anna as the respective symbols of the fatherland and its territorial integrity come to play to complete the full image of a narrative that yearns to maintain a vast russia with all its imperial and soviet colonies (kazakhstan and vladivostok as direct references in the game), disregarding the smaller faction-based fights for the greater nationalist strive of rebuilding russia after its destruction the enemy.
in a few words: it's a refreshing game for the western audience.

Metro Exodus was the first game I tried on Xbox Game Pass back when it launched in 2018. I played about an hour of it and as soon as I was left out in the open world, I hated it so much, I uninstalled it. In fact, I also tried playing Metro 2033 TWICE back in the day, but for one reason or another one, I uninstalled them as well. I'm pretty sure I didn't even try Last Light. So yeah, I could say I was never a big fan.

Fast forward 5 years, I wanted to give the game a second chance, with the enhanced edition and all. And boy did I feel the same way about the open world sections. However, I did stick with the game and I focused solely on the main missions. That's where the game shined. 

Regarding the open world, I feel like the designers of the game wanted it to feel more innovative and modern with these new areas; however it gave me the complete opposite feeling. I found them unnecessary, tedious and not cohesive enough with the rest of the game. Luckily there were only two of these sections, and I said before, I skipped them completely, going straight for the main missions.

The story is simple but well executed. By the end I was completely absorbed by its depressing atmosphere and I didn't want anything bad to happen to anyone anymore. I loved the gameplay, mixing action and survival and making every bullet count. The crafting system was very well done as well, giving you plenty of upgrades for your weapons and equipment.

The levels themselves were very nice, never feeling repetitive or tedious and I greatly enjoyed them, but if there's one thing I will complain about is the good/bad endings. Again, another thing the game wanted to be "modern" about and it ended up being a stupid gimmick. You kill at least one murderer begging for their life? You get the bad ending. Otherwise, you get the good one. That was so cheap in my opinion and didn't add anything either.

Content wise, I feel like the game had just the right length. Not to short, not too long either. I also have the two DLC, and although I've read that they are quite good, I've had enough. I'm very happy with what I've achieved and I don't want to go back to this world anymore. At least until they announce the sequel.

Overall, I had a lot of fun and although I think the game does some awful things to its design, it also does a lot of things very very well. 8.5/10, recommended.

After committing myself to finish a playthrough, I have decided to revise my review of the game. It is on par with the other metro games. The story in this one is better than the first two. But the production value is lower. When I first played the game(a year after it's release because epic games) it was in a poor state. The guns were unresponsive, the character acceleration was awful, and it was incredibly buggy a YEAR after release mind you. I returned to it near three years later and found that mostly the game was more enjoyable now(though the character controller is still ridiculous). The game would be better with these issues fixed than it's predecessors, however, the production value is still not what you'd expect from a triple A title. Audio lines play over each other, some models are lacking faces, and the environments are at times hard to navigate with the awful character controller. The first two free roam maps are mediocre, but everything after that, especially the forest and final level, is peak Metro. The game was also far shorter than I thought, only having three "Open world" levels. Now I would recommend but still caution that the game has some flaws in quality

The horror isn't too much, so I didn't have to shit my pants which is good. But all in all the devs chose not to terrorize me non-stop which is appreciated, I just can't handle these kinds of shockers after work. So, well done by the devs, it was exciting and an appropriate amount of terrifying.
The atmosphere and graphics are excellent. The lighting in particular (without ray tracing). Some of the animation work (weapon handling, interactions with your backpack, using any of your gear like lighters, using a workbench etc.) are probably some of the best you will ever see in a game. Especially pulling out your backpack or the map (which is a physical object) is just stunning and must have taken hours upon hours to animate and perfect. Details like these add so much to the authenticity of the world. Amazing job there.
You absolutely must pick up as much resources as you can to craft the gear and ammo that you need to survive. The developers managed to make you feel unease if you haven't crafted and looted enough, you will run out of ammo and will try to conserve it, even on normal difficulty. I avoided some encounters, because I knew I didn't have the resources, always shot to kill and spent bullets conservatively. Which is okay, this is a core gameplay principle, it fits the setting, and I wasn't as annoyed by this as I thought I would, because the economy was hard but well balanced. So this is well done by the developers.
The story line is good / okay. Personally I wasn't blown away by it, but this will work just fine for most people. A huge mistake not to give the character of the player a voice. He literally says nothing the entire game (except for intros to areas/missions) which is a huge mistake. 
The shooting, the weapon customization and the light/stealth mechanics are fun and very well done. Sniping scary monsters in the frontal lobe with a pimped out cross bow with an IV scope and night vision googles on while hiding in the pitch black metro is a personal highlight for me.  
Performance on Linux with Proton/Wine is generally great and everything works perfectly out of the box.
