This is going to be a  review of Metro Exodus. Lets start with the best things about this game. 

THE STORY,  DIALOGUE AND CHARACTERS: (9/10) I really like the characters is in this game and the dialogue and voice acting play a major role in making them interesting to listen too. The story is simple but done really well and flows nicely with a few plot twists here and there which spice it up a bit. I liked the story in all Metro games but this one is just a bit better. Your character and a group of spartan soldiers along with Anna and her father are simply going from area to area to find a place that is safe from radiation and trouble to settle down.   

The next thing which is improved is CRAFTING, EQUIPMENT and WEAPON and UPGRADES(9/10). It is done a lot better. No more selling ammunition or guns to get currency to buy other guns or equipment or to upgrade. Now you actually gather resources during exploring areas to craft ammo and equipment and do various other things like clean your guns and repair your gear. You can even craft filters now! Gunplay is good and there is more upgrades for all the guns and they are all useful. And on top of that you actually find gear upgrades like for your mask and helmet and armor. 

The ENVIRONMENTS and LEVEL DESIGN (8/10) is decent. Metro Exodus has some different environments to keep you interested like snow areas, a desert area level and a jungle area level. Some areas are more open than others and take longer to complete and allow you to explore more which is a good thing. The only thing is there isn't a lot of levels in the game which is a shame.

VISUALS and SOUND(10/10): Great! No issues with these.

Now on to the not so good things. Luckily there isn't much. The biggest thing being PERFORMANCE(8/10): This game struggles on my system when I enable RTX mode and I have a decent RTX video card. The game almost crashed in one area. Stayed at 1 frame per second and froze for a good minute. Without RTX on it runs better but still has the occasional frame drop. It is just a shame I can't get RTX to run smoothly no matter  how I fiddle with the settings. The other issue is this game still manages to have bugs and glitches in it like enemies freezing in mid air once they die or decorations just floating in mid air no really sitting on top of  anything.

Other minor issues I have with the game.
-Can't switch out a pheumatic weapon like the Tikkar for any other gun besides the crossbow. Don't ask me why they thought this was a good idea in a short game like this.
-lack of crafting tables in some levels and some don't allow you to change weapons only upgrade them. I don't know why  they thought it was a good  idea.
-the game overall is a bit short. You don't get a lot of time to fiddle around with the last two weapons you get late in the game a lot.

Overall I still recommend this game. It is still good your are just probably better  of playing it without RTX on and the glitches aren't a game breaker. It is still an improvement in most ways compared to the other Metros. 

Final Score: 8.5/10

Edited:

Finished the game. This is my first full review of a game. First off, this game is marvelous! Thanks 4A team for delivering this masterpiece.

( - ) Let me talk about the negative things of this game first:
Metro Exodus is a great story-driven game. Graphic is top notch. However, there are few minor problems with character animations and audio bugs. People talk over each other sometimes and if you're going to play without subtitles, it's kind of hard to follow the dialogue. Facial animation was not that great, some of the cutscenes were a bit off for me but most of the time they were good. I guess it's not originally for the English version, playing this game in Russian version could be better but I would never know for sure. Still, these are some minor issues that didn't really affect too much of my experience playing this game.

( + ) Let's get to the good part:
This is definitely the best single player first person shooter with a great story for me! It's been so long since I really enjoyed a game like this. The character development is one of my favorite things about this game. The game does a great job of making you feel connected with the NPCs. Everyone in your Aurora squad has their unique personality and you can easily tell the difference.

The new crafting and modding system is interesting. I love how you can change the mods on your guns while you're doing quests because it affects the gameplay a lot. You have options to choose your loadout before and during the missions. However, if you decide to play this game on Ranger Hardcore mode, the resources are pretty scarce which forces you to play this game on stealth most of the time.  Cleaning your guns is very important because the dirtiness affects your weapon's stats (accuracy and fire rate). Your guns could be jammed many times if they are too dirty.

New quest-finding system is great too. The game doesn't show you where the quests are, you'll have to discover those points of interest on your own using your binocular. Those high grounds are the goldmines of intelligence if you take your time and look for places. It will be shown as a question mark on your map after you stared at a specific location for about 3 seconds.

I love the day-night cycle in this game. The game gives you options to select day or night time. There are many safe houses around the map and you can use them to heal yourself, use the workbenches or sleep. It changes the whole game of how you choose to approach your next mission. Day time means less monsters and the human AIs are quite harder. They can easily see you from afar and alert the other guards so for example, if you want to take down a bandit camp, night time is much more effective. However, night time in this game is horrifying (more monsters to deal with). There are also anomalies in this game and it gives me S.T.A.L.K.E.R vibes. It only happens at night and will hurt you if you get too close.

The atmosphere is one of the best about this game. It's breathtaking with 4 different seasons and environments that the game offers you to explore. Different biome has its unique feeling into it. Just take your time to explore every corner you go through, there are many surprises that won't let you down.

Just like the old Metro games, your playstyle and your decisions dictates the outcome of the game. In my opinion, the karma system in this game is one of the best I've seen so far in all of the games I've ever played. You will see the consequence of your decisions during mid game and at the end as well.

There's no need to say about the soundtracks. They're insanely good and fits the theme well.

I got the bad ending even though I tried hard to get the good one. There are things that the game won't tell you but you have to think carefully before you act. Therefore, I'm still working on my second playthough because I missed so many things on my first playthrough and I'm trying to get the good ending this time.

Thank you 4A! Solid 9/10.

Edit:
Update to my review after more hours at troubleshooting.
Turns out, it was DX12 mode ruining everything! Well, mostly everything. I still have the issue with the cloud saves (Basically, turn them off before gaming... You risk getting your auto save corrupted.). But the frequent crashes have been resolved by switching from DX 12 to DX 11 mode. Which sucks... I can understand that this shouldn't make much difference, from a user perspective, but it is still something I would expect to have in working order, but alas, it is not.

But coming back to a review on the game, the storyline is solid, the characters are great, the voice actors (EN) are great, if i tad cliched at times. I'm now waiting before moving on to the DLCs, but the way the story is closed is satisfactory. The limited replayability is a factor, but this is a story based FPS, so it's to be expected.

All in all, after addressing the constant crashes, I'm now quite satisfied with the experience, and I recommend this game (as long as you don't suffer the same excruciating experience with the constant crashes as I did.)

[h1]Metro: Exodus. The third chapter in the Metro series.[/h1]

Making a new part of the Metro is a difficult task. Making a new part such that it was more successful than the previous two is an almost impossible task. In this part of the trilogy, players will leave the dark world of the Moscow metro and get to the surface in order to board the Aurora train and explore the regions of the nuclear post-apocalypse of Russia, and together complete the adventure of Artyom, Anya and his friends.

Graphics and sound have improved significantly compared to the previous two parts. The linear level design is mixed with a small open world, and a more advanced weapon and equipment modification system has been introduced.

The story is short, but it makes you think about life. Namely, about the horrors of nuclear war and all the consequences that follow from it. When every day survivors worry about how to live on. People go crazy not knowing where to find water, food, medicine and even some temporary habitat. When there is almost no living place left in the world and everything is covered with some creatures, and radiation exceeding the norm several times on the surface.

I also recommend you to take DLC Two Colonels. It tells the whole ins and outs of the history of Novosibirsk in a concise manner. The turning point is very exciting, and the ending will not leave you indifferent either.

This is a perfect example of direct and environmental storytelling. Putting the absolutely enthralling plot of the game aside, its presentation is immaculate. Through every biome you encounter you are able to infer a massive amount of what is going on in the area just by taking a look around before anything even happens (let me not start on the outstandingly gorgeous visuals from every inch and corner of the game). The characters let the story unveil itself at a smooth pace, all with unique personalities and connections to yours and the rest of the crew. The pacing of the game feels like it is properly fast, given your in-game circumstances, while also not removing from the game play, creating an intensely immersive adventure that I truly think is the best presented in the last half-decade.

TL;DR: If you are down and jiggy with story driven games and are also down and jiggy with well integrated gameplay, I could not recommend anything else nearly as strong as I do Exodus, or the entire Metro series if I'm being honest with myself.

Honestly, Metro: Exodus was one of, if not the worst PC game experience from a Triple A studio I ever had. The game was beyond buggy. Just to name a few bugs, I clipped through game platforms and died to fall damage, had NPCs bug out and duplicate themselves in cutscenes, world geometry breaking leaving grass and objects floating midair, Stealth being a nightmare due to NPCs being able spot you through walls and worst of all, several crashes that not only corrupted my auto-saves but somehow corrupted my game settings and control layout just to name a few. I am genuinely surprised that the game is in such a state even nearly four years after its launch with the developers/publishers seemingly prioritizing adding Ray-Tracing instead of fixing critical bugs. The story is nothing special and only occasionally comes close to that of Metro: 2033 and Metro Last Light but it undermines the impact of those games. Gameplay can't seem to figure itself out since numerous game features just get tossed in only to get removed in the following chapters. My final opinion is to play the previous games of the series and leave this watered down, buggy, sandbox cash grab game behind.

I'v wanted to play Exodus sense release but was held back by a lousy CPU, and lack of time later on. Finally got around to picking it up and playing it on a machine that could manage it, I played through Metro 2033 and Last Light on Ranger Hardcore with as little hud as possible and enjoyed them greatly.

So my approach to Exodus was the same, ranger hardcore no hud - on paper a good idea until I discovered they added a slew of new interaction keys , I was like on the third level before I figured out how to pass time. With that in mind that is the place I am coming from with this review.

At its core, Exodus is amazing - it builds on the world of Metro continuing the story and it is a good story at that (I shed a itty bitty spartan tear near the end there), the gunplay is essentially about the same with some improvements on sound design while making some maligned weapons central to gameplay while others are instantly all but forgotten.  Unfortunately it is held back from being a over all amazing game by crippling issues that the previous games laugh at.

The worst was getting to the end of the third level (Caspian) died and all three autosaves were tied to that tower, and each and every one would load into a fatal error on load and crash the game. This meant I had to start the chapter over and do the entire thing from scratch.

Now having the game on the hardest difficulty is intended to create a challenge, but in Exodus this only leads to frustration as enemies headshot you from across the map with a sub machinegun or shotgun (instant death), have xray vision and regularly and reliably see you through walls - sometimes even shooting you through solid objects too. Once they discover you they will probably never lose track of you again, that xray+night vision eyeballs means no matter how well you are hidden they will probably shoot at you. This is particularly frustrating on the Caspian level, you also encounter heavily armored gatlin wielding enemies near the very end of the previous level and a couple times in the caspian level (though you can catch one unaware and disable him) these guys can instantly spin up their gatlin gun (unlike you) and track your forehead at all times.  Stealthing around knocking guys out has always been my metro go-to approach, in Exodus you can randomly have enemies you cant knock out which is super frustrating especially on levels where no-kill is the best way to make your crew happy.

Coming out of Last Light and into Exodus the change in personalities of Anna and Miller is startling, with Anna losing her cold sniper vibe for a  house wife constantly worrying and that occasionally shoots at things approach. Miller went from a commanding presence to Mister Magoo, and somehow falling into many of the 'russian career soldier' trope that is universally made fun of in movies.

------

Overall I did enjoy my time in Exodus, and would recommend it - but there are no excuses for a game that has been out this long to have such crippling (gameplay) issues.

Metro Exodus is a solid sequel to the original games, carrying over the tense atmosphere and desolate, beautiful isolation of the post-apocalyptic setting, while transporting the player to an open world setting. The graphics are absolutely beautiful, and the pacing of the game encourages exploration outside of your main goals, without punishing the player for taking long moments to take in the landscape. You will fight various monsters and armed humans, and you have the option of going non-lethal stealth towards human enemies. The gunplay is solid, combat and utility items felt satisfying to use (as in throwing knives, finding a night vision upgrade etc) and the game was largely bug-free for me.

If you liked the original stalker games, this is as close as it gets. It's my understanding some of the devs with 4a even worked on the original stalker games with gsc. Exodus feels like a lived-in world, although unlike stalker there is a lot more plot, central hub w/ npc type stuff. Rather than the more isolating feel of stalker, where you might come upon a group of cheeki breekis around a campfire, but are otherwise alone in the zone. Nonetheless, the writing and voice acting are well done, so the plot and cutscene sections still feel pretty cool. 

In an unfathomably cool move, the devs have recently released extremely powerful modding tools for this game, which will allow modders to create new amazing content for this game. Part of the reason the original stalker games are my favorite games ever is that the modding community has kept them alive, with graphical and gameplay overhauls as well as total conversions and various kinds of new content. I could say the same about other popular moddable games, like bethesda hits Skyrim and Fallout 4. 

Have you ever finished an rpg, and felt a kind of nostalgia for that experience? Wished you could wipe your memory and start again? Mods bring back that magical immersion, that sense of wonder that makes games feel really worth your time. 

Opening the door for modders means that this game is now all but guaranteed to age like fine wine, and any problems one might have with the base game will become moddable as well- for example, an "arachnophobe" mod could be made that removes the spooky spiders from your playthrough. Just a basic, small example. 

It's also currently on sale for 7.50$ which is nuts. I'd say it's worth full price of 30 bucks, and any sale is just icing on the cake. The game is pretty accessible, so even if you've never played stalker or the original games I would recommend it. Just keep in mind you will want to explore every nook and cranny, play it safe and pick off enemies rather than rush in. Hardcore/ranger difficulty is available for those who want a greater challenge. Enjoy!

The game is excellent. Takes the already existing Metro formula and makes it even greater by adding open world exploration, weather and daytime/nighttime cycles, and basic crafting, adding a very much needed extra layer to scavenging without going overkill (just 2 materials), also giving you a lovely backpack to craft and adapt to different situations such as engagement distance or stealth, all on the go.

That said, the game did give me some serious headaches. Got soft-locked on Volga and almost had to restart the entire game because of a subtle bug, and in the end I haven't even finished it because it constantly crashes on the loading screen of one of the latest chapters (Enhanced Edition). I'm still leaving a positive review because it's just that good, all my bug-less playtime has been really fun.

Word of advice: just play the regular edition, specially if you're playing with a Radeon graphics card. There seems to be something about DirectX 12 (default and only option for Enhanced Edition) which makes it prone to crashes. Regular edition allows you to change it to DX11 and that's that.

Pacing can feel a bit off compared to the other Metro games with the change to an open world. Didn't bother me but YMMV. Exodus looks fantastic especially with the Enhanced Edition if you have the hardware to run it. Game-play still feels great and there's a good amount of content for repeat play-throughs.

[h1][u][b]🥕🍅🥬🥦 𝓕𝓾𝓵𝓵 𝓡𝓮𝓿𝓲𝓮𝔀 🍆🥔🌽🥑[/b][/u][/h1]

Some time after the events at D6, Artyum becomes emboldened to prove if anything has survived outside the Metro. He eventually gets his answer from some early story reveals that I won't spoil and the Spartans special forces team fleeing the Metro on a functional train. This has both story and game-play ramifications that makes this a fairly different experience compared to the prior entries.

The Metro series has never looked better with a good amount of environmental variety with each train stop. A4 Games did a really good job of keeping each map feeling fresh and not the same broken concrete look each time. Enemy types are also helped by this which was a welcomed detail to find out. Animations continue to be well done and textures, shadows, lighting all look great. Music, voice acting & motion capture also keep that high bar of quality and you can always switch to Russian for that extra level of immersion.

Levels aren't linear anymore but instead are now open maps to navigate, however to be clear this isn't S.T.A.L.K.E.R. or Fallout 4, this has clear points of interest to head to with the occasional side objectives to check. There's little benefit to explore if you don't have a clear plan and would likely be a waste of limited resources that could jeopardize the rest of your play-through. 

Speaking of resources, you no longer have to care about using your ammo as currency. That's been totally scrapped and now everything revolves around crafting ammo with resources you find in each level. Make sure you check corpses and any abandoned containers laying around. You can sometimes find gear upgrades as well but most of those will be through side quests. Be sure to approach to all NPCs at any story change to trigger dialogue in order to potentially get more quests.

I can't recall if Last Light had this but Exodus has in essence a morality/choice system. Making certain story choices and performing specific combat actions will determine who sticks around on your team as you progress in the story. This will affect some cut-scenes, endings & achievements. Without spelling everything out, you need to choose of either killing everyone or trying to spare\save everyone. Even outside of that, you might miss a few things because of specific quest conditions so maybe be a bad guy 1st and save the guide for your paragon run. 

I will also forewarn you that there is no manual save system with only 1 quick save slot available for the whole game. The game will periodically save as well as usually saving before a major scripted cut-scene. This will be something to keep in mind during a hardcore run or a save everyone run where a few mistakes can ruin everything.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

3 years past since Metro Exodus has been released, half years later has been released first DLC “The Two Colonels”, and six months later has been released second DLC “Sam’s Story”.
I really like the Metro saga and have played 2033 for 3 times and Last Light twice.
The game went wide, game mechanics have increased, but the beginning of the story is weak. Picture is same good as in Redux versions, but not wonderful. If you play Enhanced Edition you may see better performance in graphics.

[h1] Main plot [/h1]

From the very beginning something went wrong, Colonel Menikov is one of the main characters in the game, senior in rank and puts spokes in the wheels from the very beginning. Although logically he should, on the contrary, solve problems, and not create them. This character is written disgustingly in this game, and [spoiler] his death at the end of the game did not touch me, there was only a question - why it was not possible to write him in this game much better, to make more drama at the end [/spoiler]. Another thing in the very beginning, which has no explanation is - [spoiler] point-blank shot in Artem [/spoiler] , we just need to accept it. Another question - why other characters stopped to introduce our opponents? In the first game 2033 each big opponent was introduced, and I had a real scare to see a Librarian. In this game we see [spoiler] a flock of King-Kongs at the end in Novosibirsk, place where they shouldn’t be at all [/spoiler] , and nobody told us about them.

Everything else is good - new locations, we finally may see something more then Moscow’s Metro. Metro’s world expansion did really good. The construction of the plot and the alignment of locations looks very harmonious - the first half of the game is dark, we are smoothly brought to an end with the history of the Moscow metro in the middle of the game. Straight after it we have desert with brightness overexposure, and it looks harmonious as we have a new mission.

As in previous games we have two game endings: good and bad. Despite not a very good beginning of the game, the final looks really well done.

[h1] Open world and Mechanics [/h1]

In Metro Exodus we have different locations, which do not restrict the player's movements. So you may explore the world, and then complete quest tasks. Buy the way we have additional tasks, which are marked on the map with question marks. But we still not able to explore fully the destroyed Moscow. In fact, we get an imitation of an open world, we don’t have the opportunity in returning to previous locations and complete additional tasks. But nevertheless it is very good that we have the opportunity to explore the universe more.

Gaming mechanics have really increased, now we don’t have gun shops and bullet currency, in Metro Exodus all weapon improvements may be found only during battles, or after doing additional quests.

[b] Extra Information [/b]
At the time I was writing the review, have learned some additional information about the game. During main company we may have other ways in gameplay, if you rush and kill everybody on your way, then NPCs would be aggressive, and you will have all time shooter. But in other way, if you use stealth and don’t kill opponents, then some NPCs wouldn’t be aggressive, and may help in few questions. I personally used rush options mostly, but it looks as a good bonus for those, who use stealth.

[h1] The Dark side of the Exodus [/h1]

So what’s wrong with Metro Exodus?
[i] Open World [/i]
An Open World for the Metro game is a good step forward, but in my opinion one thing is missing - mini map. I do understand, that game wants to go more in realism, and it’s really good, but if you make a bullet counter in bottom right corner, it’s not a big problem to put a map in to right corner. Yes, developers gave us an ability to have a compass (but you need to find it, first of all), which always shows you the way to main missions - so if you are lost in the corridor this compass will show you “move straight, then turn left into exactly this door”. But it doesn’t work like this. 

If you want to visit an additional mission - you need to stop and open a map, but the game doesn’t pause, opponents still may hit you. And at the same time - game makes an ammunition deficit, very similar to Resident Evil. So it’s really easily accessible situation - small amount of ammo, a pack of monsters is chasing you, and you are lost in the forest.

[i] Technical problems [/i]
During my passage - bugs and crashes became synonymous to Metro Exodus. Although my computer meets the recommended requirements, each hour during large-scale shooters - game has crashed. In the middle of the game I have saved my progress, while the main character was in the car, and later when I launched the game it crashed straight after loading. When I was driving the car and stopped to check the map - the camera moved to an incomprehensible angle, and there was something like a third-person view. In the last chapter - boat didn’t want to turn, and only from third loading I had a chance to turn left. And this is a small fraction of those bugs that occurred during the game. At the middle of gameplay I caught myself thinking that I have to adapt to the game - to the way she behaves. So I can’t relax and play for my own pleasure, because I have to watch my every step so that the game doesn’t crash or break.

And the biggest questions had raised by the inscription - “ [u] Autosave data has been corrupted. Use the Chapters section to select available episodes.  Some saved levels cannot be loaded. The saved game information appears to be corrupted. Do you want to burn the game by replacing corrupted data? [/u] ”. I started the game on one computer, and wanted to continue on another one via Steam Cloud saves, but Metro Exodus didn’t give me such ability. Whose problem is it - Metro’s or Steam’s, have no idea, but it was the first and only error for all time while I was using Steam Cloud. By searching additional information about this problem I have seen that error with savings is a very common problem in case of Metro Exodus, mentioned by many users, not only for PC gamers but as well for console users.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
In general - main plot is good even taking into account some inconsistencies and enraging characters. The world is built very well, locations are memorable, and the feeling of innovation does not fade away until the very end.
Biggest problems are with bugs and crashes - 3 years past since Metro Exodus has been released and game developers haven’t fixed all this issues. For example 2 years past since Cyberpunk has been and today it’s wonderful game without all those problems, that have been at the release. In return, we were given two DLCs by 4A Games. In my understanding, DLCs and bug-fixes with optimization are not interchangeable, taking into account that DLCs must be purchased in addition. If there is no such technical problems in Enhanced Edition version, then why regular Metro Exodus is still available to purchase?
In general, the attitude of developers to the game and their customers after the release is very frustrating.

 [h1] One more thing - Sam and Colonel [/h1]

The first DLC is “The Two Colonels”, we are revealed the history of underground life in Novosibirsk, which has touched upon in the last location of main Company. The duration of this DLC is 2 hours. I really enjoyed this DLC. In such small duration developers created a beautiful story that surpassed the main game in terms of plot, emotions and richness.

Sam’s Story - is the second DLC, which takes 5 hours to beat (main game is 10 hours to compare). Not a bad story came into plus extra location and several endings. Need to know - this DLC has same technical issues, as were in the main company.

A confused, buggy mess that completely misses everything that made the first two great. 

PROS:
-Amazing music
-The last level of the game (which was similar to the previous two games). 
-Metro 2033 (redux) was good, go play that instead.
-Metro Last Light (redux) was good, go play that instead.

NEUTRAL:
-Voice acting is hit or miss. Katya and her daughter are particularly bad, but several characters have problems with awkward forced (and inconsistent) accents. However, there is a ton of voice acting and some are well done.
-The "Enhanced Edition" supposedly has great graphics (if you can get it to run).  I have an RTX 2070 but could not get playable FPS in enhanced edition even with all settings on low/off. 

CONS:
-The plot. Metro Exodus completely abandons every plot point that was built up in the first 2 games. 
-Weak map design: the majority of the game takes place outside in bright, large, and open areas - exactly the opposite of the atmosphere that made the first two games great. 
-"Open world" elements are contrived and pointless. There is literally no reason to explore the world. The only thing you might find are some weapon "upgrades" (ie larger magazine, better stability barrel, etc) or generic collectables. 
-You can only use 1 of each type of equipment. You will never use any of the other gear, so why bother to look for it?  
-Generic meaningless collectibles:  I found "audio tapes" and "postcards" - neither appears to give you anything for finding them. The postcards have no lore and I have not seen anywhere to find the list of the ones you've already collected.
-Nothing to do in the open world. There are some fuseboxes in human sections that turn out the lights...yay...
-Extremely verbose NPCs. The idea behind having lots of voice acting to give life and background to the world is wonderful - but this is a textbook example of failed execution. Various NPCs throughout the game will talk.....and talk.......and talk....... but not say anything of value. Neither adding to the lore of the game world nor to the gameplay as a player. They just say endlessly gibberish. 
-No fast travel
-1 vehicle that stays where you left it (only on the Caspian level).  
-BUGGY BUGGY BUGGY
--Corruption bugs: half the time when I load the game, it tells me that my file has been corrupted. This would normally worry me, but it doesn't seem to actually do anything as my save game still loads with no changes. 
--AI bugs: enemies will see you through the ground/walls; being in the "dark" will make you totally invisible at times, and have absolutely no effect at other times; going the exact same route will result in different AI behavior (e.g. sometimes they see you, sometimes they dont). 
--Map bugs: after spotting camps ("?" on the map) and going to one, even after looting the area, the map would not update (and continued to show a "?")
--Crashing bugs: one particular sequence on the Caspian level constantly crashed the game. I had to crouch and look directly at the ground while navigating the area to get past it.
--Car/Journal bugs:  if you open your journal while in a vehicle, your head will go through the roof and you can't see out the windshield correctly anymore

One of the first things to hit you is the horrible graphics. The art direction is off-putting. It doesn’t help that the character models are also terribly made.
The environments are bland and plain. Even without the terrible graphic design, Metro Exodus looks like a cheap-looking indie game.

The Metro Exodus audio design is terrible as well.
The game’s atmosphere is ruined with the sounds of music playing like some awful soundtrack in a porn movie.

The bosses and especially the bosses with multiple enemies makes the bosses hard to fight. I know because I’ve fought several.
There is also a terrible checkpoints system.
The game gets confusing when it comes to the world building. It’s difficult to understand the geography and the characters.

Speaking of characters, you have to put up with some annoying voice acting. You’ll have to let it go.
The voice acting isn’t bad, but it’s not great either. One character comes across as un-fun, annoying, and bland. You’ll have to decide whether that character’s voice is funny or annoying.

The most annoying is Metro Exodus’s protagonist Artyom. Artyom is like a wannabe John Wick. He has an attitude and won’t stop.
The end result is that Artyom is not fun to play.
He is all over the place, as if he were daydreaming. I don’t know how it’s possible to build a game around a wannabe character that acts like a maniac.
With all the issues that were built into Metro Exodus, it’s a little too much to take.

Even with all the issues, I can see the potential. The world is visually stunning. It’s dark and scary at times, and it’s dark and scary in almost every frame.

I also forgot to tell you, it's a first person shooter game. I know, i know, i'm shocked as well.

The game itself is good when it works. I'd say it's worth about £20. 

My first playthrough of the standard edition at release suffered from a couple of hard crashes that required patches to fix, but I was able to complete the game and enjoyed doing so. This edition seems to be significantly more buggy. I've had 7 or 8 hard crashes, needed to load historic saves to get around buttons not working, alt-tabbing seems to break the game at seemingly random times, and a number of the animations are still broken, for example reading a map whilst in a vehicle causes the camera to be stuck in the roof. 

The game itself is pretty fun though it suffers from being 'open world'. Part of the suspense and charm of the original games was the the feeling of being confined within the metro. Where searching for upgrades and sneaking around enemies left you with baited breath in the original, here you spend most of the time crossing expansive areas with nothing to do but look at the pretty landscape. Then it crashes and you have to do it all over again.

There is also no suspense in this game unless you play on the hardest difficulty and even then it's more frustration than suspense. You'll probably spend a good 20 hours playing this game and you'll enjoy it, though I doubt very many people ever play it a second time. The original games are still excellent experiences but if you want a similar open world Metro game then may I suggest the Stalker series instead.

Since I've finished Metro 2033, Metro: Last Light and read Sapkowsky's novel, I've been wanting to play this game. Back in 2019., my PC was too weak to run it, but after an upgrade I finally bought it and let me tell you, it's beautiful.
First few games had this grim, dark gameplay focused on atmosphere, with rare moments to relax. I loved it, to be honest. There was something special about the fact Moscow felt so alien and scary, you *couldn't wait* to return to Metro's safety. Even Metro tunnels, as dangerous and scary as they were, still felt like home. Now, in Exodus, you embark on an entirely different journey. You leave Moscow.
Without going into spoilers too much, I'll just say you visit different areas, explore different places, bond with your crew A LOT and find adventure along the way. But fear not, because it still retains what made it a horror game first place. A lot of quest areas are still creepy (arachnophobes, be ware), there are few scattered jumpcares, and the stealth is an important part of the gameplay just as before. Game retains "good/bad" ending, and it mostly depends on whether you've managed to sneak past enemies, since murdering  NPC' s the game considers innocent counts towards the bad ending. Still, it does not take away from enjoyment. You can freely kill bandits, thugs, basically anyone who wields gun (only very specific areas require you to spare everyone). I'm halfway through the game, and so far only two areas were like this, so it's not really a big deal. 
There are, also, some very calming, relaxing moments. Taking your time on Aurora feels like being home. You can sit down, have a drink, take a smoke and talk with your friends and your love, Anna. You can listen to them, see their own stories unfold in front of your eyes and it's just as great as it sounds. Games like this truly give me hope developers can still make a game that's both inspiring, tells a great story and a game that's fun for one thing a game should be: a escape from a harsh reality, an exodus.

Pros:
-Incredibly immersive. Little touches like having to duct tape a broken gas mask or wipe the spores from your visor really help make the game feel alive.
-Weapons have to be maintained and cleaned, inventory screen doesn't pause time making it incredibly tense. In a fun way!
-Ai is surprisingly good. If you encounter enemies alone, they'll be more cautious, and they'll be more aggressive in packs. Humans will react to your performance, they'll lose confidence as you reduce their numbers and can ultimately surrender.
-Compelling narrative that embraces a human element lacking in most games. For a post apocalyptic action shooter, this game is about loving life and humanity, having hope for the future, and being willing to fight for it.
-I really love these segments between chapters where they're just riding the train until you proceed with the story. You can walk about, take in the sights and sounds, rest and socialize with your companions, even play guitar or pull the horn on the train. Truly a wonderful touch and one of my favorite parts of the game.

Cons:
-A game about survival immersion should really have food/water management, at least.
-Slippery controls, sometimes feels like piloting a hovercraft over ice rather than a human being with solid footing. You will slide off platforms and bounce off small bumps until you get accustomed to these physics & stop trying to do cool things.
-Cinematic priority, sometimes your actions don't matter because the game has a pre-scripted scene prepared. 
-Buggy. Really kills the mood when the games trying to be all cinematic and cool while objects are flying around and you're being attacked while casually locked in a cutscene animation.
-Ledge detection is terrible. Expect to stand in front of ledges jumping over and over until the game finally recognizes what you're trying to do and climbs you up.
-This is NOT an open world game, they're just large, linear levels with multiple pathways. It's not open world in philosophy either, expect plenty of invisible walls and action restrictions.
Noice.

Well, I think this game is hit or miss.  FWIW, I finished, loved, and replayed S.T.A.L.K.E.R. (that is the last time I am typing all of those periods).  Also, many, many years ago I finished the original Metro on a PC.

I now play on a Mac.

Like STALKER, it's "Eastern European" so...
1. It's plot is obtuse which sometimes feels like high art and other times like gibberish.
2. It has the bare minimal "train/learn" level.  You get the keyboard command once for a second or so and then the game assumes that A. you saw it, and B. you'll remember it under pressure that comes almost immediately.  You'll be making a different plan fairly often during the load screen.  Fairly steep and Darwinian.  Even more so than what I remember of STALKER or the original Metro (which, IMO had some legendarily difficult ambush moments).

So that all makes it different than the typical "Western" AAA title.  Which can be refreshing and maddening at the same time.  

Now what's worse.  This feels like a console port.  Or coded on a common-platform for the reduced control set of a console.  So many buttons are "triple overloaded" meaning every button does one thing if merely pressed, another thing if pressed-and-held, and yet a third thing if double-pressed.  Given that the game is "Eastern European" and designers from that "school-of-thought" love their everything manual with this button to reload, that button pressed once to fire, that button held to charge the weapon, etc., etc., you will find yourself accidentally pressing-and-holding when you intended a double-press (or vice versa).  And dying because of it.

So I tended to give-up and wait for the reload screen when getting ambushed+mauled by melee baddies.  I am a pretty "set-in-my ways" stand-off + pie the corner FPS gamer.  IMO, you need to be excellent at stand-off cover-based shooting and clever about tip-toeing into the "baddie alert radius" very carefully.

Would I buy it again?  Probably not a full price.  But it was on sale.  Still, it's not COD.

Post-finish edit:  Okay I finished.  Got the bad ending.  And now I sit wondering whether to play to strive for the good ending and play the DLC.  Truthfully, I am probably not going to bother.  FWIW.

Metro Exodus is the latest, and probably last game in the Metro trilogy. Here, you continue playing as Artyom, as he and his crew left Moscow behind in search of a better place to live, free of radiation. They traveled to several locations across Eastern Europe and Central Asia, encountering different types of people and a variety of landscapes, such as slavers on a dried sea and grown-up summer camp kids in a lush valley. It's a welcome change of setting from the previous Metro games, which has very little differences in people you meet and locations you visit.

While promoted as an open-world game, its kinda hard to consider it as one. The maps are bigger and less linear compared to the previous games, but not a "true" open-world, like lets say, Borderlands. Some maps are linear, but bigger and there can be alternate paths. Some other maps you can free roam, but most of these areas are visited anyway since the missions are like round-trips along the map, making free-roam kinda pointless, and there's no fast travel and you cannot return to previous levels. There are no secret sidequests or unique, powerful weapons in hidden corners of the map. The most you'll get is probably extra loot or collectibles, which usually aren't that far off from the main path.

What I think is a major improvement is the portrayal of characters. Due to the "road trip" nature of the game, most of the characters you meet either stays with you, and those who don't usually plays a major part in the chapter they're in. It makes them more memorable, unlike the previous games where sometimes I am left wondering if I have met this character before because they appeared once, and disappears until we meet them again in later levels. You can also hang around them in levels or in the train where they keep talking with you or with each other, sometimes telling important info about themselves, or the place you're in.

A new feature in this game is the crafting and customization system, which replaces the military ammo currency. There are no merchants in this game, but you can craft ammo and consumables by yourself. And for weapon modifications, they are found on dropped weapons, which you can keep and install yourself. You can change your weapon with any other you picked up while on the train. Makes it easier to make powerful guns, without worrying about the currency or hoping an enemy drops a good one.

For me, there is only one problem with this game, the "saves corrupt" notice. Despite that, it seems like an empty warning, since if you choose not to overwrite your saves you can continue your playthrough without any problem. But I really wish there were more open-world maps, since most chapters are linear ones, and some more sidequests would be nice. And maybe a more detailed journal entry regarding those, since some additional objectives are mentioned in dialogue only and you could probably forget.

Metro Exodus is a pretty major improvement over the previous titles, in graphics, atmosphere, level variation, and character portrayal.  If you enjoy the previous Metro games, get this one and finish Artyom's journey. If you're a fan of post-apocalyptic games or the STALKER franchise, give the Metro games a try, but do not start with this one as this is the end. It comes bundled with an Enhanced Edition version, but that one requires a strong PC and doesn't have cloud saves.

A fun game. I really like how they take their time to tell the story and establish characters with long opportunities of dialog if you want to sit through them.  It makes a really immersive world.
The game is very fun and realistic, and its full of fun achievements to try to unlock. Although its not very realistic because its a buggy game its still very fun, and has its humor moments.

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]

I recommend this game but only if you haven't played another Metro game before. It gives the full 'Metro' experience and it has all of the new things this game has to offer. If you have played another Metro I don't think this game adds anything new or special.

[h1] Review [/h1]

I will try to summarize it in different parts: Combat, Story and Mechanics. Last part I think is necessary to mention because it's a part which I personally don't like.

[h2] Combat [/h2]
The combat is pretty interesting in this game, not really too challenging but just enough for casual single player experience.

[h3] Weapon gunsmith [/h3]
Very good combat and very interesting gun mechanics. I don't remember how it was done in Last Light (that was too long ago for me) but I guess this was a bit different. The guns were interesting to tweak and they didn't  go the route whatever you find new is automatically better. There are some downsides to some attachments, but not too much. They could've done more in this department.

[h2] Story [/h2]
Story wise I don't really liked it that much. I played it at English and I really got irritated by the Russian accent while talking English (with occasionally a Russian word in it). 

[h3] Characters [/h3]
Anna's constant hugging and asking if you're OKAY got very annoying at one point. I know it's probably if you're more immersed you get attached to the character but I kinda lost that because of the annoying voice acting. 
The characters are OKAY-ish, I don't feel there's anything to write home about. I don't really feel like the characters stand out that much. I don't feel Duke, or Danish or whatever they're called have any unique personalities. Just NPC's that are at a certain point in the game.

[h3] Cutscenes [/h3]
There are A LOT of cutscenes in this game and they get really annoying because you can't skip them at all. They're all set in the in game world and the game developers didn't find a way to skip these apparantly. Very annoying if you're doing another walkthrough (which is needed for some achievements). If you've seen it once you don't really need to see them again. 

[h2] Mechanics [/h2]
The constant 'E' holding and 'R' holding (for weapons) is extremely annoying after a while. Some things can really be improved upon. It almost feels the game has some kind of limitations in it (game engine perhaps?) so a lot of animations need to be forced into place (crawling, going through tight areas etc).

[h3] Quick Time Events [/h3]
If you like them, cool, you'll have fun, but in this game there are so many of them, and they're all so predictable. I can't count how many times Arythom fell of something and get saved or have to stab a creature. After a while it gets frustating.

[h3] Movement [/h3]
The movement of your character is like floating into the air. While running you sometimes just float in the air and you get some airtime and it's very easy to get fall damage. Sometimes even from very low altitude. Your character forgots what gravity is at times and he just goes all over the place. Sometimes it feels like you're stuck at very weird areas. This is not something I personally like and it's very, very annoying. 

Overall the movement and the way the character just runs or walks needs improvement in a further installment. It's not 'clunky'per say, but too 'floaty' if you catch my drift.

I like the game, but it has some issues. For one, I think there are way too many mechanics that exist just for the sake of "realism". Mechanics like having to clean your weapons, craft filters, fixing your gas mask, and charging your flashlight may be realistic, but I feel like they just hold the gameplay back. Luckily, you don't have to do these often, so they are just a minor annoyance. The level design also isn't always perfect. Most levels consist of you pulling a lever somewhere to move on (which isn't necessarily a bad thing), but often times levels are so dark with so little clarity it can be hard to even find the lever. Additionally, sometimes the game makes you do a bunch of running around to fetch stuff just to open a door, which isn't very fun. There's also some minor visual issues I found, but they're not a big deal. In the end, I liked pretty much everything else though so I recommend it.

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
Metro Exodus is a post-apocalyptic survival shooter developed by 4A Games and released in 2019. I've been a fan of the Metro series for a while now, so I was excited to jump into the third installment and see how it stacked up against the previous games.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
Metro Exodus builds upon the gameplay of its predecessors, with a focus on stealth, survival, and resource management. The controls are smooth and responsive, and the gameplay mechanics, such as the crafting and weapon customization systems, are well-implemented and add depth to the experience.
One of the standout features of Metro Exodus is its open-world environments, which offer a refreshing change of pace from the linear levels of the previous games. These environments are detailed and immersive, and there are a plethora of side missions and activities to discover. However, I did encounter some bugs and glitches during my playthrough, such as NPC characters getting stuck in the environment or weapons disappearing from my inventory. These issues weren't game-breaking, but they did detract from the overall experience.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
Metro Exodus follows the story of Artyom, a young man who embarks on a journey across the post-apocalyptic Russian wasteland in search of a new life. Along the way, he meets a diverse cast of characters and encounters various factions, each with their own motivations and agendas. The story is well-written and engaging, with plenty of twists and turns to keep you on the edge of your seat. The pacing is well-balanced, with a mix of action and slower, more reflective moments.

[h1]Graphics and Sound:[/h1]
Metro Exodus boasts impressive graphics that are a step up from the previous games in the series. The environments are visually stunning, with detailed textures and realistic lighting effects. The character models and animations are also top-notch. The sound design is equally impressive, with a haunting soundtrack and realistic sound effects that really immerse you in the world. The voice acting is solid, with strong performances from the main cast.

[h1]Replay Value:[/h1]
Metro Exodus has a decent amount of replay value, with multiple endings depending on the choices you make throughout the game. There are also various difficulty levels to challenge yourself with, as well as a New Game+ mode where you can carry over your upgrades from a previous playthrough. The open-world environments also encourage exploration, with hidden secrets and collectibles scattered throughout the world.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Overall, Metro Exodus is a solid addition to the Metro series and a great example of a survival shooter done right. The gameplay is engaging, the story is well-written, and the graphics and sound are top-notch. While there were a few bugs and glitches that detracted from the experience, they were few and far between and didn't ruin the game for me. If you're a fan of the Metro series or survival shooters in general, I would definitely recommend giving Metro Exodus a try.

Metro Exodus is the culmination of the Metro series and also it's the most ambitious installment so far. Exodus improves on everything good about the previous two games and adds to it. The narrative has a much more cinematic flair and has much more compelling characters compared to the previous games. The linearity is also stripped back as half of the levels take a semi-open-world approach, allowing for further exploration and side quests. This aspect is particularly balanced well since it doesn't double down on side quests and markers like a lot of AAA titles do. While it might seem that the grittiness of the previous games is stripped back, it doesn't shy away from creating an unforgiving environment and an engaging survival horror experience. This game is one of the best post-apocalyptic shooters yet and is a must-play for those who like the Half-Life and S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games.

I will say that I usually am not big into horror games, but this one struck a nice balance and doesn't rely on jump scares or cheap tactics. It's more about the settings and environment, which is really a key character throughout.

These games are often discounted way past what they are worth, so I'd recommend playing through the series if you have the time. If you don't just play through this one as it has the modern and polished. You don't necessarily have to play the first two for it to make sense, though I do encourage it.

As a lover of both books and all the games I went into this with high expectations, I was not disappointed for the most part. The story like the other games is rich and immersive. The world space and design is very impressive and I do admire that they went for a less linear experience for the main story.

BUT

Although I enjoyed this game and it's DLCs I do find myself at times yearning for the more scripted and linear formula that made Metro so enjoyable. This game has a mix of both open world sections and closed linear section. Both are great, but for me what makes Metro so enjoyable was the journey you experienced in the heavily scripted sections where the story telling is most pushed. I do feel that the characters and the relationships were an integral part of the game but I do also think that interactions were forced far more than they should be however It doesn't detract from the overall story experience.

Overall this game in my opinion is a great addition and it offers a lot to be enjoyed. If you want a story rich game then it worth a look at. My recommendation is the play all three games in order to see the development of the story.

The Metro series perhaps is the most immersive game of all the games I've played by far and this game is the best of all three. What an amazing conclusion to the trilogy. Feels great to finally be able to get out of Moscow and breathe fresh air. The crafting mechanic is the best thing that can happen to this game. Makes exploration so much better. Only bad thing I can say about this game is The Damir bug in the Caspian level (and hasn't been fixed as of this writing). You have to restart the whole level or use a hack to progress the game.

The concluding entry in the Metro story-line as of writing this review, in this instalment. We follow Artyom yet again, obsessed with discovering a world beyond the frozen lands of the radiated Moscow surface and the metro-system he calls home, it's a fruitless journey. He continuously comes home injured, clinging onto life, unfairly wasting the dwindling metro medical supplies to fuel himself for his next expedition. Until one day, he learns through a quite literal trial of fire, of the state of the rest of Russia. And through that discovery, the truth behind his wife's father, who is pulled on a journey with Artyom. And a handful of Spartans, the metro-systems guardians, who willingly explore unknown lands for a chance at a better life. 

Metro Exodus is an incredible, emotional, send-off to the world we've learned to love over the course of the last ten years. The visuals of the game are incredible, with beautiful view's of the Post-Apocalyptic world that we spend the entirety of the series in. With a vast range of levels, we see a wide range of scorching sand dunes, to cramped, dank swamps. Frozen over cities and breath-taking river look-out points. This may be one of the most detailed and awe-inspiring open-world games I've ever played. And for the cherry on-top, for the most part. Metro Exodus ran incredibly well, with great optimisation for all PC's. Granted you can't run it on a twenty year old laptop, but if you have a solid setup. The game will run incredibly well with minimal hiccups and not even losing out on too much at lower settings.

Game-play is similar to the first two games, although with some welcome additions and reworks to fit this one's new open-world style level system. With the introduction of an on-the-fly weapon modification system in the form of a tactical backpack. And while the idea of having to scavenge a barren wasteland for materials to upgrade and maintain weapons may sound annoying, the world is anything but barren. It is chock full of bandit camps, mini-adventures and dangerous zones to scavenge. I've played this game a few-times, and every time my journeys have been different to the last. In the form of random events and the changing day/night cycle and dynamic weather system. All-ways keeping you on your toes.

The story is just as quality as the first two, and even better, the relationship between Artyom and Anna is explored more than it was in Last Light. There are at times where the writing can be seen as clunky, weird, out of place, or other vague descriptors I can use. It's less objective driven than the first two, and more emotionally driven. Straying from the hopeless feel of 2033's campaign, and the Call-Of-Duty aesthetic of Last-Light's.

Audio is good, that's all I can really say. It has kept it's original style of music, with the grim orchestra's that are audible in every track. Con's? Bugs, there were quite a few in the twenty-one hours I've played, crashes, visual bugs, broken shaders, and an ominous black void that consumed my screen once. Boss fights are not at the same level of quality that is the rest of the game, simple shoot at it until it dies design. Not what I had expected from the Metro franchise, but with the context of it's trying development, it's understandable. 

In short, it's a emotionally charged send off to Artyom's story, and can stand as one of the very few successful video-game Trilogy's. My final rating is a strong 8.5/10.

Most immersive post apocalyptic sim ever. The level of detail and immersion is phenomenal and mind boggling. The game barely ever takes you out to some menu or whatever. You can find hundreds of other soulless post apocalyptic titles that have crowded Steam in recent years with skill trees, crafting, abilities and whatnot with a 30$ or so price tag but none of them seems to be an ACTUAL POST APOCALYPTIC experience like Metro Exodus which costs only 10$. This game proves that art, detail and great story-telling in video games are possible and are a massive success without having coop, loot boxes and micro-transactions that plagues gaming industry these days. Metro Exodus is a first-person shooter video game developed by 4A Games and published by Deep Silver. It is the third installment in the Metro video game trilogy based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's novels, following the events of Metro 2033 and Metro: Last Light. It released in 2019 for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4, Xbox One and Stadia and in 2020 for Amazon Luna. A Linux and macOS conversion was released in 2021. An enhanced version of the game released for Microsoft Windows on 6 May 2021, and was later released for PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S on 18 June 2021. The game received generally favorable reviews from critics and sold 6 million units by February 2022

Metro Exodus is set in the year 2035, one year after the events of Metro: Last Light, on a post-apocalyptic Earth that has been devastated by a nuclear war. The game continues the story from Metro: Last Light's "Redemption" ending. Similar to the previous two entries, the player assumes the role of Artyom, who flees the Moscow Metro and sets off on a continent-spanning journey with his allies to the far east, on a locomotive called the "Aurora". The story takes place over the course of one year, starting with a harsh nuclear winter in the Metro. Another major character, returning from the previous game and the book Metro 2035, is Anna - who is now Artyom's wife. Miller, Anna's father and leader of the Spartan Order, also returns from previous games and novels.

After the attack on D6, Artyom becomes disillusioned with the constant infighting and corruption within the Metro and leaves the Spartan Order. He soon becomes obsessed with proving that other human survivors exist outside of Moscow and makes numerous dangerous expeditions to the surface, much to Anna's concern and Miller's frustration. However, on one such expedition with Anna, they witness a working train running on the surface. Before they can follow it, they are captured by Hansa soldiers, along with a group of people who claim to be from outside of Moscow. The Hansa soldiers execute the other prisoners, and Artyom is shot and left for dead, taking Anna to their base. Surviving the gunshot, Artyom follows the soldiers to rescue Anna, and in the process inadvertently destroys a signal jammer that was blocking all communications going in and out of Moscow. Radio transmissions from all over the world begin to be picked up, and Artyom and Anna realise humanity has not gone extinct. They escape by stealing one of Hansa's locomotives, the Aurora, with the aid of a defected Hansa train engineer called Yermak.

As the train leaves, the Spartan Order moves in to retake it and are shocked and confused at Artyom and Anna's presence. Knowing that Hansa will have all of them put to death for knowing the truth, Miller concludes that the Spartans' best chance of survival is to flee Moscow. Once outside the city, he reveals to the others that while many of Russia's cities were bombed, the war did not end and NATO proceeded to occupy what was left of the nation. To prevent NATO from attacking Moscow, the Russian leadership decided to secretly jam all communications to make the outside world believe nobody had survived. They then receive a radio broadcast from Moscow Defense Command calling for survivors to rally at the "Ark", located at Mount Yamantau. Miller decides to head there, believing that the Ark is where the Russian government has rebuilt itself.

After crossing the cult-controlled Volga River, the Spartans reach the Yamantau base. They discover the base's service and construction crew have devolved into cannibals who lure survivors in with the false promise of safety. Artyom and the Spartans manage to fight their way out and escape, but Miller's faith in Russia is shattered when he discovers that the government never took refuge in Yamantau, nor survived the war, and thus the Spartans are left wondering what to do next. Using a map they recovered from Yamantau, they decide to travel to a satellite communication center near the Caspian Sea in the hopes of gaining access to a satellite to find habitable land to settle. At the dried up remains of the Caspian Sea, the Spartans steal water and fuel from the local bandits while obtaining an updated satellite map.

As the Spartans continue on their journey, Anna begins to cough up blood, fearing the cause was accidentally breathing poison gas during the journey. They decide to scout a nearby taiga forest valley to see if it is suitable to settle. While scouting the forest, Artyom is caught between two rival survivor factions, and he discovers that the dam protecting the valley from radiation is on the verge of failing, making the area uninhabitable. Artyom returns to the train to learn Anna's condition has worsened. The Spartans detour to the heavily-irradiated city of Novosibirsk, the closest location where an antidote may be found.

Miller and Artyom decide to head into the city alone to search for the antidote despite the risk. They enter the Novosibirsk Metro and find a young boy named Kirill, one of the last of the Novosibirsk survivors, who explains that his father left on a mission to obtain a map marking the location of a clean, habitable area. Miller and Artyom split up, with Miller going to find the map and Artyom searching for the antidote. He manages to recover the antidote, but is gravely wounded by a mutant and absorbs a heavy dose of radiation. Artyom, Miller, and Kirill return to the train with the map and the antidote, but Miller dies of radiation poisoning on the way back after using a dose of anti-radiation serum meant for himself to save Artyom. The rest of the Spartans donate their own blood to give Artyom a critical blood transfusion. Anna is cured with the antidote and with the map, the Spartans settle on the shores of Lake Baikal, which is completely free from radiation.

Artyom's ultimate fate depends on the choices the player made during the journey; In the bad ending, Artyom dies from the radiation poisoning, and the Spartans and a grieving Anna hold a funeral for him and Miller while Artyom's and Miller's spirits awaken on a dilapidated version of the Aurora, remaining in the ghostly purgatory for eternity. In the good ending, Artyom survives. Miller is buried and Artyom is selected to take his place as leader of the Spartan Order. Now with a home free from radiation, Artyom decides to return to Moscow and reveal the truth of the world to the survivors of the Metro.

The Two Colonels
While Artyom goes to find the cure for Anna's illness in Novosibirsk, Miller begins retracing the steps of Kirill's father Colonel Vyacheslav (Slava) Khlebnikov to find the satellite map. One year prior, Khlebnikov works as a soldier protecting the Novosibirsk Metro while raising Kirill. Meanwhile, the Novosibirsk Metro government, OSKOM, makes plans to evacuate the Metro but there isn't enough anti-radiation serum to protect the entire population. As a result, OSKOM begins forcibly confiscating serum from the populace, causing civil unrest. Civil war soon breaks out in the Metro, forcing Khlebnikov to defend OSKOM headquarters from the rebels. However, General Anatoliy Vinogradov (Tolya) deploys poison gas during the battle, killing almost everybody in the station. When Khlebnikov confronts him, Vinogradov (Tolya) reveals that OSKOM leadership has already taken what serum is left and fled, deciding to flood the Metro with poison gas to mercy kill the rest of the population. However, bitter that he was left behind, Vinogradov (Tolya) orders his men to destroy the OSKOM evacuation train before committing suicide. With no other choice, Khlebnikov descends into a mutant-infested bunker to retrieve the map leading to Lake Baikal. He finds the map, but succumbs to radiation poisoning after losing his serum dose. In the present, Miller enters the bunker and finds Khlebnikov's body and the map.

I adore the Metro series of games, and Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition is no exception. This latest installment in the post-apocalyptic series takes you on an epic journey across the ruins of Russia, and the enhanced edition brings the game to new heights with the addition of ray tracing.

In Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition, you play as Artyom, a seasoned survivor of the nuclear war that wiped out most of humanity. As you journey across the ravaged landscape, you'll encounter a cast of memorable characters and uncover the mystery behind the doomsday device.

The gameplay in Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition is just as immersive as its predecessors, with a blend of stealth and action that keeps you on the edge of your seat. And with the added bonus of ray tracing, the graphics are absolutely stunning. The ray tracing really adds a level of realism to the world, making the destroyed cities and landscapes feel even more alive.

Overall, Metro Exodus Enhanced Edition is a must-play for fans of the series and newcomers alike. Just make sure you bring plenty of ammo and a sturdy flashlight - you never know what dangers lurk in the shadows.

Like its namesake, this third (and final?) installment in the Metro series is a bit of an exodus from the first two games. In some ways, it brings some much needed fresh air, and perhaps in other ways, is a bit in over its head.

The game's introductory sequence feels par for the course for Metro, but it is not long after that you begin to take on some of the big changes made this time around. Gone are the deep, dark crawls through Metro tunnels; instead, welcome in some open-world and above ground environments. No longer wishing to stay in Moscow, Artyom and the remaining rangers board a train, taking them well across Russia. 

There are three major 'hub' locations to explore, with some shorter, linear missions sprinkled between. I will say that these larger environments are very beautiful to both look at and pillage through. They are a far cry from the same train tunnels of 2033 and Last Light. However, at least a first, this feels like a detriment to the overall experience. Having grown used to the charm and almost cozy feel of the dimly lit underground, these new sprawling areas feel somewhat overwhelming. It often becomes difficult or even tedious to navigate, and while they look great, they simultaneously feel empty. 

I would spend much of my time exploring every nook and cranny that I could, only to find buildings devoid of any loot or anything of notable interest. Key locations, typically involving main missions or the handful of side quests generally bring more detailed areas, but you will find that there ultimately isn't much to do in the open-world beyond looking at some pretty scenery (which isn't entirely a bad thing) or fighting off the occasional mutant. 

Side quests are one of the places this game falls short. You are only provided a few per section, mainly being a quick fetch quest or clearing out a bandit camp. Going for this approach, I would have hoped they added more to do in these big expanses. Realistically, you could probably clear each main area in under an hour if are quick about it. 

The main reason to explore is to find supplies for the new crafting system. You can now locate various resources in the environment to craft items like medkits or ammo, as well as find new modifications for your weapons. Basic crafting can now be accomplish at any point using Arytoms backpack, with more advanced stuff needing to be done at workbenches scattered throughout the levels. While I appreciate this added element, it eventually starts to feel thin; like it needed more available options to work with. It wasn't long before I found certain weapons and attachments that I exclusively used the rest of the game, as there was not much else to mix and match. That said, it does still at least offer more customization than the first two.

Stealth is still a large part of the gameplay, and in fact heavily encouraged if you want to see the 'good' ending of the game. You can take out lights, hide in the darkness and choose to peacefully knock out enemies or stab them in the back. There are some more repercussion this time around for going in guns blazing any time you come up to an enemy encampment, but that option is still there for those with that preferred playstyle. Certain sections thankfully offer a few different approaches for variety, such as sneaking your way directly through a hostile camp, or scanning the environment for a side passage that bypasses it entirely. 

As far as enemy AI, it still feels roughly the same with only marginal improvements. It seems this time around, enemies are more prone to movement in efforts to dodge your shots. There were still some moments though where it could use some work. There were many times where I was hidden in darkness and absolutely sure I was out of enemy sight, only to immediately be discovered and alarms raised. General movement around the environment could have also used some work. Artyom now quickly becomes tired after sprinting and must slow to catch his breath if prolonged for too long. While this might help with realism, it quickly becomes an annoyance when you have such a large map to traverse. Additionally, some of the jumping and vaulting mechanics were quite finicky. At times, carried momentum from a jump would send me falling into water, or I would randomly get stuck against a rock and slow to walking speak for no reason.

Story of Exodus is more substantial, with greater stakes and more emotional moments. There is also a lot more detail and liveliness to the characters, helping the game to feel much less static than its predecessors. I won't spoil any of it here, but if there was one thing for sure worth playing the game for, it would be to see the final hurrah of our former subterranean dwellers. At its core, many of the key components that make of the series still work well and are fun on their own. It is with the drastic changes made that I wished they spent a little more time fleshing out, providing more for the playing to do and see. While maybe not the send-off that Metro needed from a mechanical perspective, the storytelling and visuals certainly do it justice.

For lack of better words, this game is fantastic. I paused my playthrough about halfway through and played the first two games...that's how quickly I fell in love with the setting. The story of Artyom doesn't continue where Last Light left off though...which I actually appreciate because the ending of Last Light was super lame. For the first time in the series, Artyom sets his sights on the idea of freedom and life outside the Metro (hence Metro "Exodus"). 

The narrative is phenomenal and I would absolutely call it a hidden gem in the current cesspool of AAA games. The characters are interesting, and you'll find yourself picking up great bits to the story if you stand around and listen to them talk. Of course, this is a little awkward since Artyom is a silent protagonist, but its cool nonetheless. The impacts of your decisions dictate some major occurrences in the game, and you'll pick up on Artyom's moral status from NPC dialog. 

Its similar to the morality mechanic in Red Dead Redemption 2. How good or bad you are dictates how the story unfolds. Unsurprisingly, this makes for outstanding immersion. This cheeky buzzword is overused by critics to describe games these days (which ends up being false), but there is no way left to describe it. 

Played at a moderate pace with exploration included, the game is about 21 hours long. Just like in the first two Metro games, taking side routes is rewarded with precious resources. The shift from the claustrophobic metro to the wide open wastes of a post apocalyptic Russia really enhances this element. Metro Exodus is one of the few games I can recommend at full price. You get away with robbery if purchased on sale. I've already purchased and played Two Colonels. Overall, Metro Exodus is a great game to sink the free hours of the holidays into!
